urn:contentItem:5W8B-GB31-JBHT-D4HK-00000-00Dueling Campaign Rallies; Countdown To Midterms; Facebook Data Protection; JPMorgan Fintech Campus; Halloween Spending; Musk Tweets Hyperloop Date2018-10-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:30ZLexisNexisDueling Campaign Rallies; Countdown To Midterms; Facebook Data Protection; JPMorgan Fintech Campus; Halloween Spending; Musk Tweets Hyperloop DateLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, ladies. Good morning to you. Thank you so much. Happy Monday. We'll see you in a little bit, girls. Thank you. It is Monday, October 27th -- October 22nd. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining me. I'm Maria Bartiromo.

Markets this morning are higher. Here are your top stories. 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Fighting for gains, futures indicating the markets this morning will open fractionally better on the session. Dow Industrials up 25, NASDAQ up 31 right now, half a percent higher.

This after a mixed story on Wall Street on Friday. The market snapped a two-day losing streak, posting a slight gain on the session with the Dow Industrials up 65 points, quarter of a percent, the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ weaker on Friday at the close.

In Europe this morning, markets are edging higher, take a look. FT-100 up a half percent, the CAC Quarante in Paris is up a quarter of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany up one-third of a percent, 40 points higher.

In Asia overnight, gains across the board at the close. And as you see, the Shanghai Composite, the best performer out of China, up better than four percent on the session.

Stocks in china soaring. The government revealing tax changes to help support the slowing economy. And with that, a multi-move across the board, and the averages, best in four years.

Investors bracing for the busiest week of earnings season so far. Ten Dow Components due to report their third quarter earnings, plus technology giants Amazon and Alphabet on deck this week.

On Friday, we get the first look at third quarter GDP. That could be a market mover. We'll break it all down and we got all the preview on earnings as well.

Another round of tax cuts could be on the way. President Trump says that he wants to get something done before November eight days from now, what that means ahead of the midterm elections this morning.

And upholding the alliance, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, is headed to Saudi Arabia today, amid pressure to take action against the Kingdom after it admitted to the death of Jamal Khashoggi.

Senator Lindsey Graham telling me on Sunday Morning Futures he felt used by the crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, but he's open to keeping the arms seal -- sales deal on track.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: I find it impossible to believe that the Crown Prince was not involved. So, go after him and his inner circle, save they alliance.

I don't mind military sales, but I cannot do business with the current leadership. MBS, he's done to me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The fallout coming up this morning.

Plus, caravan crisis, thousands of illegal immigrants crossing into Mexico with their sights on the U.S.A. We're going to take you live to the border to get an update on that caravan this morning.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Benchmark Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly, and Independent Women's Voice CEO, Heather Higgins, is here this morning. Good to see you.

HEATHER HIGGINS, CEO, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S VOICE: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Welcome.

HIGGINS: Thank you

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK INVESTMENTS: It's going to be a hectic week.

BARTIROMO: Hectic week because of earnings, hectic week because of?

MCDOWELL: GDP out on Friday. We find out how fast this country was growing in the third quarter and if we need more tax cuts, quite frankly.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good point. President said that on the campaigns trial on Saturday, but it's also a huge week for earnings. We've got technology in the spotlight, Amazon and Alphabet may very well move markets.

KELLY: Yes, big time. Especially because I'm looking forward to Verizon tomorrow because they're going to talk about their 5G rollout. They did it in four different cities. So, that's the way with the future.

We'll see how much capital they need to put into that. That's part of the Infrastructure Bill. Remember the President keeps talking about infrastructure?

HIGGINS: Uh-hmm.

KELLY: Well, 5G is part of that.

BARTIROMO: The GDP number on Friday, Dagen, I guess the, you know, Atlanta Fed was all the way up at, what, four -- better than 4.5 percent, 4.8 percent or so?

MCDOWELL: Right. But the --

BARTIROMO: Where are we now on that?

MCDOWELL: Well, the Wall Street Journal, in its estimate, so it was 4.2 percent in the second quarter, but the third quarter is expected to come in at 3.4 percent in the preliminary reading. A wide --

BARTIROMO: Still a good number.

MCDOWELL: A widening trade gap could be a drag on third quarter GDP.

BARTIROMO: Ooh.

MCDOWELL: Based on the Journal.

BARTIROMO: There you go. So good backdrop, Heather.

HIGGINS: It is now. And they're -- the administration's really happy with anything over three percent just because we --- they keep saying -- everybody said even three percent was impossible.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

HIGGINS: We're so happy to have anything over three percent. That is great. And so -- but they're looking at these four percent plus numbers and they're thrilled.

BARTIROMO: So you get the biggest week of third quarter earnings so far. That's going to also show you some real growth. That means like Amazon, Microsoft, Google parent company, Alphabet, all setting to report along with 10 Dow Components.

On the economic side, the highlight of the week, of course, is that GDP report. And in terms of what we're going to see in terms of market expectations. Pretty much baked in a better than three percent number?

KELLY: Yes. I think it is. One of the things that has weighed on economists has been the tariffs, and so that's why the look-through into tech earnings this week is, what have the implications been.

Especially when you think about Apple, they come out next week. They haven't updated the guidance, but they said the tariffs are a tax on consumers. So, how is that going to impact their phone sales, especially because they came out with new releases?

I think it's interesting to note that technology stocks are only valued seven percent higher than the general market. The market's trading about 15.9 times earnings, tech's around 16.6, but they have twice the profit margins.

So, let's see what the guidance is coming forward. So you saw Goldman Sachs even came out earlier this week. I mean, last week.

They were talking about how tech isn't overvalued and that this the selloff has been unwarranted, but it's important to note that investors have been rotating into safer names.

They don't think we're going to get 10, 20, 30 percent returns going forward. They went into consumer staples stocks. Consumer staples stocks are up 3.5 percent over the last month.

MCDOWELL: Right.

KELLY: Technology stocks are down 3.5 percent.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: One thing to also watch out for, the Wall Street Journal writes about this in today's paper. Slowing sales growth.

So instead of earnings, because, again, if sales growth slows -- and we have had, according to the Journal, 35 percent of the S&P 500 companies have reported so far. Based on our estimates, it's actually 38 percent, miss-sales forecasts.

If sustained, that quarterly sales miss-ratio would mark the highest so far this year. So again, if you're coming up short on sales for whatever reason, whether it's higher prices that you -- you're not -- that you're trying to pass on and people aren't buying it, whatever the reason, that doesn't bode well for earnings growth into next year.

And sales are only growing, are expected to grow 7.3 percent, which is slightly lower than expectations going into this quarter.

BARTIROMO: And, of course, the guidance is going to be reflecting what the expectations are on the trade situation, right? On tariffs.

Because if we start -- this is when we're going to know. I mean, companies should probably guide us toward us, "All right, we're going to see lower sales than expected because of the tariffs."

I don't know that's the case, but I would imagine this is the quarter when we find out if, in fact, it is going to weigh on earnings.

KELLY: Yes. I think the most important thing that the market's going to focus is operating margins. They think margins are going to come down and be compressed because several factors. Some of them are the rising input costs, now we're seeing inflation's going up.

We're also seeing labor costs are going up, costs of goods are going up.

HIGGINS: Right.

KELLY: So the problem is this, how are they going to be able to maintain that, if they're not able to get more productivity out of their workers?

MCDOWELL: Right. If you can pass on these higher costs, which like with Unilever, some of the big consumer products companies, then that's good news. The --

I mean not ultimately to the customer, but it's good news for the companies again, but it's -- again, the higher input costs, you can't --

KELLY: Yes. It's --

MCDOWELL: For whatever reason, it's not just tariffs. Watch a lot of companies potentially, if they're coming up short, start to blame tariffs.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: You're going to have to kind of comb through the -- try and separate the fact from the fiction.

HIGGINS: It'll be --

KELLY: Also the storm, they'll see that in -- about the storms, right? So we -- they'll think next quarter's going to be weak because of the storms, whatever's happening.

We've seen -- Home Depot should be strong, but they actually got a downgrade last week because they think the consumer's not going to be as strong in upgrading their homes.

BARTIROMO: Well, whatever weakness we see, the President's trying to offset it now with talk of more tax cuts ahead of the election.

He spoke to reporters just this weekend about a package that they're working on right now. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We are looking at putting in a very major tax cut for middle income people. And if we do that, it will be sometime, just prior I would say to November.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Of course, Election Day is 15 days away at this point, November 1st. Ten days away.

MCDOWELL: He didn't say which November.

BARTIROMO: I mean, of course, you know, Congress is out of session until after the November Elections.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Exactly.

BARTIROMO: So maybe he comes out with an announcement before midterm elections, but we're not going to see a vote, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No. And quite frankly, the deficit is becoming -- it's starting to become an issue for politicians and for the American people.

President Trump said "I'm ordering all my cabinet secretaries to cut their spending by 5 percent. But discretionary spending is what one-third -- roughly one-third of the entire budget every year. And if you cut out defense, it's a cut -- I think it represents less than one percent of overall spending.

So again, I don't -- he -- it would take -- it's a long road to plow in terms of pushing through a tax cut at this point.

BARTIROMO: But we know they want to make the individual cut permanent and we know that that's going to be on their agenda should they have the opportunity, even after the midterm elections.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Maybe it --I mean he said Kevin Brady is working on it.

HIGGINS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: House, Ways and Means. So maybe it's an announcement from House, Ways and Means before the midterms.

HIGGINS: It could be. They won't get anything passed. But it's been pretty clear that even though they passed the first tax cut, that even though they were constrained by certain prior agreements to have the individual cuts be temporary, the goal was always to make those be permanent.

You are now seeing a recovery which, for the first time in a very long time, is being led by blue-collar job growth, blue-collar wages, small business confidence, rather than leading from the top.

It's sort of from the bottom. And those people are going to be going into the midterms looking at this fantastically booming economy.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HIGGINS: Trump's approval ratings are now higher than Obama's were going into his first midterms. And his disapproval ratings have actually come down, layering on a promised middle-class tax cuts can't hurt.

And -- because serious way, if you want to take on the deficit, and this may be the one President who can cut through the swamp and actually get this done, because the creatures on both sides of the aisle like the current services baseline, economic gains that would never, ever be allowed in the private sector in terms of automatic budget increases and claiming.

Because, you know, they get to claim to these two different constituents coming into their office and for the exact same thing, they get to claim that they were either cutting it or increasing it because of the semantics involved with the built-in increases.

KELLY: Right.

HIGGINS: If you're serious about taking on the deficit, then have you to be serious on taking on the financial accounting games that are played in Washington.

BARTIROMO: And there's Saudi Arabia on deck as well. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin now defending his decision to go to Saudi. He's meeting with Saudi officials in Riyadh this week.

He says the trip is aimed at reinforcing ties at this critical moment. He's not going to that conference, but this trip comes after Saudi Arabia said that Washington Post journalist, Jamal Khashoggi, was in fact killed in a fist fight inside the Istanbul Consulate.

The Kingdom is forcefully denying any connection between the killing and the Crown Prince, Mohammed bin Salman. Lawmakers, though, are showing skepticism on that.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SEAN HANNITY, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: Did the Crown Prince know anything about it? If there were people closely tied to him involved in this operation?

ADEL BIN AHMED AL-JUBEIR, DIPLOMAT, SAUDI MINISTER OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS: There weren't people closely tied to him who were involved in this operation. This was an operation that was a rogue operation.

This was an operation where individuals ended up exceeding the authorities and responsibilities they had.

GRAHAM: it's ridiculous to believe that 18 people would go to Turkey to kill Mr. Khashoggi and nobody in the government know about it. That would be brazen abuse of authority.

He was clearly murdered in a consulate. Things like that don't happen in Saudi Arabia without people at the top knowing.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Dagen, your thoughts?

MCDOWELL: I will quote the Wall Street Journal editorial today on this very issue. Saudi Arabia needs to step up. We still don't know -- they haven't produced Khashoggi's body, provided more details of precisely how or when he decide.

The story doesn't add up. Of the 18 people arrested, five others sacked, several a part of Mohammed bin Salman the inner circle. It's unlikely they would have acted alone without at least, you know, feeling a tacit assent from the Crown Prince.

The Wall Street Journal editorial goes on to write, "The U.S. goal should be to preserve our alliance with Saudi Arabia while making clear that murdering journalists is unacceptable and that Mohammed bin Salman's erratic judgment and willful use of power are problems for the bilateral relationship."

We can't dictate what King Salman will do about who should run Saudi Arabia, but you can -- but Mohammed bin Salman also can't be allowed to conclude that America thinks this is no big deal.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And they've got to do something. The U.S. has to do something to push back in the face of this heinous situation.

Question is, does Mohammed bin Salman survive? He's got two other sons. There are a lot of people who want this guy out at this point. Lindsey Graham included.

So big question here, you know, I mean, the arms sales is going -- it's going to go through. The relationship is going to go through because there's one big black eye here that we're faced with and that is Iran, so.

MCDOWELL: But the muddled response from this administration and the uneven response that we've seen since this all began, we need to be on very firm footing about the message, like Lindsey Graham said that we send to King Salman about who we -- who should run the country.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HIGGINS: I want to disagree. I think that the administration has been taking a difficult situation. These are people that behaved really badly, like so many of the people we've had to deal with. And they've got this challenge of how do you negotiate making them pay for it, making them fess up to it, but not having them lose so much for --

MCDOWELL: But comparing it to Brett Kavanaugh was a misstep. I'm sorry.

BARTIROMO: Right. All right. We'll take a break.

When we come back, it's shifting gears for FiatChrysler. Details on the automaker's roughly $7 billion car parts deal. That's next.

And then a spooky box office debut, we've got it here on Halloween. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Battle at the border for sure, a migrant caravan moving toward the United States. It has grown now to roughly 5,000 people. Griff Jenkins is live in McAllen, Texas this morning with details there, right in the middle of it. Griff.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

That's why we've got to secure our border. That's why we've got to build the wall and make sure that our southern border is safe.

But also, to make sure that we have other technology because it's very important to realize that the wall can be built in certain areas but there are other areas where the wall can't be built. We have to use other advanced technologies to make sure that we keep the illegal immigration from coming across.

BARTIROMO: But how much -- Kevin McCarthy says that this bill funds $23 billion, which is what's needed for the border wall because $1.5 billion has already been accounted for.

I will say this. If we get the McCarthy bill passed, and I think we will in the House, it will give the Senate particularly this year an opportunity to sit down and get that done and build the wall in a much more robust way.

Let's face it. We did start with $5 billion, that's a start. I actually sit on the Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee on the Appropriations Committee and that's very important to me. It's important to our subcommittee. I think it's important to most Americans. We're seeing by virtue of this caravan right now just how chaotic and really anarchistic the border situation has become.

But we need to refine it now. Obviously it was so important to get tax reform passed. We got no help from the Democrats. That's actually very sad. And I think that's going to hurt them in the midterms.

This was a very good bill the first time. We're just going to make it better.

BARTIROMO: Ok. But I mean the economy is growing well.

You incentivize investment. Whether you're John Kennedy, Ronald Reagan or Donald Trump, you realize lower taxes means ultimately more money for the Treasury. And I think that's a good thing.

When we talk about deficits, we actually have to look at the spending side of the equation and sadly really no one wants to look at that right now, especially on the mandatory side of the equation. Ultimately, I hope we get there.

But if we don't have a taxing problem in America, we have a spending problem in America. So right now, more money in the hands of hard-working Americans is good for the economy and good for the country.

BURMAN: Fifteen days as you mentioned until the midterm elections and the newest poll from The Wall Street Journal and NBC News shows that Americans are tuned in, 68 percent of Republicans say that they have high interest in the upcoming elections while that number is just a tick higher at 72 percent for Democrats. (CROSSTALK)

HIGGINS: His disapproval numbers are lower than they were before.

BARTIROMO: So it's going --

HIGGINS: Yes, those are.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A big week ahead. Lots of corporate earnings and big economic news. Deirdre Bolton on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange this morning with details there. Deidre, good morning.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That is right. Good morning, Maria. So a tenth of the Dow components, so 10 companies, that would be a third actually in the Dow 30 are going to be reporting this week. CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, Maria. This happened over the weekend a rafting accident killed four American tourists and a Costa Rican guide in the Central American country. Plus, British businesses already rolling back spending ahead of a formal exit of Britain from the E.U. U.K. Secretary of State for International Trade Lim Fox joins me exclusively to weigh in, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Monday, October 22nd. Your top stories right now 8:31 a.m. on the East Coast. Markets are rallying this morning; Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading of 110 points, this is the high of the morning, up one half of one percent on the industrial average as we enter a huge week in terms of third quarter earnings. The S&P is up 12, and the NASDAQ right now up almost one percent, 63 points higher on the NASDAQ.

European trading similar story. Take a look at the markets in Europe right now. The FTSE100 in London is up almost one percent, 57 points higher. The CAC Quarante in Paris up a third of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany up two-thirds of one percent, 66 points higher. Asian markets closed higher overnight, pretty much across the board. Best performer, look at Asia, Shanghai composite in China -- look at China, rather, Hong Kong up 2-1/3 percent, Shanghai up better than four percent.

The price of oil inching higher this morning as we are now just two weeks away from U.S. sanctions on crude exports from Iran. Why one big name is saying that these oil prices are unhealthy for the world, at $69.9 a barrel on crude right now.

All those coming up this morning, but, first our top story this half an hour targeting trade. The United States, and E.U., trying to hammer out a deal. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross recently said that progress has been unsatisfactory, his word not mine. The U.S. and the U.K. also working to secure a stronger trade ties as U.K. navigates its exit from the European Union. There is an important meeting this week, between E.U. lawmakers and the U.S., and that is the 23rd; so, we will see what comes out of that meeting.

Joining us right now is Dr. Liam Fox, he is the U.K. Secretary of State for International Trade and the President of the Board of Trade. It is good to see you, Dr. Fox, thanks so much for joining us.

DR. LIAM FOX, U.K. SECRETARY OF STATE FOR INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND PRESIDENT OF THE BOARD OF TRADE: Nice to see you again.

BARTIROMO: First off, tell us what's at stake here in terms of what's -- what the negotiations look like between U.K., and E.U.?

FOX: Well, we're looking to get withdrawal agreement where we can maximize our access to the E.U. market and make an access there to the U.K. market, but without tying hands about future opportunities in the growing parts of the world. The IMS saying that 90 percent globally growth in the next 10 to 15 years will be outside continental Europe. We obviously have to be free to able to take advantage of that and not be tied by any agreement with the E.U. after we leave.

BARTIROMO: So, is that only way you can do a deal with E.U., that it's, like, exclusive that you will not have access to other bilateral deals?

FOX: No, we said one of the conditions of leaving it is that we have to have an independent trade policy. It's one of the main reasons that I campaigned and voted to leave. But we also have, other areas of contention too with E.U.; we will not have any parts of the United Kingdom treated differently from any other, particularly Northern Ireland. We want to ensure that we do not get any restrictions on us, for example the tax harmonization with the E.U. afterwards, and we have to ensure that we ultimately have control over the date at which we end in the transition period.

BARTIROMO: And the E.U. is saying, well, what's in it for us?

FOX: Access to the world's fifth biggest market.

BARTIROMO: There you go.

FOX: And Germany's biggest trading partner. And we will be the biggest trading partner -- second biggest trading partner in the world from the European Union when we leave. So, it's crazy to introduce impediments to trade or investment that don't exist today. Why would we want to see tariffs on our goods and add costs to our consumers?

BARTIROMO: And you're willing to go as far as you have to go with this stance, right? Because these are tenuous talks -- I mean, people are wondering if, in fact, Britain does exit the E.U. Theresa May, is she committed?

FOX: We'll be leaving the E.U. in 29th of March next year. The question is, under what conditions and what our future relationship looks like? And as the prime minister will tell the House of Commons today, the deal is 95 percent done but we have these areas, where our sovereignty is at stake.

BARTIROMO: You said it very, very well -- very articulate. You're hosting International Trade Day here in New York to strengthen the trade ties between U.S. and the U.K., tell us about that. What do you want to see with U.S.?

FOX: Well, we have a unique relationship with U.S. And it's our biggest single export market as a country. We have a trillion dollars invested in one another's countries, and really, the Americans put to work for U.K. companies and vice versa every day. So, it's very important that we look at future of these growing global markets, see where we have restrictions, what we can do with one another, how do we help, for example, our SMEs? How do we help protect in areas like cybersecurity -- these are the issues that we're discussing today?

BARTIROMO: Yes, what would you like to see in a bilateral deal with U.S. I know that there are issues in terms of Europe and U.K., but specifically the U.K. and the U.S., what might that look like?

FOX: Well, we want to see where there are restrictions in terms of tariffs and goods, but if you look at real opportunity, it's for us to move forward. This is -- the U.S. is the biggest globally service exporter, we're second. If we can get liberalization there, fantastic. If can get a move towards a single market, for example in financial services, that would be ground breaking globally.

BARTIROMO: But how does that -- how does that jive with what's happening already for financial services companies? I mean, you know that businesses need certainty. And over this last year, businesses weren't sure how this would play out, and so they've tried to hedge their bets -- putting some of their employees in Germany, trying to take some others out. I mean, the exit from the European Union has confused some people, certainly financial services companies. Theresa May, the Prime Minister, said that this deal is 95 percent complete, which you just said a moment ago, but have you already seen disruption as a result of the uncertainty?

FOX: No, we've seen, actually, more investment coming into U.K.

BARTIROMO: How?

FOX: Last year, Britain maintained its place as the third top destination for foreign direct investment in the world, and the top in Europe which even when we're seeing a decline in global FDI, there's still an increase in the U.K. It was remarkable. London is still the number one metropolitan destination of the world for investment. And last year, in venture capital on tech, we saw more come into London, just one city, than the whole of France, Germany, Spain and Ireland put together. So, investors have maintained their confidence because of the underlying economic fundamentals in the U.K.

BARTIROMO: Very interesting and you make good point about the services part this. This is what you'd like to see up with the U.S.?

FOX: Well, the time to meet regulation is where you have market dominance, and why would we wait until China came up lead, for example, before we set the rules around global services? This our time. This is the time, when we can have biggest impact, on our future perspective.

BARTIROMO: Do you think that the world has gotten unified behind pushing back on China in terms of their behavior with regard to, you know, stealing intellectual property, forcing the transfer of technology. I mean, the President and the United States, obviously, Donald Trump has been pushing back on China but is U.K. there with the U.S.?

FOX: In the analysis, yes, that we want to see over production end subsidy, lack of transparency, not knowing what state and what's private, all that analysis we share. Of course, we don't share the two-three-two mechanism and doing under guise of national security, because in the U.K. we are -- hosting our day on the (INAUDIBLE) carrier setting up New York Harbor, and we supply steel into the U.S. military. And yet, we're not having supply on national security ground, so it's the mechanism we disagree with, not the analysis.

BARTIROMO: Do you believe those tariffs on steel go away if you close do close a bilateral trade deal with the United States?

FOX: Well, they are sanctions on the European Union. So, when we leave the E.U., then that's an issue between the U.K., and the United States -- that becomes bilateral.

BARTIROMO: But has that been one of the talking points, has that been among your negotiating with the United States when you do get a bilateral deal with U.S. Do you want -- obviously, you want the tariffs to go away on steel, right?

FOX: We won't want that, but, of course --

BARTIROMO: But have they indicated they would?

FOX: And we are not allowed, actually, to negotiate that while we're members of the European Union under E.U. law.

BARTIROMO: I see. OK, so that's the sticking point. When would you expect all of these deals to take place? You say the U.K. is going to be exiting March 29th of 2019, when would you see a realistic date for a trade deal to be in place with the E.U. and the U.S.?

FOX: Well, we have -- we'll expect the E.U. at one point of exit, we'll obviously have that relationship in place. For the United States, we finished our public consultation, this month, on future trade arrangements. The U.S. would like to see that in place by the end of 2020.

BARTIROMO: The President has talked about no tariffs, no -- you know, no taxes on any imports and exports. Is that something that you've discussed?

FOX: That would be a wonderful place to be. Why would we have any costs for our consumers that we didn't have to have.

BARTIROMO: Well, people say that then when they're actually talking about it, you all -- you are giving up money that's already been yours from the U.S. being at a disadvantage in a lot of these deals.

FOX: Well, there's a differential on car tariffs, for example, the automobiles. But there's a 25 percent tariff applied by the U.S. to U.K. light trucks, we'd like to see that go. That is not just tariff, of course, it's the nontariff barriers, and that's what we've seen an escalation in, in G20 countries over this decade. Back in 2010, we were operating that 300 none tariff barriers to trade, now the G20 are operating 1200, and that's just not acceptable trend.

BARTIROMO: What is the catalyst that we need to be aware of in terms of U.K.-U.S. deal going forward? What should we be watching?

FOX: Well, we'll begin those discussions when we leave the E.U., so that will be the end of March next year. And at that point, we'll both set out what we think our ambitions are, what are asks of one another. We are in favor of general liberalization of trade. The U.K. is a very free trade in country. We'll want to see what we can do outside the E.U. that the E.U. couldn't do, for example, on data movement. The E.U. has got restrictions on data movement that U.K. is not committed to, so we can see the where we got areas that we can make progress that we have at the moment.

BARTIROMO: How important is securing the borders for the U.K.?

FOX: Well, our borders need to be secured in terms of the U.K. must determine who comes into the United Kingdom and who doesn't. One of three reasons that we gave for leaving the European Union is control of our money, control of our laws and control of our borders.

BARTIROMO: Yes, why do you think the U.K. has been the under performer of the European economy in all of this? Has it been uncertainty of it? Or how would you characterize the economy and U.K. right now?

FOX: See, if you look at an economy, that had its -- an increase in exports of 10.6 percent last year, the third top destination for investments in the world, and the top in Europe. And unemployment rate just dropping below four percent.

BARTIROMO: So, you're not buying it, you think things are going well in the U.K.?

FOX: The reason why investors are still coming is that economic fundamentals are strong. There are a number of people who've never really come to terms with losing the referendum, and seem to resent the fact our economy is performing so strongly. They told us that we'd see a half a million jobs lost; we have added 600,000 to the economy since the referendum.

BARTIROMO: Fair enough, that was fake news, I guess. Let me ask you about Saudi Arabia.

FOX: Fake prediction.

BARTIROMO: Fake prediction. You recently pulled out of the Future Investment Initiative in Saudi Arabia, joining a long list of people to do that including, Fox. Do you see the decision affecting the U.K.'s relationship with the kingdom? What do you want to see in terms of the Saudi Arabian government post Jamal KhashoggI's murder?

FOX: We want a suitable explanation, and one that is backed up by credible investigation. We've had a slightly different view from Saudi government overnight about how this event happened. We want to verify that.

BARTIROMO: And put this in the scheme of priorities for the U.K. as you look forward toward your Brexit moment next year, what are the priorities for the U.K., in terms of global affairs?

FOX: Well, we want to get a good result for with our European partners and future trade, that's still 44 percent of our exports. But we want to make sure that other trading partners in the world are able to trade more freely with us, the United States, being the top.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So, it's all about trade. In terms of --

FOX: In terms of trade, because I think trade under pins global security. How we put it is that trade is a means to spread prosperity, prosperity under pins social cohesion, social cohesion contributes to political stability, and that's the bedrock of our collective security. So, let's make sure that people can all share, in that prosperity that we generate. But of course, we have to generate it first.

BARTIROMO: Very well said, Dr. Liam Fox, it's good to see you. Thanks so much. We'll be watching your international day of trade today. Liam Fox there.

SCHORK: Well, let's look at this rationally, Maria. urn:contentItem:5WB8-DDG1-DY0W-408D-00000-00Dueling Campaign Rallies; Countdown To Midterms; Facebook Data Protection; JPMorgan Fintech Campus; Halloween Spending; Musk Tweets Hyperloop Date2018-10-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:30ZLexisNexisDueling Campaign Rallies; Countdown To Midterms; Facebook Data Protection; JPMorgan Fintech Campus; Halloween Spending; Musk Tweets Hyperloop DateLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, ladies. Good morning to you. Thank you so much. Happy Monday. We'll see you in a little bit, girls. Thank you. It is Monday, October 27th -- October 22nd. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining me. I'm Maria Bartiromo.

Markets this morning are higher. Here are your top stories. 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Fighting for gains, futures indicating the markets this morning will open fractionally better on the session. Dow Industrials up 25, NASDAQ up 31 right now, half a percent higher.

This after a mixed story on Wall Street on Friday. The market snapped a two-day losing streak, posting a slight gain on the session with the Dow Industrials up 65 points, quarter of a percent, the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ weaker on Friday at the close.

In Europe this morning, markets are edging higher, take a look. FT-100 up a half percent, the CAC Quarante in Paris is up a quarter of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany up one-third of a percent, 40 points higher.

In Asia overnight, gains across the board at the close. And as you see, the Shanghai Composite, the best performer out of China, up better than four percent on the session.

Stocks in china soaring. The government revealing tax changes to help support the slowing economy. And with that, a multi-move across the board, and the averages, best in four years.

Investors bracing for the busiest week of earnings season so far. Ten Dow Components due to report their third quarter earnings, plus technology giants Amazon and Alphabet on deck this week.

On Friday, we get the first look at third quarter GDP. That could be a market mover. We'll break it all down and we got all the preview on earnings as well.

Another round of tax cuts could be on the way. President Trump says that he wants to get something done before November eight days from now, what that means ahead of the midterm elections this morning.

And upholding the alliance, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, is headed to Saudi Arabia today, amid pressure to take action against the Kingdom after it admitted to the death of Jamal Khashoggi.

Senator Lindsey Graham telling me on Sunday Morning Futures he felt used by the crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, but he's open to keeping the arms seal -- sales deal on track.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: I find it impossible to believe that the Crown Prince was not involved. So, go after him and his inner circle, save they alliance.

I don't mind military sales, but I cannot do business with the current leadership. MBS, he's done to me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The fallout coming up this morning.

Plus, caravan crisis, thousands of illegal immigrants crossing into Mexico with their sights on the U.S.A. We're going to take you live to the border to get an update on that caravan this morning.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Benchmark Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly, and Independent Women's Voice CEO, Heather Higgins, is here this morning. Good to see you.

HEATHER HIGGINS, CEO, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S VOICE: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Welcome.

HIGGINS: Thank you

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK INVESTMENTS: It's going to be a hectic week.

BARTIROMO: Hectic week because of earnings, hectic week because of?

MCDOWELL: GDP out on Friday. We find out how fast this country was growing in the third quarter and if we need more tax cuts, quite frankly.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good point. President said that on the campaigns trial on Saturday, but it's also a huge week for earnings. We've got technology in the spotlight, Amazon and Alphabet may very well move markets.

KELLY: Yes, big time. Especially because I'm looking forward to Verizon tomorrow because they're going to talk about their 5G rollout. They did it in four different cities. So, that's the way with the future.

We'll see how much capital they need to put into that. That's part of the Infrastructure Bill. Remember the President keeps talking about infrastructure?

HIGGINS: Uh-hmm.

KELLY: Well, 5G is part of that.

BARTIROMO: The GDP number on Friday, Dagen, I guess the, you know, Atlanta Fed was all the way up at, what, four -- better than 4.5 percent, 4.8 percent or so?

MCDOWELL: Right. But the --

BARTIROMO: Where are we now on that?

MCDOWELL: Well, the Wall Street Journal, in its estimate, so it was 4.2 percent in the second quarter, but the third quarter is expected to come in at 3.4 percent in the preliminary reading. A wide --

BARTIROMO: Still a good number.

MCDOWELL: A widening trade gap could be a drag on third quarter GDP.

BARTIROMO: Ooh.

MCDOWELL: Based on the Journal.

BARTIROMO: There you go. So good backdrop, Heather.

HIGGINS: It is now. And they're -- the administration's really happy with anything over three percent just because we --- they keep saying -- everybody said even three percent was impossible.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

HIGGINS: We're so happy to have anything over three percent. That is great. And so -- but they're looking at these four percent plus numbers and they're thrilled.

BARTIROMO: So you get the biggest week of third quarter earnings so far. That's going to also show you some real growth. That means like Amazon, Microsoft, Google parent company, Alphabet, all setting to report along with 10 Dow Components.

On the economic side, the highlight of the week, of course, is that GDP report. And in terms of what we're going to see in terms of market expectations. Pretty much baked in a better than three percent number?

KELLY: Yes. I think it is. One of the things that has weighed on economists has been the tariffs, and so that's why the look-through into tech earnings this week is, what have the implications been.

Especially when you think about Apple, they come out next week. They haven't updated the guidance, but they said the tariffs are a tax on consumers. So, how is that going to impact their phone sales, especially because they came out with new releases?

I think it's interesting to note that technology stocks are only valued seven percent higher than the general market. The market's trading about 15.9 times earnings, tech's around 16.6, but they have twice the profit margins.

So, let's see what the guidance is coming forward. So you saw Goldman Sachs even came out earlier this week. I mean, last week.

They were talking about how tech isn't overvalued and that this the selloff has been unwarranted, but it's important to note that investors have been rotating into safer names.

They don't think we're going to get 10, 20, 30 percent returns going forward. They went into consumer staples stocks. Consumer staples stocks are up 3.5 percent over the last month.

MCDOWELL: Right.

KELLY: Technology stocks are down 3.5 percent.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: One thing to also watch out for, the Wall Street Journal writes about this in today's paper. Slowing sales growth.

So instead of earnings, because, again, if sales growth slows -- and we have had, according to the Journal, 35 percent of the S&P 500 companies have reported so far. Based on our estimates, it's actually 38 percent, miss-sales forecasts.

If sustained, that quarterly sales miss-ratio would mark the highest so far this year. So again, if you're coming up short on sales for whatever reason, whether it's higher prices that you -- you're not -- that you're trying to pass on and people aren't buying it, whatever the reason, that doesn't bode well for earnings growth into next year.

And sales are only growing, are expected to grow 7.3 percent, which is slightly lower than expectations going into this quarter.

BARTIROMO: And, of course, the guidance is going to be reflecting what the expectations are on the trade situation, right? On tariffs.

Because if we start -- this is when we're going to know. I mean, companies should probably guide us toward us, "All right, we're going to see lower sales than expected because of the tariffs."

I don't know that's the case, but I would imagine this is the quarter when we find out if, in fact, it is going to weigh on earnings.

KELLY: Yes. I think the most important thing that the market's going to focus is operating margins. They think margins are going to come down and be compressed because several factors. Some of them are the rising input costs, now we're seeing inflation's going up.

We're also seeing labor costs are going up, costs of goods are going up.

HIGGINS: Right.

KELLY: So the problem is this, how are they going to be able to maintain that, if they're not able to get more productivity out of their workers?

MCDOWELL: Right. If you can pass on these higher costs, which like with Unilever, some of the big consumer products companies, then that's good news. The --

I mean not ultimately to the customer, but it's good news for the companies again, but it's -- again, the higher input costs, you can't --

KELLY: Yes. It's --

MCDOWELL: For whatever reason, it's not just tariffs. Watch a lot of companies potentially, if they're coming up short, start to blame tariffs.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: You're going to have to kind of comb through the -- try and separate the fact from the fiction.

HIGGINS: It'll be --

KELLY: Also the storm, they'll see that in -- about the storms, right? So we -- they'll think next quarter's going to be weak because of the storms, whatever's happening.

We've seen -- Home Depot should be strong, but they actually got a downgrade last week because they think the consumer's not going to be as strong in upgrading their homes.

BARTIROMO: Well, whatever weakness we see, the President's trying to offset it now with talk of more tax cuts ahead of the election.

He spoke to reporters just this weekend about a package that they're working on right now. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We are looking at putting in a very major tax cut for middle income people. And if we do that, it will be sometime, just prior I would say to November.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Of course, Election Day is 15 days away at this point, November 1st. Ten days away.

MCDOWELL: He didn't say which November.

BARTIROMO: I mean, of course, you know, Congress is out of session until after the November Elections.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Exactly.

BARTIROMO: So maybe he comes out with an announcement before midterm elections, but we're not going to see a vote, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No. And quite frankly, the deficit is becoming -- it's starting to become an issue for politicians and for the American people.

President Trump said "I'm ordering all my cabinet secretaries to cut their spending by 5 percent. But discretionary spending is what one-third -- roughly one-third of the entire budget every year. And if you cut out defense, it's a cut -- I think it represents less than one percent of overall spending.

So again, I don't -- he -- it would take -- it's a long road to plow in terms of pushing through a tax cut at this point.

BARTIROMO: But we know they want to make the individual cut permanent and we know that that's going to be on their agenda should they have the opportunity, even after the midterm elections.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Maybe it --I mean he said Kevin Brady is working on it.

HIGGINS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: House, Ways and Means. So maybe it's an announcement from House, Ways and Means before the midterms.

HIGGINS: It could be. They won't get anything passed. But it's been pretty clear that even though they passed the first tax cut, that even though they were constrained by certain prior agreements to have the individual cuts be temporary, the goal was always to make those be permanent.

You are now seeing a recovery which, for the first time in a very long time, is being led by blue-collar job growth, blue-collar wages, small business confidence, rather than leading from the top.

It's sort of from the bottom. And those people are going to be going into the midterms looking at this fantastically booming economy.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HIGGINS: Trump's approval ratings are now higher than Obama's were going into his first midterms. And his disapproval ratings have actually come down, layering on a promised middle-class tax cuts can't hurt.

And -- because serious way, if you want to take on the deficit, and this may be the one President who can cut through the swamp and actually get this done, because the creatures on both sides of the aisle like the current services baseline, economic gains that would never, ever be allowed in the private sector in terms of automatic budget increases and claiming.

Because, you know, they get to claim to these two different constituents coming into their office and for the exact same thing, they get to claim that they were either cutting it or increasing it because of the semantics involved with the built-in increases.

KELLY: Right.

HIGGINS: If you're serious about taking on the deficit, then have you to be serious on taking on the financial accounting games that are played in Washington.

BARTIROMO: And there's Saudi Arabia on deck as well. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin now defending his decision to go to Saudi. He's meeting with Saudi officials in Riyadh this week.

He says the trip is aimed at reinforcing ties at this critical moment. He's not going to that conference, but this trip comes after Saudi Arabia said that Washington Post journalist, Jamal Khashoggi, was in fact killed in a fist fight inside the Istanbul Consulate.

The Kingdom is forcefully denying any connection between the killing and the Crown Prince, Mohammed bin Salman. Lawmakers, though, are showing skepticism on that.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SEAN HANNITY, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST: Did the Crown Prince know anything about it? If there were people closely tied to him involved in this operation?

ADEL BIN AHMED AL-JUBEIR, DIPLOMAT, SAUDI MINISTER OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS: There weren't people closely tied to him who were involved in this operation. This was an operation that was a rogue operation.

This was an operation where individuals ended up exceeding the authorities and responsibilities they had.

GRAHAM: it's ridiculous to believe that 18 people would go to Turkey to kill Mr. Khashoggi and nobody in the government know about it. That would be brazen abuse of authority.

He was clearly murdered in a consulate. Things like that don't happen in Saudi Arabia without people at the top knowing.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Dagen, your thoughts?

MCDOWELL: I will quote the Wall Street Journal editorial today on this very issue. Saudi Arabia needs to step up. We still don't know -- they haven't produced Khashoggi's body, provided more details of precisely how or when he decide.

The story doesn't add up. Of the 18 people arrested, five others sacked, several a part of Mohammed bin Salman the inner circle. It's unlikely they would have acted alone without at least, you know, feeling a tacit assent from the Crown Prince.

The Wall Street Journal editorial goes on to write, "The U.S. goal should be to preserve our alliance with Saudi Arabia while making clear that murdering journalists is unacceptable and that Mohammed bin Salman's erratic judgment and willful use of power are problems for the bilateral relationship."

We can't dictate what King Salman will do about who should run Saudi Arabia, but you can -- but Mohammed bin Salman also can't be allowed to conclude that America thinks this is no big deal.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And they've got to do something. The U.S. has to do something to push back in the face of this heinous situation.

Question is, does Mohammed bin Salman survive? He's got two other sons. There are a lot of people who want this guy out at this point. Lindsey Graham included.

So big question here, you know, I mean, the arms sales is going -- it's going to go through. The relationship is going to go through because there's one big black eye here that we're faced with and that is Iran, so.

MCDOWELL: But the muddled response from this administration and the uneven response that we've seen since this all began, we need to be on very firm footing about the message, like Lindsey Graham said that we send to King Salman about who we -- who should run the country.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HIGGINS: I want to disagree. I think that the administration has been taking a difficult situation. These are people that behaved really badly, like so many of the people we've had to deal with. And they've got this challenge of how do you negotiate making them pay for it, making them fess up to it, but not having them lose so much for --

MCDOWELL: But comparing it to Brett Kavanaugh was a misstep. I'm sorry.

BARTIROMO: Right. All right. We'll take a break.

When we come back, it's shifting gears for FiatChrysler. Details on the automaker's roughly $7 billion car parts deal. That's next.

And then a spooky box office debut, we've got it here on Halloween. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Battle at the border for sure, a migrant caravan moving toward the United States. It has grown now to roughly 5,000 people. Griff Jenkins is live in McAllen, Texas this morning with details there, right in the middle of it. Griff.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Maria. When the caravan gets to this border, if they do indeed come here, they're going to find an overwhelmed border already with illegal crossing.

And the Rio Grande Valley Sector where I'm standing McAllen is the busiest sector of the entire U.S. border, and it had more than 12,700 illegal crossing arrests in just the last three weeks.

Over the weekend, over 800 pounds of marijuana confiscated, and it is part of the problem here they're seeing is also family units, women and children coming, much like the caravan of migrants from Central American countries.

We spent time yesterday with the Sector Chief, a guy named Manuel Padilla, talking about the caravan that's coming and what he says is a need for more infrastructure. Take a listen.

MANUEL PADILLA, CHIEF, RIO GRANDE VALLEY SECTOR: If we had this combination of personnel, technology, infrastructure throughout my border, we would truly transform this area. It's a win-win situation for everybody.

This area right here, we do not see MS-13, we do not see criminal aliens coming into this area, because of the capability that we have through this combination of personnel, technology, infrastructure.

JENKINS: But he's only got well and about 55 of the nearly 300 parts of this sector and it's a busy one. The President, Maria, will be in Houston today and Houston is in this RGV area. I'm sure this topic will certainly come up. Maria.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: All right, Griff, thanks so much. Griff Jenkins is live McAllen, Texas.

What a scene. We are going to be watching that as that caravan moves closer to where Griff is actually standing.

Switching gears, a deadly train derailment in Taiwan. Cheryl Casone with that right now in headlines. Cheryl, good morning to you.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Maria, good morning.

An express train went off the tracks, killing at least 18 people. This happened in Eastern Taiwan. More than 150 others were injured in this disaster. Witnesses say all eight of the train's carriages went off the rails as it was traveling to the eastern city of Taitung.

This comes a year after another express train on the same line derailed. The cause of yesterday's accident, under investigation.

Well, Fiat Chrysler is unloading its car parts business. The company is selling the unit to Japan's Calsonic Kansei for just over $7 billion. Calsonic is owned by the U.S. private-equity firm, KKR. The deal is going to make the newly-combined company one of the world's biggest auto parts suppliers.

The FiatChrysler- - excuse me -- in the premarket up 4.6 percent, about.

And then finally, there is this. The horror movie, "Halloween," making a killing at the box office this weekend.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There's a reason we're supposed to be afraid of this night.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I've been preparing for this for a long time.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It is not safe to be on the streets tonight. Go home! Get out of here! Get inside! Michael?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: The film raking in $77.5 million, a record opening for the franchise. It also is the second-best October opening weekend of all time.

Holding on to second place, in its third weekend, "A Star Is Born," $19.3 million.

Rounding out top five, last week's big winner was "Venom," followed by " Goosebumps 2: Haunted Halloween," and, Maria, "First Man."

Jamie Curtis, she's still got it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, she does. Good movies this weekend. Thanks, Cheryl.

Coming up, a new way to calculate your FICO score, we will tell you why your cash may help. That's next.

And then Facebook goes shopping. The technology giant's reported plan to purchase a cybersecurity company, all right here after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Increasing access to credit, Fair Isaac, the company behind the FICO score, is rolling out a major change, UltraFICO Score will go beyond payment history.

According to the Journal this morning, it will factor in bank account activity, how consumers manage their cash and checking, savings and money market accounts. It launches next year.

Joining us right now to talk more about that is Mark Hamrick. He's Bankrate.com's Senior Economic Analyst.

And Mark, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks very much for joining us.

MARK HAMRICK, SENIOR ECONOMIC ANALYST, BANKRATE.COM: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: So, you think this is about younger people, this new FICO change. Tell us about it.

HAMRICK: Primarily, and we think about the fact that there's a large portion of the U.S. population which really isn't doing business with traditional financial service companies. Millennial have been smart. They're saving more money.

Our recent Bankrate survey found that about two-thirds of the American public was essentially limiting its spending and millennials are doing the best job of saving more money so that money is sitting in accounts not necessarily being spent.

At Bankrate, we say that the two biggest problems that have been identified by Americans is their failure to save for retirement and for emergencies. So, financial companies want to create new customers and help connect them to borrowing products. It's a logical step for them.

KELLY: Is there a way to opt out of this? It's -- the last thing I want with the Equifax hacking and everything going on about security, the last thing I want is somebody to pull up my UltraFICO to see how much money -- cash I have in a bank account, right?

BARTIROMO: And how you're managing all your money, and all your accounts.

KELLY: Yes, exactly. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Savings, checking.

HAMRICK: Yes. Well, to the question, I think you're right on. I think Americans are tired of having their personal information essentially taken from them.

And I think this is going to be something to watch in terms of regulation in the coming years, whether it's the information that Facebook and Google possess about us or our credit rating scores, because I think we have a sense that we have no control over this information.

MCDOWELL: What about the -- with the -- this new FICO score, is this a way to essentially offer people even more credit, if you will, that this is at a time when people are increasingly stretched, that you've seen auto lending particularly on the fringes of people with very low subprime auto lending really being pulled back on?

Is this a way to basically shine up people's credit scores and make them more palatable to the lender?

HAMRICK: That's a very good question. I think that is essentially the tension that could be created by this. In other words, giving loans to people who are not well qualified.

But that, I don't think, is the intention. Most financial service firms are not looking to create new losses.

Fed Chair Powell has said that he thinks that household balance sheets are in good shape. He's more concerned about the commercial side.

So, I think this is more about trying to identify good data about consumers and potential borrowers and connecting them to products that they might find useful.

HIGGINS: Meanwhile, you've got a new survey on how Americans are spending, and if they're cutting back on spending, right? Let's talk about that.

Sixty-six percent say that they're living -- they're limiting spending, thirty-six percent say that they are doing it to save money.

HAMRICK: Yes, and I think this is a good thing. As I said, you know, I don't think there are many Americans that go essentially into their last days saying, "You know what, I saved too much money." Ii think more Americans regret that they didn't do a better job of saving for retirement or emergencies.

HIGGINS: And I think that 36 percent was only of the 66 percent that were saving.

HAMRICK: Right.

HIGGINS: So it was only 24 percent overall that we're saving for longer term.

The other thing that was interesting in the study was, there has long been a contention that the big difference between how well you do in life is how long your time horizon is.

And when you looked at the study, the people who were making over $50,000 clearly had a longer time horizon that they were saving for, whereas the people who were under that were just sort of saving for the short-term needs and they weren't thinking beyond that.

How, if we're going to move away from the Keynesian mentality, that the more debt you have and the more spending you have, the better off we all are, to one where people are more prudent and thinking about their savings, how is borrowing going to help that happen?

HAMRICK: I think essentially, it's two different questions. I think the first question is, as long as you have a healthy economy, most Americans will be mindful of trying to achieve proper financial goals.

I do think in our society, we have a significant problem with lack of financial literacy and that's an education issue, which i don't hear a lot of people talking about.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's too bad. It really just starts at home. But we're certainly interested in that.

HAMRICK: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Mark, thanks so much for joining us.

HAMRICK: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you this morning. Mark Hamrick joining us from Bankrate.com.

Take a short break. When we come back, Jamie Dimon's big bet, why J.P. Morgan is building a campus in Silicon Valley. That's coming up.

Then fixing traffic gridlock, details on Elon Musk's high-speed transit tunnel. It's nearly finished. Will it offer free rides to the public? We will tell you about that. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Monday. It is Monday, October 22nd, your top stories right now, 6:32 a.m. on the East Coast. The major indices on Wall Street looking to open higher this morning ahead of a big week for earnings. This right here is the high of the morning, up 73 points on the Dow Industrials, a quarter of a percent. The NASDAQ is up two-thirds of a percent, that's 42 points higher. This after a mixed close on Friday, all ahead of a big week in earnings. This is one of the busiest weeks we're going to see.

Dow Industrials, on Friday, up 65 points at the close, a quarter of a percent higher.
