urn:contentItem:5XS8-5BH1-JCJY-G23B-00000-00Duty of care should protect elderly from online fraud, trust warns2019-12-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:29ZLexisNexisNEWSVersion:1Duty of care should protect elderly from online fraud, trust warnsBy Mike Wright, Social Media Correspondent

Duty of Care laws should also protect the elderly from online fraud, an influential trust which backed the Telegraph campaign has said.

The Carnegie Trust UK, which first drew up the legal model for regulating tech giants, has written to the Culture Secretary Baroness Nicky Morgan saying social media giants should "take responsibility" for the "explosion" of consumer fraud on their sites.

The call comes as the trust published a draft bill setting out its vision for enforcing a duty of care, including making Ofcom the new regulator and arming with 'dawn raid' powers to seize data from tech firms' offices.

The Government announced in its October Queen's Speech that it planned to publish a draft duty of care bill next year for pre-legislative scrutiny.

Yet, now the Conservatives have been returned with a strong majority, campaigners are watching to see what form the proposed bill will take in the new Queen's Speech tomorrow.

In the summer the Government published a white paper outlining how it planned to adopt duty of care to clamp down on online harms, following a yearlong campaign by the Daily Telegraph.

Its initial plans proposed creating a regulator to sanction tech giants if they failed to protect users from a wide range of harms, spanning terrorism to self-harm content.

Ministers said they are considering arming the regulator powers to levy fines running into the billions and even prosecute senior executives for serious breaches of their duty of care.

However, William Perrin, a trustee of Carnegie UK and former senior government advisor, said it was a "strategic error" not to include economic crime under the scope of duty of care.

Mr Perrin, who authored the first duty of care proposals with Lorna Woods, a professor of Law at Essex University, warned the issue would only become more salient with more older people now using social media.

He said: "The online services targeted by the White Paper have allowed an explosion of consumer harms including the sale of illicit medicines and dangerous toys as well as fraud and phishing by failing to take systemic action.

"A statutory duty of care should correct that, leading to the online space as a whole being a safe place in which businesses can operate and where consumers can have confidence that they will not be duped, scammed or misled.

"The scale of online fraud is astonishing, the most prevalent crime in England and Wales-as more older and vulnerable people come online it's only fair that regulation should protect them."

The Carnegie Trust's draft bill called for Ofcom to be made the regulator, arguing it has the experience and reputation to take the job on immediately.

It also warned that tech giants should only be allowed to challenge the regulator's decisions by judicial review, saying otherwise it could be tangled up in endless appeals from wealthy tech companies.

The duty of care model has received wide support ranging from children's charities to medical bodies such as the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health to the Church of England.

Following the publication of the Carnegie Trust's draft bill, Andy Burrows, NSPCC Head of child safety online policy, said: "For too long children have been at risk because big tech has argued that regulation is all but impossible, and they've been able to wash their hands of responsibility.

"This Bill shows how readily the Government can introduce a regulatory framework that can hold social networks to account and protect young people from abuse.

"It is vital that this new Government uses its power to urgently bring in a comprehensive Duty of Care regulator. Anything less than that would be insufficient and mean children and families, once again, are left to fend for themselves online."

urn:contentItem:5TRG-KFR1-DY2R-2021-00000-00Dynamism has declined across Western economies;America v Europe2018-11-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:29ZLexisNexisSPECIAL REPORTDynamism has declined across Western economiesAmerica v Europe

Has dynamism declined across the economy?

A BIG PROBLEM when attempting to tell if competition has weakened is that experts have stopped trying to answer the question. In the 1930s industrial economists viewed an uncompetitive industry as one in which a few firms had a large share of output and prices were high or quality low. Roll forward 80 years and competition regulators take refuge behind legal definitions of types of misconduct, such as price-fixing. If you ask them whether economy-wide dynamism has ebbed, they often insist that there are no analytical concepts or satisfactory data that allow that question to be answered, rather like medieval geographers who refuse to consider any evidence that the world is round unless it is written by members of the church in ecclesiastical Latin.

This learned helplessness reflects the tricky legacy of Robert Bork, an American scholar and judge who wrote "The Antitrust Paradox", a deeply influential book published in 1978. It correctly criticised blundering state intervention in the 1960s and 1970s, and pointed out that many big firms were efficient and many concentrated industries competitive. But Bork went further and argued there was no logical or empirical link between competition, profits and concentration. He also wrote that, when assessing takeovers, it did not matter if consumers were damaged by higher prices and less supply, as long as firms captured enough profits from efficiencies, so that in aggregate both were better off.

Bork's view of real firms has aged badly. He described the dynamism of Detroit's carmakers just before Japanese rivals exposed them as lazy and dangerous, and criticised AT&T's break-up, which became a triumph for consumers. Forty years later the economy has changed. A battery of new studies link concentration, profits and falling wages. Intellectual property, not physical objects, is where the action is, and tech has created networked business models. Since 1978 total profits (that is corporate free cashflows, or the money that firms make after paying for investment) have risen from 1.9% of GDP to 4.5%. It is sensible to ask why competition is not bringing earnings down to earth and what might be done to boost it. The alternatives are to do nothing about inequality, or to introduce draconian taxes or regulation to redistribute income.

A working definition is that an industry may be uncompetitive if there is a concentration of sales, employees, intellectual property or data, and if returns on capital are abnormally high for long periods of time, with little sign of churn or new entrants. If you want a sense of the global hotspots, follow the money. It points you towards America, tech and others sectors not exposed to trade.

Consider the global pool of abnormal profits, or all the earnings that companies make above a hurdle rate for their cost of capital. This exercise assumes an 8% cost of capital excluding goodwill and includes the world's top 5,000 non-financial firms. In order to capture intangible assets, these figures capitalise research and development (R&D) spending as an asset with a ten-year life.

Global "excess" profits are $660bn. Some 72% of that is made by American firms, split between tech, health care and sectors that are not exposed to trade, such as airlines and defence (see chart on next page). Other industries that are exposed to trade, including manufacturing, are less important. Europe accounts for 26% of the global pool of excess profits. Firms in the rest of the world capture 2%, with Chinese firms earning less than the hurdle rate.

At the national level, America and Europe can be examined using three tests: concentration, abnormal profits and openness. America scores badly (see charts on previous page).

Take concentration first. The numbers need to be treated with caution, but between 1997 and 2012 it rose in two-thirds of 900-odd census industries, with the weighted average market share of the top four firms growing from 26% to 32%. It continued to rise in 2012-14. A tenth of the economy is made up of industries where four firms have more than two-thirds of the market.

Profits are indeed abnormally high. A good measure is the free cashflow of corporate firms. This is 76% above its 50-year average, relative to GDP. There are pockets where profits and prices are high compared with other countries, including airlines, credit cards, telecoms, pharmaceutical distribution and credit checking. As anyone who has squeezed into an old economy-class seat or signed fiddly receipts at the check-out knows, these industries clearly lag behind the rest of the world. They also involve thickets of regulation.

As for openness, America is still the world's largest centre of innovation. It spends $450bn a year on R&D, 20% more than China and more than Europe, Japan and South Korea combined. But business churn is subdued: of the listed firms that made a very high return in 1997, 50% still did in 2017 (using a hurdle of 15% and excluding goodwill). Fewer new firms are being started. And America's opening up to the world has stalled, with trade to GDP falling steadily since 2011 and the output of foreign firms' subsidiaries in America stagnating.

America became a unitary market more than 100 years ago. Europe has not finished the job. The typical big European firm is smaller than its American rival, reflecting a punier domestic market, with more global spread, showing the need to escape that market. There are few big tech firms. The largest generators of excess profits include Unilever and Nestlé, drugs firms, and luxury-goods stars such as LVMH that dress Crazy Rich Asians, not locals.

Nonetheless, there are grounds for concern. Europe relies on American tech firms. Concentration is creeping up. A forthcoming study by Chiara Criscuolo and colleagues at the OECD, a club of mainly rich countries, shows that the average market share of the top four firms in each industry has risen by three percentage points since 2000, roughly half of the rise in North America. The free cashflow of non-financial firms as a share of GDP is 18% above its 20-year average. A very profitable listed firm in 1997 had a 46% chance of still being very profitable in 2017. Like America, Europe has suffered a decline in the number of new firms. It is weak on innovation, spending half as much on R&D in absolute terms as America. It scores better on trade, however, which has risen slightly relative to GDP since 2007.

Joseph Schumpeter, an Austrian economist, distinguished between two kinds of competition. There is the daily battle of wits between two apple sellers. And then there are breakthroughs by entrepreneurs that transform how industries operate. These leaps are unpredictable. In 1920 America's cutting-edge giants included the Central Leather Company and Baldwin Locomotive, but they were soon overtaken by a new generation of consumer-goods firms. Perhaps today giant profits will stimulate a new leap in competition amid the fears of decline.

There are some green shoots. Investment among listed firms in America is rising at an annual rate of 18% as the Trump boom motors along. A giddy mood should lead to more start-ups. Retail, media and health-care firms live in terror of digital competitors. Some investors think that artificial intelligence could create the next Schumpeterian revolution. Masayoshi Son, a Japanese investor, is betting $100bn on the Singularity, the moment when computers become more intelligent than humans.

Other signs point towards entrenched power. The high stockmarket values of profitable firms show that investors think their advantages will endure. Protectionism will reduce competition. There are few new entrants in, say, internet search or American airlines or telecoms. And powerful firms intend to stay powerful tomorrow. Of the total capital spending and R&D done by America's leading 500 companies, the top 20 firms account for 38%. Big firms are buying innovative start-ups. And data may bind customers to incumbent firms. At the heart of this is the modern world's greatest creation and biggest source of fear—the tech industry.

urn:contentItem:4FD0-VG00-01CT-N3NX-00000-00Early Intel on Earnings Season.2003-10-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:30ZLexisNexisEarly Intelon Earnings Season.

various company earnings

Byline: Cynthia L. Webb

'Tis the season for corporate earnings. Market experts and investors alike will be closely following financial results set to be released by several technology bellwethers this week. Chief among them is chipmaker Intel Corp.

A day before Intelis scheduled to release its third-quarter earnings, reports are out on efforts by Intelrivals to develop new laptop and server chips. "The announcements, at a technical conference in Silicon Valley, include a long-awaited technology makeover for Transmeta Corp., a struggling start-up that pioneered energy-efficient chips for laptops and prodded Intelto follow suit. Centaur Technology Inc., a U.S. unit of Taiwan's Via Technologies Inc., is discussing ultra-small chips for portables. At the other end of the computing spectrum, Sun Microsystems Inc. and Fujitsu Inc. plan to describe new high-end chips for servers to outflank an Intel chip dubbed Itanium 2 . Though aimed at different markets, the new chips illustrate common pressures that are reshaping competition in the semiconductor industry," The Wall Street Journal said, noting that the new chips, "to be discussed this week at the Microprocessor Forum , in San Jose, Calif., attack markets outside Intel's PC stronghold."

Intelis playing it cool, something it can afford to do when it holds a big share of the semiconductor marketplace. A spokesman told the Journal: "There is always competition in semiconductors, although the names of the companies can change. We continue to invest aggressively in the technology and manufacturing that help us stay ahead of the competition." Don't expect Intelto give up on its hold on the chip market, though it will be interesting to watch as new flames fuel Intel's creativity for new products. * The Wall Street Journal: IntelRivals Will Present New Chips (Subscription required)

While Intelfends off competitors at this week's trade show, there are already high hopes for Intel's numbers. Reuters said today that Intel"may rise ahead of its quarterly result on Tuesday. Deutsche Bank said on Friday it had raised its rating on the stock to 'buy' from 'hold.' The stock rose slightly in after-hours trade on Friday." In its round-up of this week's earnings releases, The Financial Times gives this rosy assessment of what's in store for the U.S. economy overall: "U.S. corporate profits have recovered strongly during this economic upswing and the outlook for company earnings is stronger, which should push the U.S. market higher before the end of the year," the article said. * Reuters via Forbes: Wall Street Seen Up In Thin Trade, IntelEyed * The Financial Times: Quarterly Earnings Reports Could Be Something To Savour * Intel's Q3 2003 Earnings Conf. Call -- 5:30 p.m. ET Tuesday

Motorola's Monday Surprise

Meanwhile, Wall Street will be watching Motorola closely today. The company is still reeling from the departure of its chief executive and lagging sales. Motorola jumped the gun on its earnings report. It was supposed to report its third-quarter earnings tomorrow, but it released its numbers this morning "because of a downgrade of its debt issued late on Friday by Moody's ," Reuters said. "Moody's cut Motorola's unsecured debt to one notch above junk, saying the No. 2 mobile phone maker faced tough challenges to boost sales and earnings amid intense competition. The company's subordinated debt was cut to junk by the rating agency. ... The credit rating agency said the downgrade 'considers the weakened outlook for most of Motorola's business segments' and expected strategic changes following the resignation of Chairman and Chief Executive Christopher Galvin , who will leave when a successor is named." * Reuters via Yahoo!: Motorola To Report After Debt Downgrade * Chicago Tribune: Moody's Lowers Motorola Debt Rating

As for the numbers, Motorola said it logged $6.8 billion in sales for its third quarter, up from $6.5 billion in the same year-ago period. Despite its negative debt rating, Motorola went on the offensive today to paint a positive picture of its financial performance. "Overall, the third quarter was a strong quarter for Motorola and one that signals some positive momentum in key aspects of our business. We again generated positive operating cash flow, for the 11th quarter in a row, reduced our net debt significantly, and increased sales 5% and orders 25% versus the prior year," Mike Zafirovski , president and chief operating officer, said in a statement. The company will say more today in a conference call after the close of the markets.

This Week's Earnings Checklist

Some of the big tech players set to release earning this week include: Apple , IBM and Siebel on Wednesday, and eBay and Sun MicroSystems on Thursday. Stay tuned.

A Qwest for Numbers

One dark spot in this week's numbers parade could be Qwest Communications . The telecom "could issue its long-awaited audited financial results for 2000 and 2001 as early as this week, people familiar with the matter said," The Wall Street Journal reported today. "Producing the audited financial results would be an important step toward resolving a Securities and Exchange Commission probe of Qwest's accounting but wouldn't in itself end the investigation, these people said. Qwest faces accounting investigations by both the SEC and the Justice Department, which also is conducting a grand-jury investigation into whether some Qwest executives illegally enriched themselves through deals with equipment suppliers." * The Wall Street Journal: Qwest Is Expected To Issue Its 2000, 2001 Results Soon (Subscription Required)

The Denver Post quoted one observer who said a settlement with the SEC may be a year or more away. "It would not surprise me if a final SEC settlement does not occur until after the 2004 (presidential) election," Janco Partners analyst Tom Friedberg said. "This has become far more of a political issue than a civil or criminal issue," he said. The Rocky Mountain News ran a report this weekend, highlighting more accusations of dubious behavior at the company. "A federal grand jury is reviewing evidence that former senior Qwest executives illegally took discounted stock from some vendors in exchange for directing business their way, a regulatory filing and sources indicate. Prosecutors are investigating whether Qwest bought equipment for business reasons or as a way for certain former executives to make quick profits once the suppliers went public. The deals occurred while Joe Nacchio was chief executive," the article said. * The Denver Post: Qwest's Re-Audit May Clear Books, Not Air * The Rocky Mountain News: Grand Jury Eyes Qwest

Telecom's Long Hangover

Speaking of telecom, ITU Telecom World opened this weekend in Geneva, though with less fireworks than the previous show in 1999. "Gone are the gigantic exhibition booths, some of which were built like pyramids, had their own elevators or were decorated daily with thousands of fresh roses. Sobriety is the new opulence at ITU Telecom World, the trade show organized every four years by the International Telecommunication Union , a UN agency," The Associated Press reported. "Telecom World 2003, which opened last Saturday and ends October 18, comes amid sustained economic gloom and financial headaches for firms that spent billions of dollars in European bidding wars for licenses to run next-generation mobile networks but have been slow to develop phones and services and claw back their investments. This year's event has drawn 908 exhibitors from 46 countries -- down from 1,200 firms at the 1999 session." * The Associated Press via Australian IT: Telecom Show Loses Its Gloss

The Financial Times also noted that a number of "big names are not exhibiting here this time, including Nokia , Siemens , IBM and Motorola . Others have disappeared altogether -- many carriers and network equipment makers went to the wall in a downturn precipitated by overcapacity as customers found their technology and services less than compelling. 'The avarice and greed of a few had tainted the sector and shaken the credibility of the people in the sector,' said Yoshio Utsumi , ITU secretary-general, at the show's opening." * The Financial Times: Leaders Own Up To Past Excesses

On a more positive note, IDG News Service said wireless technology will be all the rage at this year's show. "Not only will broadband wireless LAN technology be a focus of the show, it will also be a service available to visitors and exhibitors. Swisscom AG , the official supplier of telecom services to Telecom World, has installed 50 hotspots in the exhibition halls," the article said. * IDG News Service via InfoWorld: Telecom World 2003 Reflects A Battered Industry

The SCO Chronicles

The New York Times yesterday reported that Utah-based SCO Group , "the company that touched off a computer industry slugfest last spring by suing IBM over its use of Unix software, may find itself embarrassed by a similar claim against a company once related to SCO." According to the newspaper, "in an unpublicized case, one of SCO's former sister companies, Lineo , has agreed to quietly settle a third party's accusations that it engaged in the same kind of copyright infringement that is at the heart of SCO's claim against IBM, industry executives who have been briefed on the matter said. The case spotlights the behind-the-scenes role of Canopy , an investment firm formed by Ray Noorda , the founder of Novell and a personal computer industry pioneer. Canopy is SCO's largest shareholder and formerly controlled Lineo."

More on the little-known case: "Lineo was sued last year by MontaVista , a maker of software for specialized computers used in consumer and industrial applications that is based in Sunnyvale, Calif. The MontaVista executives said they had been notified that software their programmers had written and licensed under the GNU General Public License -- the license that governs companies that distribute Linux software -- had appeared, with copyrights removed, in Lineo's software. The license, which allows for the free distribution of software, still requires that the copyright notices be retained. Neither side would comment on the settlement, which was put under a court seal last month," The New York Times reported. * The New York Times: Copyright Lawsuit Is Turnabout For SCO (Registration required)

Microsoft's Mobile Moment

While the telecom conference in Geneva is a shadow of its past, a few major announcements are still expected. Microsoft and Vodafone are out of the box early, with an announcement today that they will jointly develop standards for Web services on mobile devices. "The initiative ... is intended to help software developers embed messaging, location, authentication and billing into applications used across mobile and PC platforms. The web services standard will be based on the industry standard Extensible Markup Language (XML)," The Financial Times reported. * The Financial Times: Microsoft and Vodafone In Web Standards Pact

No surprise here: Microsoft chairman Bill Gates talked about what he sees as the answer to telecom's future success during a speech at the conference. It's software, he said (makes sense coming from the world's largest software maker). "The thing is pretty simple. Software is the ingredient that helps continue to grow this industry," Gates said, according to Reuters. * Reuters via CNN/Money: Microsoft Makes Telecom Push

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5MMK-Y2R1-JCMN-Y19F-00000-00Early layoffs and closures in 2017 suggest a rocky year ahead for tech industry2017-01-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:29ZLexisNexisEarly layoffs and closures in 2017 suggest a rocky year ahead for tech industryPaul Sawers

Jan 14, 2017( VentureBeat: http://venturebeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) From Microsoft[1], IBM[2], and Twitter[3] through Zenefits[4], Intel[5], and Autodesk[6], the year 2016 ushered in some notable 'downsizing initiatives' across the technology industry. Throw into the mix heavily VC-funded startups selling for peanuts[7] and high-profile companies closing and selling assets to competitors[8], and 'wild' assertions that the big tech bubble is about to burst may not seem so 'wild' after all. Of course, dotcom-bubble-burst v.2.0 has been predicted pretty much since the big boom-and-bust at the turn of the century, which saw a swathe of vastly overvalued startups go belly-up, bringing an entire industry to its knees. But the doom-monger express chugs on, with many[9] analysts, VCs[10], and experts predicting rocky roads ahead[11].New year, new dawn?

Just two weeks into the New Year, and we're already seeing signs of what could be to come throughout 2017 and beyond. On January 12 alone, Twitter-like social network App.net announced it was shutting shop[12], while publicly traded music-streaming company Pandora revealed it was cutting 7 percent of its workforce[13], as rumors continue to circulate[14] that it will soon be acquired. And a day earlier, three-year-old drone startup Lily, with $15 million in funding, announced it was closing down[15] after failing to secure more funds. But App.net, Pandora, and Lily are just the latest in a series of closures and downsizing announcements from across the technology industry in the first two weeks of 2017. Less than a week into the new year, troubled[16] cloud storage startup Bitcasa, funded to the tune of $21 million, posted a goodbye message[17] to its website announcing that the company was no more. Official confirmation of what's coming next for the people and platform has yet to emerge, but we heard that it may have been acquired[18] by Intel. Despite recently revealing grand plans to monetize and become a publishing powerhouse[19], growing its traffic 140 percent to 60 monthly visitors[20], Medium laid off 50 employees[21], equating to a third of its workforce. It's also closing its New York and Washington, D.C. offices. Founder and CEO Ev Williams explained the company's pivot, blaming a broken advertising system:It simply doesn't serve people. In fact, it's not designed to. The vast majority of articles, videos, and other 'content' we all consume on a daily basis is paid for — directly or indirectly — by corporations who are funding it in order to advance their goals. And it is measured, amplified, and rewarded based on its ability to do that. Period. As a result, we get well, what we get. And it's getting worse.Elsewhere, Instagram-competing camera app company VSCO, with $70 million in VC money since its 2011 launch, revealed it was shuttering its New York office[22] and laying off all the staff, though it wasn't clear how many that amounted to. And San Francisco culinary startup Zesty, founded in 2012 and with $10 million in VC funding, reportedly terminated a $20,000 monthly lease on a Mission District hub late last year, and in the first week of 2017 laid off 13 members of staff[23]. Then there's blood-testing company Theranos, which laid off 43 percent of its staff[24] in October, amounting to 340 employees, and followed it up last week with another 41 percent cut[25], or 155 workers. But that debacle is less to do with the state of its industry than longstanding controversy around[26] the company's flawed working practices. Still, the Palo Alto company is a major figure in the Silicon Valley startup scene, having nabbed more than $600 million in equity financing since its inception in 2003. Incidentally, the very same day, fellow medical-testing company Counsyl, with more than $150 million in VC funding, revealed it was cutting 5 percent[27] of its workforce, equating to 24 people. With almost $80 million in VC funding to its name, San Francisco-based events app maker DoubleDutch revealed it was cutting around 70 positions[28], or 40 percent of its workforce. This came six months after it announced another[29] major staff cull. Closures and cuts in 2017 haven't been limited to U.S. companies. Earlier this week, London-based smartwatch maker Vector Watch announced it was closing down[30], with Fitbit snapping up the team and technology — a move that followed a month after the exact same thing[31] happened with Pebble. So what does this all mean for the year ahead? Doom and gloom, or hope?PredictionsA few weeks back, we asked a number of Silicon Valley VCs[32] what they expected to see in 2017 — including whether they anticipated a major bubble burst. 'You mean as it was predicted to in 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, and 2016?,' said M.G. Siegler, general partner at GV. 'No, I do not.' Jerry Chen, partner at Greylock Partners, was equally dismissive of such suggestions, saying:I don't think we will see a burst, but interest rate hikes combined with investors who start to weigh risk better will lead to a new normal. We experienced a significant market correction earlier this year, and the market will no longer tolerate growth at all costs and companies with high burn rates. But the market will reward companies who build competitive moats, using cash strategically, and execute an effective go-to-market business model.Late last year, veteran stock market strategist Ned Riley — who apparently foresaw the original dotcom bust of the early 21st century — said that he doesn't see a particularly bad year[33] ahead for the tech industry. 'I look at 2017 as an exciting year,' said Riley. 'Secular growth for this sector is particularly strong for the next three to five years.' He added that he doesn't foresee the same 'irrational exuberance' that he saw back in 1999 and 2000. It's clear there will be more upheaval across the technology industry this year, with Twitter still in trouble and SoundCloud urgently seeking a buyer[34]. But it's easy to look at a handful of examples and extrapolate any number of conclusions. The flurry of closures and layoffs we've seen so far in 2017 could easily be a result of companies delaying announcements until after the Christmas break. Or it could be indicative of a major trend we'll continue to see throughout the year. We'll have to wait and see. New York (CNN Business)The third quarter is over and Corporate America will soon be reporting just how awful their latest earnings were during the Covid-19 pandemic and recession. Strategist: 2021 earnings won't hit 2019 levels Earnings expected to plunge ... New York (CNN Business)The third quarter is over and Corporate America will soon be reporting just how...

New York (CNN Business)The third quarter is over and Corporate America will soon be reporting just how awful their latest earnings were during the Covid-19 pandemic and recession. Strategist: 2021 earnings won't hit 2019 levels Earnings expected to plunge ...

New York (CNN Business)The third quarter is over and Corporate America will soon be reporting just how awful their latest earnings were during the Covid-19 pandemic and recession. Strategist: 2021 earnings won't hit 2019 levels Earnings expected to plunge again but there are hopeful signs The bad news: Profits probably fell more than 20% compared to a year ago -- the second-worst drop since 2009. The good news: That's actually an improvement over the second quarter, when earnings suffered a more than 30% plunge. That was the worst since the Great Recession in 2009. But investors have gotten some hopeful signs lately: Wall Street analysts have boosted their earnings forecasts slightly for the third quarter, according to FactSet Research. Typically, Wall Street cuts its projections the closer companies get to reporting their numbers. On September 1, analysts were predicting a profit drop of 22.2% in the third quarter. Now, Wall Street is expecting a 21% drop. That's still a notable contraction, of course, but slightly less bad than the forecasts of just a month ago. The same thing has happened with sales estimates. Revenue for the third quarter is currently expected to decline 3.6% from a year ago versus forecasts of a 4.1% drop at the start of September. Have to admit it's getting better Sure, these may sound like subtle, incremental changes. And they are. But it's all part of a bigger trend. Analysts also expect continued improvement for earnings in the fourth quarter, with a projected profit drop of 12.7% and sales decrease of 1.2%. So Corporate America might be slowly turning the corner. Wall Street is forecasting a sizable rebound in earnings and revenue for the first half of 2021, too, with profits set to rise nearly 13% in the first quarter of next year and soar 44% in the second quarter. This earnings comeback is a big reason why stocks have skyrocketed from their March lows -- despite lingering concerns about coronavirus, worries about whether more stimulus is coming from Washington and, of course, questions about the upcoming presidential election (and how long it may take until a victor is declared). "The market is taking a lot of comfort from the fact that even though we are going to get a big decline in the third quarter, it was much worse three months ago" said Deepak Puri, chief investment officer of the Americas for Deutsche Bank Wealth Management. "We are moving in the right direction. That is the comforting factor. Economies and businesses are starting to reopen," he added. Puri also noted that it's encouraging to see that Big Tech companies like Apple, Amazon, Facebook, Microsoft and Google owner Alphabet, which make up a bulk of the S&P 500, are unlikely to suffer much of a hit to sales and profits. In addition, earnings are starting to improve for companies in cyclical sectors that were hardest hit during the early part of the spring slump, such as industrials, materials and energy. Still, there are many wild cards in play that could wreak havoc on earnings going forward. Could a Joe Biden win over President Trump lead to higher taxes and more regulations on banks? Possibly. A second wave of Covid-19 cases in America also could cripple earnings growth and the broader economy. That's why Puri concedes that investors have to take current forecasts with a grain of salt. "Estimates could go higher in 2021 due to expectations for a fast recovery. But the outlook is highly uncertain," he said. "Reality almost never syncs up with the early estimates from analysts."

urn:contentItem:5S6J-F391-DY0W-44D6-00000-00Earnings Blitz; French President Speaks to Congress; Iran Nuclear Deal; Return of the Trading Desk; Return of the Trading Desk; Big Money of Advertising; ECB Leaves Rates Unchanged; Dr. Ronny Jackson Withdraws as Nominee for Veteran Affairs; H.P. and New York Giants Teaming Up for Safety2018-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:30ZLexisNexisEarnings Blitz; French President Speaks to Congress; Iran Nuclear Deal; Return of the Trading Desk; Return of the Trading Desk; Big Money of Advertising; ECB Leaves Rates Unchanged; Dr. Ronny Jackson Withdraws as Nominee for Veteran Affairs; H.P. and New York Giants Teaming Up for SafetyLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back.

Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

I'm Maria Bartiromo -- happy Thursday to you. It is Thursday, April 26th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings in the driver's seat on Wall Street this morning -- that is what's dictating stocks. The Dow Industrials expected to be up about 50 points right out of the gate -- that's a quarter of a percent higher. The Nasdaq is up two-thirds of a percent right now -- that's 38 points higher.

Technology titans Amazon and Microsoft will be headlining the biggest earnings day of the season. Both are due out tonight after the bell. We will preview.

Plus Facebook shaking off the scandal -- shares soaring in the premarket, up better than 6 percent right now after the company beat expectations yesterday and posted strong growth in daily users and monthly users.

The Dow snapped a five-day losing streak yesterday, lifted by earnings from Boeing. The company reported better than expected earnings and revenue -- that helped it lift the Dow up about 60 points at the close, one-half of 1 percent. The S&P was up 5 but the Nasdaq was down about three-and-a-half.

In Europe this morning here's the scoop. We've got money moving into stocks as well but it is a fractional move. The FT100, the CAC 40 and the DAX index all higher by about between a quarter of a percent and half of a percent. Investors are waiting on the European Central Bank -- that decision on rates due out later this hour. No change in interest rates expected but we will be watching ECB president, Mario Draghi and what he says at his live news conference about stimulus going forward.

In Asia overnight, markets were mixed, take a look. The shanghai composite the worst performer in China, down one and a third percent.

A Wall Street retreat -- Deutsche Bank announcing plans to slash jobs in the United States amid falling profits. Details on the company's sprawling rebuilding efforts. Deutsche Bank shares are down two-thirds of a percent this morning.

And then child's play for Amazon -- how the technology company is teaching Alexa new parenting tricks.

Then, we will tell you the most cringe-worthy phrases used in the office. I think we know a couple of them.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman, along with Iraq and Afghanistan war veteran, Fox News contributor Pete Hegseth.

Great to see everybody today.

PETE HEGSETH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning to you.

HEGSETH: I wonder what those phrases are -- and how many of those have I said on TV.

BARTIROMO: "Try to think outside the box" --

HEGSETH: Ok.

BARTIROMO: That's one of them.

HEGSETH: Is that what it is?

BARTIROMO: It's one of them. We'll bring you all the phrases. But there are -- I know a phrase you hate.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Tell me.

BARTIROMO: "Let's unpack this".

MCDOWELL: Yes -- you read my mind. You read my mind.

BARTIROMO: You hate that phrase, I know it.

MCDOWELL: Yes. And that's kind of recent. And you know what I also hate? "Nothing burger". I hate it -- "nothing burger".

HEGSETH: I like --

MCDOWELL: Not just because Hillary Clinton used it. But it's just over- used.

HEGSETH: I don't like "with all due respect", because you know what's coming next -- little respect.

FREEMAN: I love that one Rickey Bobby says, but other than that, not so much.

Great earnings -- we'll see tomorrow if the economy and the fourth full quarter of the Trump presidency is really moving to a higher level.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We've got the GDP out this week. And of course, this is the single busiest day for earnings so far. And they have been largely better than expected. So we've got that profit story very much in place. We're going to talk about that this morning.

But first our top story right now. Emmanuel Macron addressed this Congress in a rousing speech yesterday. The French president made the case for staying in the Iran nuclear deal, saying that the U.S. and France can work together to forge a more comprehensive agreement that ultimately President Trump can come to accept.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EMMANUEL MACRON, FRENCH PRESIDENT: As for Iran, our objective is clear. Iran shall never possess any nuclear weapons -- not now, not in five years, not in 10 years, never.

This agreement may not address all concerns, but we should not abandon it without having something substantial and more substantial instead. That's my position.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: But later in the day, when speaking with reporters, Macron conceded that he believes the President will exit the Iran deal, quote, "for domestic reasons" and that of course, the deadline is next month.

Joining us now to talk about that is a member of the House Armed Services Committee, Democratic Congressman John Garamendi of California. Congressman -- it's good to see you. And thanks so much for joining us.

REP. JOHN GARAMENDI (D-CA), HOUSE ARMED SERVICES COMMITTEE: Good morning. Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: So your take on both of these statements from the French president. We know that the President -- President Trump has until May 12th to decide whether or not to renew that Iran deal. Your takeaway?

GARAMENDI: He's right and I hope he's wrong. He's absolutely right -- we have to stay in it. The JCPOA gives us the very best opportunity we have to prevent Iran from ever having a nuclear weapon. Certainly for the next decade, probably the next two decades, that agreement will prevent them from having a nuclear weapon.

The second point, will the President back away from it? I hope not. It would be a very, very serious mistake for a variety of reasons.

One, it would pull the United States away from key partners -- people that we absolutely have to work with if we're going to deal with Syria and Iran going into the future.

So let's hope that he's right on the first issue, that the JCPOA does prevent Iran from having a nuclear weapon; and secondly, that he's wrong about what the President might do. I think the President will recognize the extraordinary risks to the position of the United States as a leader in this world if he were to pull out.

BARTIROMO: What about changing certain areas? I mean isn't it true that there isn't enough opportunity to check whether or not they're being honest in terms of what they're doing with their nuclear capabilities? Are there fixes that the allies can put in place to change this deal so the President is more poised to stay in it?

GARAMENDI: Maria, you have a good point but you're slightly off the target. The view of what Iran is doing, that is, checking their nuclear programs -- that's in place.

The problem is all of the other things that Iran is doing. The Hezbollah, the support that they're giving to Syria, the support for terrorists from around the entire region -- all of those things were not included in the Iran nuclear deal. And those indeed are problems and the President is correct that that needs to be addressed and certainly President Macron is also quite correct, that we need to address those issues.

But that doesn't mean that we drop or exit the nuclear deal, which actually is working and the reviews by the international agencies as to what is happening in Iran are quite good, they are very incursive into Iran. So that's not he problem.

The problem is on the other things that Iran is doing beyond the nuclear.

HEGSETH: Congressman it's Pete Hegseth --

GARAMENDI: Sure.

HEGSETH: -- but this president gave Europe an opportunity to fill some of the holes and fixes in the deal which doesn't provide -- you may think it does, it doesn't provide oversight, it sunsets in 10 years. We gave them billions of dollars. They use it to fund terrorism.

Why do you trust that the Iranians won't after ten years, even if everything you're saying is true will actually give up their nuclear ambitions? Don't we have to be harder on them and have more visibility on enforcement? And how in the world does the existing deal do that?

GARAMENDI: If you get into the details of the agreement, the nuclear agreement, there are several stages along the way. There is a 10-year. There's also a 20-year and then Iran has signed on for the nonnuclear proliferation treaty which is forever more into the future. In other words, they have committed to not engage in nuclear weapons activities in the future.

HEGSETH: Do you trust them?

GARAMENDI: Of course, we don't trust them. That's why we have these verification programs in place which are very, very intrusive. And there are many mechanisms to determine if in fact they begin 10 years, 15 years, 20 years out in the future to restart their nuclear program. All of those remain in place.

I mean, it's really unfortunate what the previous administration is doing to this current administration in terms of leaks, in terms of trying hard to put all these barriers up in place. I actually think it's disgusting. I mean it's a -- but it feels like that's the only way this information could have gotten out. That's why I bring this up.

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: Well, it does show what a nasty town Washington can be. And also, the oddity of this story is this is not a nominee who came from somewhere else and these reports come out. This is someone that is -- the president has been working with closely, that the previous president worked with closely. You had a lot of people on the record from both parties saying this is a solid citizen, a great colleague, and so to now have off the record --

HEGSETH: Yes.

FREEMAN: -- allegations. Contrary to what the president and his predecessor have said they witnessed, I find it just beyond bizarre that this is what takes down a nominee. But that's the culture we live in now.

HEGSETH: No, go ahead.

MCDOWELL: No, there and -- you can speak to this. There are great entrenched interests.

HEGSETH: Yes.

MCDOWELL: In the way that the veterans administration operates, in terms of the way that money is doled out. So, if they think, these interests think that somebody's going to come in and change the status quo in terms of who gets the money and how much then --

HEGSETH: The veterans industrial complex is powerful. This guy was -- this president wants to shake it up. He would have as well. He never got his encore. He never got his confirmation hearing, said it was rumor and innuendo which is incredibly (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: Isn't that right.

FREEMAN: It's so awful. Why didn't Obama fire him? And why has President Trump had such a good working experience with him?

BARTIROMO: There's a cabal that wants to destroy Donald Trump.

HEGSETH: Correct.

BARTIROMO: And they want chaos around him. Your name has been floated out there.

HEGSETH: Yes, it has.

BARTIROMO: Would you want the job?

HEGSETH: If the president asked me to serve, great. But he hasn't at this point. So, we'll see.

BARTIROMO: We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The NFL draft kicks off tonight on FOX as new technology is helping players put their best foot forward. Cheryl Casone with all the details now, Cheryl.

CASONE: About the foot Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CASONE: There you go. NFL draft day is here, and as young athletes are preparing to enter the league, the NFL is looking at new ways to protect them. So, I went down to the New York Giants training facility to find out how a partnership with H.P. is helping them stay one step ahead of injury.

(BEGIN VIDEO TAPE)

CASONE: It's one of the biggest risks of playing in the NFL, injury. But it's not just concussions that take players out of the game. With nearly two-thirds of football injuries occurring in the lower limbs, the shoes athletes wear can determine a team's fate.

LEIGH WEISS, DIRECTOR OF REHABILITATION, NEW YORK GIANTS: Shoes are no longer seen as a piece of apparel. You know, they're a piece of protective equipment.

CASONE: Here at the New York Giants training facility, they are using this. Technology from H.P. with 3D scanning that creates digital profiles of players' feet.

JOE SKIBA, EQUIPMENT DIRECTOR, NEW YORK GIANTS: It's taking your foot, it's taking your length, it's taking your width.

CASONE: OK.

SKIBA: So, one of the most important things in today's game is players safety.

CASONE: Yes.

SKIBA: So, the first thing we want to do is we want to take a scan and make sure he's actually wearing the exact footwear he should be wearing to perform on the field.

CASONE: Quarterback Davis Webb showed me how it all works.

DAVIS WEBB, QUARTERBACK, NEW YORK GIANTS: Your right foot is a -- is a little bigger.

CASONE: OK, your right arch is bigger than your left. So, you do need custom shoes?

Turned out, he needed the equipment more than he thought.

SKIBA: So, we're going to put the recommendation right here.

WEBB: That's what I wear.

CASONE: Is this right?

SKIBA: Actually, this is not -- this is actually not a set-up. This is actually the cleat that Davis actually wears.

CASONE: H.P. technology puts million-dollar players together with high end shoes from Nike, Adidas and Under Armour, boosting performance and health.

RON COUGHLIN, PRESIDENT, H.P. PERSONAL SYSTEMS: There's probably no shoe that has more pressure than a 300-pound linemen on a cleat. And so, having the best fit for them and the support, they probably have the highest need in the world. So, it was a great place for us to test our technology.

CASONE: Every player from all 32 NFL teams are being scanned for this season.

JENNIFER LANGTON, VICE PRESIDENT, NFL HEALTH AND SAFETY: We can help bring innovation to the space, i.e. You know, the H.P. fit scanner, so they are in the best cleat available for themselves.

CASONE: And the Giants are hoping their partnership with H.P. will give them a shoe-in to the Super Bowl.

WEISS: So, at the end of the day, you know, the healthy football teams are usually more successful football teams and that's -- and that's what we started for.

CASONE: So, a healthy team is a winning team?

WEISS: Yes, that's what keeps me up at night.

CASONE: And since I'm a runner, I had to try it.

COUGHLIN: Wow, you have a big width difference. Do you know that?

CASONE: No.

COUGHLIN: Really?

CASONE: Yes, look at that.

UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN: But you did come up with two cleats.

COUGHLIN: In case, you are going to go out there.

(END VIDEO TAPE)

CASONE: All right, so yes, I learned a few things about my own feet as well, Maria, when I went out and shot the story. But --

BARTIROMO: So, you need custom made shoes?

CASONE: I need custom-made shoes. I have a low arch on my left and a right -- a high arch on my right. I had no clue. I have whacky feet. But so are they. So, I feel better about it. Anyway, the draft is tonight, we're really excited.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Cheryl. Don't forget to catch the live coverage of the NFL draft tonight, 8:00 p.m. Eastern time. Showtime. Cheryl, thank you. Still ahead, Kanye West causes a stir again after the rapper tweets his praise of president Trump and has a new not so kind words of former president Obama, next hour, right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it its Thursday, April 26th. Your top stories right now.

END

urn:contentItem:5S6J-F391-DY0W-44DC-00000-00Earnings Blitz; French President Speaks to Congress; Iran Nuclear Deal; Return of the Trading Desk; Return of the Trading Desk; Big Money of Advertising; ECB Leaves Rates Unchanged; Dr. Ronny Jackson Withdraws as Nominee for Veteran Affairs; H.P. and New York Giants Teaming Up for Safety2018-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:30ZLexisNexisEarnings Blitz; French President Speaks to Congress; Iran Nuclear Deal; Return of the Trading Desk; Return of the Trading Desk; Big Money of Advertising; ECB Leaves Rates Unchanged; Dr. Ronny Jackson Withdraws as Nominee for Veteran Affairs; H.P. and New York Giants Teaming Up for SafetyLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back.

Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

I'm Maria Bartiromo -- happy Thursday to you. It is Thursday, April 26th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings in the driver's seat on Wall Street this morning -- that is what's dictating stocks. The Dow Industrials expected to be up about 50 points right out of the gate -- that's a quarter of a percent higher. The Nasdaq is up two-thirds of a percent right now -- that's 38 points higher.

Technology titans Amazon and Microsoft will be headlining the biggest earnings day of the season. Both are due out tonight after the bell. We will preview.

Plus Facebook shaking off the scandal -- shares soaring in the premarket, up better than 6 percent right now after the company beat expectations yesterday and posted strong growth in daily users and monthly users.

The Dow snapped a five-day losing streak yesterday, lifted by earnings from Boeing. The company reported better than expected earnings and revenue -- that helped it lift the Dow up about 60 points at the close, one-half of 1 percent. The S&P was up 5 but the Nasdaq was down about three-and-a-half.

In Europe this morning here's the scoop. We've got money moving into stocks as well but it is a fractional move. The FT100, the CAC 40 and the DAX index all higher by about between a quarter of a percent and half of a percent. Investors are waiting on the European Central Bank -- that decision on rates due out later this hour. No change in interest rates expected but we will be watching ECB president, Mario Draghi and what he says at his live news conference about stimulus going forward.

In Asia overnight, markets were mixed, take a look. The shanghai composite the worst performer in China, down one and a third percent.

A Wall Street retreat -- Deutsche Bank announcing plans to slash jobs in the United States amid falling profits. Details on the company's sprawling rebuilding efforts. Deutsche Bank shares are down two-thirds of a percent this morning.

And then child's play for Amazon -- how the technology company is teaching Alexa new parenting tricks.

Then, we will tell you the most cringe-worthy phrases used in the office. I think we know a couple of them.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman, along with Iraq and Afghanistan war veteran, Fox News contributor Pete Hegseth.

Great to see everybody today.

PETE HEGSETH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning to you.

HEGSETH: I wonder what those phrases are -- and how many of those have I said on TV.

BARTIROMO: "Try to think outside the box" --

HEGSETH: Ok.

BARTIROMO: That's one of them.

HEGSETH: Is that what it is?

BARTIROMO: It's one of them. We'll bring you all the phrases. But there are -- I know a phrase you hate.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Tell me.

BARTIROMO: "Let's unpack this".

MCDOWELL: Yes -- you read my mind. You read my mind.

BARTIROMO: You hate that phrase, I know it.

MCDOWELL: Yes. And that's kind of recent. And you know what I also hate? "Nothing burger". I hate it -- "nothing burger".

HEGSETH: I like --

MCDOWELL: Not just because Hillary Clinton used it. But it's just over- used.

HEGSETH: I don't like "with all due respect", because you know what's coming next -- little respect.

FREEMAN: I love that one Rickey Bobby says, but other than that, not so much.

Great earnings -- we'll see tomorrow if the economy and the fourth full quarter of the Trump presidency is really moving to a higher level.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We've got the GDP out this week. And of course, this is the single busiest day for earnings so far. And they have been largely better than expected. So we've got that profit story very much in place. We're going to talk about that this morning.

But first our top story right now. Emmanuel Macron addressed this Congress in a rousing speech yesterday. The French president made the case for staying in the Iran nuclear deal, saying that the U.S. and France can work together to forge a more comprehensive agreement that ultimately President Trump can come to accept.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EMMANUEL MACRON, FRENCH PRESIDENT: As for Iran, our objective is clear. Iran shall never possess any nuclear weapons -- not now, not in five years, not in 10 years, never.

This agreement may not address all concerns, but we should not abandon it without having something substantial and more substantial instead. That's my position.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: But later in the day, when speaking with reporters, Macron conceded that he believes the President will exit the Iran deal, quote, "for domestic reasons" and that of course, the deadline is next month.

Joining us now to talk about that is a member of the House Armed Services Committee, Democratic Congressman John Garamendi of California. Congressman -- it's good to see you. And thanks so much for joining us.

REP. JOHN GARAMENDI (D-CA), HOUSE ARMED SERVICES COMMITTEE: Good morning. Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: So your take on both of these statements from the French president. We know that the President -- President Trump has until May 12th to decide whether or not to renew that Iran deal. Your takeaway?

GARAMENDI: He's right and I hope he's wrong. He's absolutely right -- we have to stay in it. The JCPOA gives us the very best opportunity we have to prevent Iran from ever having a nuclear weapon. Certainly for the next decade, probably the next two decades, that agreement will prevent them from having a nuclear weapon.

The second point, will the President back away from it? I hope not. It would be a very, very serious mistake for a variety of reasons.

One, it would pull the United States away from key partners -- people that we absolutely have to work with if we're going to deal with Syria and Iran going into the future.

So let's hope that he's right on the first issue, that the JCPOA does prevent Iran from having a nuclear weapon; and secondly, that he's wrong about what the President might do. I think the President will recognize the extraordinary risks to the position of the United States as a leader in this world if he were to pull out.

BARTIROMO: What about changing certain areas? I mean isn't it true that there isn't enough opportunity to check whether or not they're being honest in terms of what they're doing with their nuclear capabilities? Are there fixes that the allies can put in place to change this deal so the President is more poised to stay in it?

GARAMENDI: Maria, you have a good point but you're slightly off the target. The view of what Iran is doing, that is, checking their nuclear programs -- that's in place.

The problem is all of the other things that Iran is doing. The Hezbollah, the support that they're giving to Syria, the support for terrorists from around the entire region -- all of those things were not included in the Iran nuclear deal. And those indeed are problems and the President is correct that that needs to be addressed and certainly President Macron is also quite correct, that we need to address those issues.

But that doesn't mean that we drop or exit the nuclear deal, which actually is working and the reviews by the international agencies as to what is happening in Iran are quite good, they are very incursive into Iran. So that's not he problem.

The problem is on the other things that Iran is doing beyond the nuclear.

HEGSETH: Congressman it's Pete Hegseth --

GARAMENDI: Sure.

HEGSETH: -- but this president gave Europe an opportunity to fill some of the holes and fixes in the deal which doesn't provide -- you may think it does, it doesn't provide oversight, it sunsets in 10 years. We gave them billions of dollars. They use it to fund terrorism.

Why do you trust that the Iranians won't after ten years, even if everything you're saying is true will actually give up their nuclear ambitions? Don't we have to be harder on them and have more visibility on enforcement? And how in the world does the existing deal do that?

GARAMENDI: If you get into the details of the agreement, the nuclear agreement, there are several stages along the way. There is a 10-year. There's also a 20-year and then Iran has signed on for the nonnuclear proliferation treaty which is forever more into the future. In other words, they have committed to not engage in nuclear weapons activities in the future.

HEGSETH: Do you trust them?

GARAMENDI: Of course, we don't trust them. That's why we have these verification programs in place which are very, very intrusive. And there are many mechanisms to determine if in fact they begin 10 years, 15 years, 20 years out in the future to restart their nuclear program. All of those remain in place.

But there really is a very major concern, correctly stated by the President, as well as by President Macron and others, that the other activities that Iran has engaged in, particularly what we're seeing in Syria right now, they are one of the major supporters of the Syrian -- of the Assad government in Syria and they have perhaps thousands of troops in Syria supporting the Syrian government and also working with Hezbollah, threatening Israel and certainly having a major impact on Lebanon.

So all those things are concerns; they need to be dealt with. France --

BARTIROMO: Well, how are they going to be dealt? How are they going to be dealt with if the President renews it and doesn't pull out?

I mean you're saying two things. You said it's working. You said the Iran deal is working. And then you said all of this stuff that they're doing -- dealing with Syria, supporting Hezbollah, threatening Israel -- so it's not working.

GARAMENDI: No. Maria -- that is not correct. The deal did not deal with those -- those issues that you just stated. It dealt with the nuclear thing. It did not deal with the other issues.

BARTIROMO: I see.

GARAMENDI: And there -- and some -- many people believe that the deal was not whole, it didn't cover everything and that's absolutely correct, it didn't cover everything. And that's absolutely correct. It did not cover everything. It dealt with what was and remains today the most important and that is that -- and President Macron said this very clearly -- Iran will never have a nuclear weapon. That's what the deal dealt with.

It didn't deal with the other activities, malicious and bad as they are. We should be dealing with those and if we work together and we don't dump the nuclear deal, which would create enormous division within the coalition that actually brought about the nuclear deal, if we don't dump that, then we will have a strong coalition to deal with these other issues rather than --

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: Congressman -- James Freeman here with the "Journal". I'm wondering, therefore, if you then support bringing back the sanctions that were relieved by the deal as punishment for everything you just described in terms of funding terrorism?

GARAMENDI: Well, there are other sanctions that are still in place, additional sanctions may be necessary and they are always available to us going into the future. That's quite possible.

FREEMAN: Does that mean you're not supporting them now?

GARAMENDI: We need to work together with other countries. Right now, all of the focus is on the President threatening to dump the nuclear deal, which would set all of this thing back and not allow us to move forward on anything. So that's the first problem.

FREEMAN: I know but you just detailed all of their offenses in the region. Doesn't that justify bringing sanctions?

GARAMENDI: It could, and we need to be working with our allies on this issue. Some of those sanctions are a direct problem to our allies and that -- and to the United States.

For example, there's a major deal that has been cut, Iran wants to purchase dozens if not hundreds of new airliners. That's a big deal for the airbus and quite possibly for Boeing. And so as you look at those sanctions, you want to be careful to only use sanctions that are detrimental to Iran, not detrimental to the interest of the coalition partners.

So what I'm saying is that sanctions are there. They can be used. But just to go back and to put all of those back in place may create additional problems and not achieve the goal.

So look at this thing carefully. Use sanctions that are very targeted, that do put the appropriate pressure on Iran so that they will back away from many of the things.

But let me also put one more issue on the table and that is when the President said three weeks ago that we had completed the work on ISIS, he wanted to pull out the troops out of Syria, and that he wanted to leave Syria to others.

Well, it turns out that the others are Russia, Iran, Turkey, and the Gulf States. That creates an enormous vacuum of power that will be filled by Iran and that's not where we want to go. So you have to look at this thing in its total complexity.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GARAMENDI: And if we do, I think we can make progress, keep the nuclear deal in place. It is working and it will work for many years into the future.

And secondly, make sure that we do apply the appropriate pressure. Keep in mind, Syria in this entire equation.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Dagen -- did you want to say something?

MCDOWELL: No. I just -- Congressman, you said look at the complete deal and all that's going on in its entirety. The problem that a lot of Americans have with that nuclear deal with Iran in the first place is we handed $1.7 billion in pallets of cash to Iran. Where is that money going as a state sponsor of terrorism?

It's going to fund terrorist attacks. It's going to fund Hezbollah. So you can't really separate those two. We gave them the money before there was any evidence that they were really pulling back on the nuclear program. We actually -- we flew it to Iran in the secret of night. And the only reason we even know about it is because of the reporting of the "Wall Street Journal".

GARAMENDI: Well, that coffee has been spilled. That coffee's no longer in the cup. So what do we do going forward? The nuclear deal is in place and it is working. That's a good thing. That's a very, very important thing. Now, let's --

BARTIROMO: You keep saying it's working -- Congressman.

GARAMENDI: It is.

BARTIROMO: But all of these things that are not working are so obvious. And then a moment ago you said we have to be careful because Iran's going to buy all these jets, possibly from Boeing and from others and we have to be careful about that.

What's our goal? Is our goal to stop the nuclear capability or get business for Boeing and the jet makers?

WEISS: Yes, that's what keeps me up at night.

CASONE: And since I'm a runner, I had to try it.

COUGHLIN: Wow, you have a big width difference. Do you know that?

CASONE: No.

COUGHLIN: Really?

CASONE: Yes, look at that.

UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN: But you did come up with two cleats.

COUGHLIN: In case, you are going to go out there.

(END VIDEO TAPE)

CASONE: All right, so yes, I learned a few things about my own feet as well, Maria, when I went out and shot the story. But --

BARTIROMO: So, you need custom made shoes?

CASONE: I need custom-made shoes. I have a low arch on my left and a right -- a high arch on my right. I had no clue. I have whacky feet. But so are they. So, I feel better about it. Anyway, the draft is tonight, we're really excited.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Cheryl. Don't forget to catch the live coverage of the NFL draft tonight, 8:00 p.m. Eastern time. Showtime. Cheryl, thank you. Still ahead, Kanye West causes a stir again after the rapper tweets his praise of president Trump and has a new not so kind words of former president Obama, next hour, right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it its Thursday, April 26th. Your top stories right now.

END
