urn:contentItem:5S6J-F391-DY0W-44DW-00000-00Earnings Blitz; French President Speaks to Congress; Iran Nuclear Deal; Return of the Trading Desk; Return of the Trading Desk; Big Money of Advertising; ECB Leaves Rates Unchanged; Dr. Ronny Jackson Withdraws as Nominee for Veteran Affairs; H.P. and New York Giants Teaming Up for Safety2018-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:30ZLexisNexisEarnings Blitz; French President Speaks to Congress; Iran Nuclear Deal; Return of the Trading Desk; Return of the Trading Desk; Big Money of Advertising; ECB Leaves Rates Unchanged; Dr. Ronny Jackson Withdraws as Nominee for Veteran Affairs; H.P. and New York Giants Teaming Up for SafetyLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back.

Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

I'm Maria Bartiromo -- happy Thursday to you. It is Thursday, April 26th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings in the driver's seat on Wall Street this morning -- that is what's dictating stocks. The Dow Industrials expected to be up about 50 points right out of the gate -- that's a quarter of a percent higher. The Nasdaq is up two-thirds of a percent right now -- that's 38 points higher.

Technology titans Amazon and Microsoft will be headlining the biggest earnings day of the season. Both are due out tonight after the bell. We will preview.

Plus Facebook shaking off the scandal -- shares soaring in the premarket, up better than 6 percent right now after the company beat expectations yesterday and posted strong growth in daily users and monthly users.

The Dow snapped a five-day losing streak yesterday, lifted by earnings from Boeing. The company reported better than expected earnings and revenue -- that helped it lift the Dow up about 60 points at the close, one-half of 1 percent. The S&P was up 5 but the Nasdaq was down about three-and-a-half.

In Europe this morning here's the scoop. We've got money moving into stocks as well but it is a fractional move. The FT100, the CAC 40 and the DAX index all higher by about between a quarter of a percent and half of a percent. Investors are waiting on the European Central Bank -- that decision on rates due out later this hour. No change in interest rates expected but we will be watching ECB president, Mario Draghi and what he says at his live news conference about stimulus going forward.

In Asia overnight, markets were mixed, take a look. The shanghai composite the worst performer in China, down one and a third percent.

A Wall Street retreat -- Deutsche Bank announcing plans to slash jobs in the United States amid falling profits. Details on the company's sprawling rebuilding efforts. Deutsche Bank shares are down two-thirds of a percent this morning.

And then child's play for Amazon -- how the technology company is teaching Alexa new parenting tricks.

Then, we will tell you the most cringe-worthy phrases used in the office. I think we know a couple of them.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman, along with Iraq and Afghanistan war veteran, Fox News contributor Pete Hegseth.

Great to see everybody today.

PETE HEGSETH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning to you.

HEGSETH: I wonder what those phrases are -- and how many of those have I said on TV.

BARTIROMO: "Try to think outside the box" --

HEGSETH: Ok.

BARTIROMO: That's one of them.

HEGSETH: Is that what it is?

BARTIROMO: It's one of them. We'll bring you all the phrases. But there are -- I know a phrase you hate.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Tell me.

BARTIROMO: "Let's unpack this".

MCDOWELL: Yes -- you read my mind. You read my mind.

BARTIROMO: You hate that phrase, I know it.

MCDOWELL: Yes. And that's kind of recent. And you know what I also hate? "Nothing burger". I hate it -- "nothing burger".

HEGSETH: I like --

MCDOWELL: Not just because Hillary Clinton used it. But it's just over- used.

HEGSETH: I don't like "with all due respect", because you know what's coming next -- little respect.

FREEMAN: I love that one Rickey Bobby says, but other than that, not so much.

Great earnings -- we'll see tomorrow if the economy and the fourth full quarter of the Trump presidency is really moving to a higher level.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We've got the GDP out this week. And of course, this is the single busiest day for earnings so far. And they have been largely better than expected. So we've got that profit story very much in place. We're going to talk about that this morning.

But first our top story right now. Emmanuel Macron addressed this Congress in a rousing speech yesterday. The French president made the case for staying in the Iran nuclear deal, saying that the U.S. and France can work together to forge a more comprehensive agreement that ultimately President Trump can come to accept.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EMMANUEL MACRON, FRENCH PRESIDENT: As for Iran, our objective is clear. Iran shall never possess any nuclear weapons -- not now, not in five years, not in 10 years, never.

This agreement may not address all concerns, but we should not abandon it without having something substantial and more substantial instead. That's my position.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: But later in the day, when speaking with reporters, Macron conceded that he believes the President will exit the Iran deal, quote, "for domestic reasons" and that of course, the deadline is next month.

Joining us now to talk about that is a member of the House Armed Services Committee, Democratic Congressman John Garamendi of California. Congressman -- it's good to see you. And thanks so much for joining us.

REP. JOHN GARAMENDI (D-CA), HOUSE ARMED SERVICES COMMITTEE: Good morning. Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: So your take on both of these statements from the French president. We know that the President -- President Trump has until May 12th to decide whether or not to renew that Iran deal. Your takeaway?

GARAMENDI: He's right and I hope he's wrong. He's absolutely right -- we have to stay in it. The JCPOA gives us the very best opportunity we have to prevent Iran from ever having a nuclear weapon. Certainly for the next decade, probably the next two decades, that agreement will prevent them from having a nuclear weapon.

The second point, will the President back away from it? I hope not. It would be a very, very serious mistake for a variety of reasons.

One, it would pull the United States away from key partners -- people that we absolutely have to work with if we're going to deal with Syria and Iran going into the future.

So let's hope that he's right on the first issue, that the JCPOA does prevent Iran from having a nuclear weapon; and secondly, that he's wrong about what the President might do. I think the President will recognize the extraordinary risks to the position of the United States as a leader in this world if he were to pull out.

BARTIROMO: What about changing certain areas? I mean isn't it true that there isn't enough opportunity to check whether or not they're being honest in terms of what they're doing with their nuclear capabilities? Are there fixes that the allies can put in place to change this deal so the President is more poised to stay in it?

GARAMENDI: Maria, you have a good point but you're slightly off the target. The view of what Iran is doing, that is, checking their nuclear programs -- that's in place.

The problem is all of the other things that Iran is doing. The Hezbollah, the support that they're giving to Syria, the support for terrorists from around the entire region -- all of those things were not included in the Iran nuclear deal. And those indeed are problems and the President is correct that that needs to be addressed and certainly President Macron is also quite correct, that we need to address those issues.

But that doesn't mean that we drop or exit the nuclear deal, which actually is working and the reviews by the international agencies as to what is happening in Iran are quite good, they are very incursive into Iran. So that's not he problem.

The problem is on the other things that Iran is doing beyond the nuclear.

HEGSETH: Congressman it's Pete Hegseth --

GARAMENDI: Sure.

HEGSETH: -- but this president gave Europe an opportunity to fill some of the holes and fixes in the deal which doesn't provide -- you may think it does, it doesn't provide oversight, it sunsets in 10 years. We gave them billions of dollars. They use it to fund terrorism.

Why do you trust that the Iranians won't after ten years, even if everything you're saying is true will actually give up their nuclear ambitions? Don't we have to be harder on them and have more visibility on enforcement? And how in the world does the existing deal do that?

GARAMENDI: If you get into the details of the agreement, the nuclear agreement, there are several stages along the way. There is a 10-year. There's also a 20-year and then Iran has signed on for the nonnuclear proliferation treaty which is forever more into the future. In other words, they have committed to not engage in nuclear weapons activities in the future.

HEGSETH: Do you trust them?

GARAMENDI: Of course, we don't trust them. That's why we have these verification programs in place which are very, very intrusive. And there are many mechanisms to determine if in fact they begin 10 years, 15 years, 20 years out in the future to restart their nuclear program. All of those remain in place.

But there really is a very major concern, correctly stated by the President, as well as by President Macron and others, that the other activities that Iran has engaged in, particularly what we're seeing in Syria right now, they are one of the major supporters of the Syrian -- of the Assad government in Syria and they have perhaps thousands of troops in Syria supporting the Syrian government and also working with Hezbollah, threatening Israel and certainly having a major impact on Lebanon.

So all those things are concerns; they need to be dealt with. France --

BARTIROMO: Well, how are they going to be dealt? How are they going to be dealt with if the President renews it and doesn't pull out?

I mean you're saying two things. You said it's working. You said the Iran deal is working. And then you said all of this stuff that they're doing -- dealing with Syria, supporting Hezbollah, threatening Israel -- so it's not working.

GARAMENDI: No. Maria -- that is not correct. The deal did not deal with those -- those issues that you just stated. It dealt with the nuclear thing. It did not deal with the other issues.

BARTIROMO: I see.

GARAMENDI: And there -- and some -- many people believe that the deal was not whole, it didn't cover everything and that's absolutely correct, it didn't cover everything. And that's absolutely correct. It did not cover everything. It dealt with what was and remains today the most important and that is that -- and President Macron said this very clearly -- Iran will never have a nuclear weapon. That's what the deal dealt with.

It didn't deal with the other activities, malicious and bad as they are. We should be dealing with those and if we work together and we don't dump the nuclear deal, which would create enormous division within the coalition that actually brought about the nuclear deal, if we don't dump that, then we will have a strong coalition to deal with these other issues rather than --

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: Congressman -- James Freeman here with the "Journal". I'm wondering, therefore, if you then support bringing back the sanctions that were relieved by the deal as punishment for everything you just described in terms of funding terrorism?

GARAMENDI: Well, there are other sanctions that are still in place, additional sanctions may be necessary and they are always available to us going into the future. That's quite possible.

FREEMAN: Does that mean you're not supporting them now?

GARAMENDI: We need to work together with other countries. Right now, all of the focus is on the President threatening to dump the nuclear deal, which would set all of this thing back and not allow us to move forward on anything. So that's the first problem.

FREEMAN: I know but you just detailed all of their offenses in the region. Doesn't that justify bringing sanctions?

GARAMENDI: It could, and we need to be working with our allies on this issue. Some of those sanctions are a direct problem to our allies and that -- and to the United States.

For example, there's a major deal that has been cut, Iran wants to purchase dozens if not hundreds of new airliners. That's a big deal for the airbus and quite possibly for Boeing. And so as you look at those sanctions, you want to be careful to only use sanctions that are detrimental to Iran, not detrimental to the interest of the coalition partners.

So what I'm saying is that sanctions are there. They can be used. But just to go back and to put all of those back in place may create additional problems and not achieve the goal.

So look at this thing carefully. Use sanctions that are very targeted, that do put the appropriate pressure on Iran so that they will back away from many of the things.

But let me also put one more issue on the table and that is when the President said three weeks ago that we had completed the work on ISIS, he wanted to pull out the troops out of Syria, and that he wanted to leave Syria to others.

Well, it turns out that the others are Russia, Iran, Turkey, and the Gulf States. That creates an enormous vacuum of power that will be filled by Iran and that's not where we want to go. So you have to look at this thing in its total complexity.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GARAMENDI: And if we do, I think we can make progress, keep the nuclear deal in place. It is working and it will work for many years into the future.

And secondly, make sure that we do apply the appropriate pressure. Keep in mind, Syria in this entire equation.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Dagen -- did you want to say something?

MCDOWELL: No. I just -- Congressman, you said look at the complete deal and all that's going on in its entirety. The problem that a lot of Americans have with that nuclear deal with Iran in the first place is we handed $1.7 billion in pallets of cash to Iran. Where is that money going as a state sponsor of terrorism?

It's going to fund terrorist attacks. It's going to fund Hezbollah. So you can't really separate those two. We gave them the money before there was any evidence that they were really pulling back on the nuclear program. We actually -- we flew it to Iran in the secret of night. And the only reason we even know about it is because of the reporting of the "Wall Street Journal".

GARAMENDI: Well, that coffee has been spilled. That coffee's no longer in the cup. So what do we do going forward? The nuclear deal is in place and it is working. That's a good thing. That's a very, very important thing. Now, let's --

BARTIROMO: You keep saying it's working -- Congressman.

GARAMENDI: It is.

BARTIROMO: But all of these things that are not working are so obvious. And then a moment ago you said we have to be careful because Iran's going to buy all these jets, possibly from Boeing and from others and we have to be careful about that.

What's our goal? Is our goal to stop the nuclear capability or get business for Boeing and the jet makers?

GARAMENDI: Well, you're quite correct, our goal was to stop the nuclear capability. And that is happening.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: How is that happening if they're supporting Syria? They're supporting Hezbollah. They're threatening Israel. And they're using the $1.7 billion that we sent over there to do just that.

GARAMENDI: Calm down for a second and carefully take a listen to what you just said. The nuclear deal -- that was what we dealt with. The JCPOA was about Iran building a nuclear weapon and at that time --

HEGSETH: They're still building missiles -- Congressman. They're still testing and building missiles, delivery systems for nuclear capabilities.

(CROSSTALK)

GARAMENDI: Hang on a second. I want you to be very, very careful about what we're talking about here. Iran was on the cusp of actually building a nuclear weapon. They could have built one within one year, maybe less than one year. That's no longer the case. They do not now have the materials or the systems to build a nuclear weapon.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GARAMENDI: That's what the JCPOA was about. These other issues were not part of that deal. The important --

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, that was not smart. That was not smart.

GARAMENDI: -- the important -- excuse me.

(CROSSTALK)

GARAMENDI: Well, maybe so. But I want you to understand Iran does not have a nuclear weapon. If they did have a nuclear weapon and all these other things were going on, where would we be?

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's the bottom line. Congressman it's good to see you, sir. Thank you.

GARAMENDI: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks for (INAUDIBLE) it all out.

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Well, the news keeps getting worse for Deutsche Bank -- a stunning first quarter loss for the company.

Cheryl Casone on it and details right now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Oh man, Maria -- yes.

We're watching shares of Deutsche Bank this morning, very closely. Net income for the first quarter tumbled nearly 80 percent. That is leading the bank to cut jobs in the investment bank as well as Deutsche Bank saying that they're going to focus investment banking on serving core European clients.

They're going to reduce commitments to the U.S. and Asia. These results are Deutsche Bank's first since they ousted chief executive John Cryan back on April 8th.

So here we go. The stock is actually -- it's actually doing a little bit better than it was earlier, we should say. It's now down a little more than a half a percent. But again, some pressure on this stock today -- coming back a little bit.

All right. Subway is planning to close 500 stores in the U.S. this year. This is after the company announced a turnaround plan requiring franchise owners to invest more in operations and this is also on the back of Subway facing intense competition from rivals like McDonald's and Starbucks. Subway's U.S. sales dropped more than 4 percent last year. so another stock to watch today.

Well, the European space agency has released the largest map of our galaxy ever. And it contains more than a billion stars -- it's actually really cool. The 360-degree map was compiled by the Guya Project over the last few years. It displays a full quarter of our galaxy.

It took photos from opposite sides of our planet's orbit to pinpoint each star's exact locations. The public release of this new map expected to keep scientists and astronomers really busy studying stars for years to come. They're very excited about this.

And then there is this, a new study taking a look at cringe-worthy office phrases.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Get out of here. I think I'm going to lose it.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Sounds like somebody's got a case of the Mondays.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Even though it's Thursday, maybe we do. All right. Researchers say seven in ten Americans confess to saying such things as "think outside the box" or perhaps "give 110 percent".

BARTIROMO: I mentioned that earlier.

MCDOWELL: There is no more than 100 percent. Just saying that -- I didn't even know that.

CASONE: No. There's more. "Hammer it out". Who likes that one, right? "Run this up the flag pole".

BARTIROMO: I hate that one.

CASONE: "Throw them under the bus". And this could be a "win-win situation". How many times have you heard that one -- Maria and Dagen?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CASONE: I've heard it a few times.

HEGSETH: I find this corporation specific stuff to be the worst. One is with a group that said we're not going to call them meetings anymore. We're going to call them "knowledge shares".

BARTIROMO: What?

HEGSETH: We're going to get together and do "knowledge shares".

MCDOWELL: "Knowledge shares".

BARTIROMO: "Knowledge shares". That's hilarious.

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: Is that (INAUDIBLE) run by a thought leader?

BARTIROMO: That's a good one.

MCDOWELL: And one more all men to avoid -- "calm down". When you tell a woman who is winning an argument with you to calm down -- generally stay away from that. We're going to hand you your business.

BARTIROMO: Hey, was I not calm?

HEGSETH: Of course, you were calm.

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: I think he didn't like the content.

BARTIROMO: I was calmly pushing back, saying no, I disagree, the Iran deal stinks.

MCDOWELL: It's called passion and accuracy.

BARTIROMO: All right. We're going to take a break.

Speaking of Wall Street debuts, Sonos reportedly preparing an IPO -- could come as soon as June. We're going to check that out.

And then Alexa is now teaching etiquette. Amazon's smart assistant now made to encourage kids to say "please" and "thank you", next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

The return of the trading desk -- according to the Wall Street journal U.S. banks are having their best year for trading revenue since the financial crisis because of the rise in volatility.

Joining us this morning Thomas H. Lee Partners co-president Scott Sperling. Scott -- good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

SCOTT SPERLING, CO-PRESIDENT, THOMAS H. LEE PARTNERS: Thank you -- Maria. Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Where do you see the growth right now? Tell us about your investing and how you're allocating capital -- Scott.

SPERLING: Well, I think the areas that people have been looking at are ones where there's stronger secular growth trends and the entire health care sector is one where that continues to be an interesting opportunity, particularly in areas where you can help bend the cost curve, be able to provide high quality services with a more cost efficient delivery mechanism.

Another area is obviously the entire technology world offers significant subsectors of opportunity. The software area has been one that has been incredibly popular.

One of the things that we always have to do is measure the secular growth against the pricing it takes to buy those kinds of companies and I think having a reasonable amount of discipline in today's world will be rewarded long-term.

BARTIROMO: Are you seeing that both on the public side and on the private side? We started the conversation talking about the return of the trading desk because of an increase in volatility.

Do you see that -- those growth areas both on the public side as well as private side, which is what you're doing obviously, private investing?

SPERLING: Yes. I think these areas are ones that will account for a bigger and bigger percentage of the economic activity in the country, regardless of whether you're looking at companies that are still private or on the public side. So I think these are areas that will be interesting in both the public market as well as the private markets.

The ability of investors in today's public market to buy these companies at multiples that look something like 16 to 17 times, down from probably 19 to 20 times, could be reasonably attractive. The fundamentals that we see in the economy right now continue to be relatively strong.

I think it's not unreasonable to expect 3 percent GDP growth. I think when you combine that with the stimulus and some of that's coming from the stimulus of the tax cut, but combine it with the longer term impact of the stimulus with the tax cut, you can see this playing out for a longer duration than we ever would have thought when you look at the tenor of this recovery period.

FREEMAN: Question, James Freeman here with the "Wall Street Journal", question on interest rates.

SPERLING: Yes.

FREEMAN: Some people get a little nervous when the yield on the 10-year treasury note hits 3 percent. As you know, we've had a lot of good years with that level -- good years for the economy, for the stock market. But I'm wondering what it means for you and your ability to do deals. Where do you get nervous in terms of that interest rate's going up or that number on the 10-year going up?

SPERLING: Sure. That is clearly part of the equation that we look at. We want to be in a world where the coverage ratios of our obligations is reasonably high. We never return to that '06 to '07 period when the coverage ratios had gotten well below 1.5x -- 1.5 times.

So as you look at the cost of debt, that comes into the calculation of what we're willing to pay for companies. Three percent as you point out is actually a relatively attractive rate when you look long-term at where those rates have been.

Oftentimes in our history it's been closer to 5 percent but certainly it's much higher than -- it's probably a hundred basis points higher than we have gotten used to over the last few years. So it has some impact on the value that will own the paper (ph) companies.

BARTIROMO: Scott -- what's your take on technology here? I mean smart speaker maker Sonos is reportedly going public. The "Journal" first reporting that the IPO could value the company as high as $3 billion. Your thoughts on the IPO landscape and where you see technology opportunities today.

SPERLING: The markets will fall in and out of love obviously with any kind of company and certainly the technology sector has benefited when you look at the so-called FANG stocks and the impact that that has had in terms of the growth of the equity market values. It's been reasonably overwhelming.

So technology, because it does have significant secular growth in an economy where growth has been hard has been very popular. I think the applicability of technology to everything we do in our lives, so Sonos for example has certainly made it easier to have audio that has a diverse number of sources available to people in their homes. That kind of technology is one that will scale very well in the consumer market and people will pay for that.

Now, what you have to look at is what the nature of the competition will be over time. And while the overall market for that type of product, that functionality will continue to grow very strongly and everyone will evaluate the specific competitors within that to see what kind of share that they will have Sonos clearly has benefited from the one of the early drivers of this trend and this technology --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SPERLING: -- and you see that, I think in the expected value I think they want for the IPO.

FREEMAN: We're talking about the Wall Street trading desk doing so well and also about Deutsche Bank not doing well. You know, there are a lot of these big U.S. banks that keep complaining that if regulators here demand, they hold too much capital. It'll be a big disadvantage versus their overseas competitors and yet the U.S. banks seem to be crushing it versus their international competition.

SPERLING: Yes, they sure do. I think you have -- look, you have smart people across the industry, I can't comment on Deutsche Bank. The people we deal with are on the investment banking side and been very good. I can't comment more broadly on D.B. but the banks have adapted very well to the new rules that have dramatically reduced the leverage ratios at our commercial banking system.

So, whereas in zero six zero seven you were looking at 20 to 30 times leverage. You know, today you're really looking at 10 to 12 times leverage. So, the ROE, the return on their equity is not going to be as good as it was then but they've adapted very well to that. You see Goldman for example, Lloyd Blankfein has been out there talking about the consumer opportunity that Goldman has, and --

BARTIROMO: Right.

SPERLING: -- markets has been a major effort for them to provide a set of services to the consumer market. So, they are looking at new areas of growth and at the same time, they continue to have very, very smart people who are very helpful to people like us, who are looking to them for financing and M&A advice.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's interesting. Goldman's trying to get it -- is into the retail market. Blackstone Group into the retail market. Scott, good to see you sir.

SPERLING: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Scott Sperling. ( CO-PRESIDENT, THOMAS H. LEE PARTNERS )

SPERLING: You're very welcome.

BARTIROMO: Joining us this morning.

SPERLING: Take care.

urn:contentItem:5S66-RXC1-JB20-G3N1-00000-00Earnings Blitz; French President Speaks to Congress; Iran Nuclear Deal; Return of the Trading Desk; Return of the Trading Desk; Big Money of Advertising; ECB Leaves Rates Unchanged; Dr. Ronny Jackson Withdraws as Nominee for Veteran Affairs; H.P. and New York Giants Teaming Up for Safety2018-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:30ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTJames Freeman, John Garamendi, Scott Sperling, Brian O'KelleyNEWSFinancial042602cb.231Earnings Blitz; French President Speaks to Congress; Iran Nuclear Deal; Return of the Trading Desk; Return of the Trading Desk; Big Money of Advertising; ECB Leaves Rates Unchanged; Dr. Ronny Jackson Withdraws as Nominee for Veteran Affairs; H.P. and New York Giants Teaming Up for SafetyMaria Bartiromo, Pete Hegseth, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Gerri Willis, James Freeman

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back.

Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

I'm Maria Bartiromo -- happy Thursday to you. It is Thursday, April 26th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings in the driver's seat on Wall Street this morning -- that is what's dictating stocks. The Dow Industrials expected to be up about 50 points right out of the gate -- that's a quarter of a percent higher. The Nasdaq is up two-thirds of a percent right now -- that's 38 points higher.

Technology titans Amazon and Microsoft will be headlining the biggest earnings day of the season. Both are due out tonight after the bell. We will preview.

Plus Facebook shaking off the scandal -- shares soaring in the premarket, up better than 6 percent right now after the company beat expectations yesterday and posted strong growth in daily users and monthly users.

The Dow snapped a five-day losing streak yesterday, lifted by earnings from Boeing. The company reported better than expected earnings and revenue -- that helped it lift the Dow up about 60 points at the close, one-half of 1 percent. The S&P was up 5 but the Nasdaq was down about three-and-a-half.

In Europe this morning here's the scoop. We've got money moving into stocks as well but it is a fractional move. The FT100, the CAC 40 and the DAX index all higher by about between a quarter of a percent and half of a percent. Investors are waiting on the European Central Bank -- that decision on rates due out later this hour. No change in interest rates expected but we will be watching ECB president, Mario Draghi and what he says at his live news conference about stimulus going forward.

In Asia overnight, markets were mixed, take a look. The shanghai composite the worst performer in China, down one and a third percent.

A Wall Street retreat -- Deutsche Bank announcing plans to slash jobs in the United States amid falling profits. Details on the company's sprawling rebuilding efforts. Deutsche Bank shares are down two-thirds of a percent this morning.

And then child's play for Amazon -- how the technology company is teaching Alexa new parenting tricks.

Then, we will tell you the most cringe-worthy phrases used in the office. I think we know a couple of them.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman, along with Iraq and Afghanistan war veteran, Fox News contributor Pete Hegseth.

Great to see everybody today.

PETE HEGSETH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good morning to you.

HEGSETH: I wonder what those phrases are -- and how many of those have I said on TV.

BARTIROMO: "Try to think outside the box" --

HEGSETH: Ok.

BARTIROMO: That's one of them.

HEGSETH: Is that what it is?

BARTIROMO: It's one of them. We'll bring you all the phrases. But there are -- I know a phrase you hate.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Tell me.

BARTIROMO: "Let's unpack this".

MCDOWELL: Yes -- you read my mind. You read my mind.

BARTIROMO: You hate that phrase, I know it.

MCDOWELL: Yes. And that's kind of recent. And you know what I also hate? "Nothing burger". I hate it -- "nothing burger".

HEGSETH: I like --

MCDOWELL: Not just because Hillary Clinton used it. But it's just over- used.

HEGSETH: I don't like "with all due respect", because you know what's coming next -- little respect.

FREEMAN: I love that one Rickey Bobby says, but other than that, not so much.

Great earnings -- we'll see tomorrow if the economy and the fourth full quarter of the Trump presidency is really moving to a higher level.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We've got the GDP out this week. And of course, this is the single busiest day for earnings so far. And they have been largely better than expected. So we've got that profit story very much in place. We're going to talk about that this morning.

But first our top story right now. Emmanuel Macron addressed this Congress in a rousing speech yesterday. The French president made the case for staying in the Iran nuclear deal, saying that the U.S. and France can work together to forge a more comprehensive agreement that ultimately President Trump can come to accept.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EMMANUEL MACRON, FRENCH PRESIDENT: As for Iran, our objective is clear. Iran shall never possess any nuclear weapons -- not now, not in five years, not in 10 years, never.

This agreement may not address all concerns, but we should not abandon it without having something substantial and more substantial instead. That's my position.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: But later in the day, when speaking with reporters, Macron conceded that he believes the President will exit the Iran deal, quote, "for domestic reasons" and that of course, the deadline is next month.

Joining us now to talk about that is a member of the House Armed Services Committee, Democratic Congressman John Garamendi of California. Congressman -- it's good to see you. And thanks so much for joining us.

REP. JOHN GARAMENDI (D-CA), HOUSE ARMED SERVICES COMMITTEE: Good morning. Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: So your take on both of these statements from the French president. We know that the President -- President Trump has until May 12th to decide whether or not to renew that Iran deal. Your takeaway?

GARAMENDI: He's right and I hope he's wrong. He's absolutely right -- we have to stay in it. The JCPOA gives us the very best opportunity we have to prevent Iran from ever having a nuclear weapon. Certainly for the next decade, probably the next two decades, that agreement will prevent them from having a nuclear weapon.

The second point, will the President back away from it? I hope not. It would be a very, very serious mistake for a variety of reasons.

One, it would pull the United States away from key partners -- people that we absolutely have to work with if we're going to deal with Syria and Iran going into the future.

So let's hope that he's right on the first issue, that the JCPOA does prevent Iran from having a nuclear weapon; and secondly, that he's wrong about what the President might do. I think the President will recognize the extraordinary risks to the position of the United States as a leader in this world if he were to pull out.

BARTIROMO: What about changing certain areas? I mean isn't it true that there isn't enough opportunity to check whether or not they're being honest in terms of what they're doing with their nuclear capabilities? Are there fixes that the allies can put in place to change this deal so the President is more poised to stay in it?

GARAMENDI: Maria, you have a good point but you're slightly off the target. The view of what Iran is doing, that is, checking their nuclear programs -- that's in place.

The problem is all of the other things that Iran is doing. The Hezbollah, the support that they're giving to Syria, the support for terrorists from around the entire region -- all of those things were not included in the Iran nuclear deal. And those indeed are problems and the President is correct that that needs to be addressed and certainly President Macron is also quite correct, that we need to address those issues.

But that doesn't mean that we drop or exit the nuclear deal, which actually is working and the reviews by the international agencies as to what is happening in Iran are quite good, they are very incursive into Iran. So that's not he problem.

The problem is on the other things that Iran is doing beyond the nuclear.

HEGSETH: Congressman it's Pete Hegseth --

GARAMENDI: Sure.

HEGSETH: -- but this president gave Europe an opportunity to fill some of the holes and fixes in the deal which doesn't provide -- you may think it does, it doesn't provide oversight, it sunsets in 10 years. We gave them billions of dollars. They use it to fund terrorism.

Why do you trust that the Iranians won't after ten years, even if everything you're saying is true will actually give up their nuclear ambitions? Don't we have to be harder on them and have more visibility on enforcement? And how in the world does the existing deal do that?

GARAMENDI: If you get into the details of the agreement, the nuclear agreement, there are several stages along the way. There is a 10-year. There's also a 20-year and then Iran has signed on for the nonnuclear proliferation treaty which is forever more into the future. In other words, they have committed to not engage in nuclear weapons activities in the future.

HEGSETH: Do you trust them?

GARAMENDI: Of course, we don't trust them. That's why we have these verification programs in place which are very, very intrusive. And there are many mechanisms to determine if in fact they begin 10 years, 15 years, 20 years out in the future to restart their nuclear program. All of those remain in place.

But there really is a very major concern, correctly stated by the President, as well as by President Macron and others, that the other activities that Iran has engaged in, particularly what we're seeing in Syria right now, they are one of the major supporters of the Syrian -- of the Assad government in Syria and they have perhaps thousands of troops in Syria supporting the Syrian government and also working with Hezbollah, threatening Israel and certainly having a major impact on Lebanon.

So all those things are concerns; they need to be dealt with. France --

BARTIROMO: Well, how are they going to be dealt? How are they going to be dealt with if the President renews it and doesn't pull out?

I mean you're saying two things. You said it's working. You said the Iran deal is working. And then you said all of this stuff that they're doing -- dealing with Syria, supporting Hezbollah, threatening Israel -- so it's not working.

GARAMENDI: No. Maria -- that is not correct. The deal did not deal with those -- those issues that you just stated. It dealt with the nuclear thing. It did not deal with the other issues.

BARTIROMO: I see.

GARAMENDI: And there -- and some -- many people believe that the deal was not whole, it didn't cover everything and that's absolutely correct, it didn't cover everything. And that's absolutely correct. It did not cover everything. It dealt with what was and remains today the most important and that is that -- and President Macron said this very clearly -- Iran will never have a nuclear weapon. That's what the deal dealt with.

It didn't deal with the other activities, malicious and bad as they are. We should be dealing with those and if we work together and we don't dump the nuclear deal, which would create enormous division within the coalition that actually brought about the nuclear deal, if we don't dump that, then we will have a strong coalition to deal with these other issues rather than --

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: Congressman -- James Freeman here with the "Journal". I'm wondering, therefore, if you then support bringing back the sanctions that were relieved by the deal as punishment for everything you just described in terms of funding terrorism?

GARAMENDI: Well, there are other sanctions that are still in place, additional sanctions may be necessary and they are always available to us going into the future. That's quite possible.

FREEMAN: Does that mean you're not supporting them now?

GARAMENDI: We need to work together with other countries. Right now, all of the focus is on the President threatening to dump the nuclear deal, which would set all of this thing back and not allow us to move forward on anything. So that's the first problem.

FREEMAN: I know but you just detailed all of their offenses in the region. Doesn't that justify bringing sanctions?

GARAMENDI: It could, and we need to be working with our allies on this issue. Some of those sanctions are a direct problem to our allies and that -- and to the United States.

For example, there's a major deal that has been cut, Iran wants to purchase dozens if not hundreds of new airliners. That's a big deal for the airbus and quite possibly for Boeing. And so as you look at those sanctions, you want to be careful to only use sanctions that are detrimental to Iran, not detrimental to the interest of the coalition partners.

So what I'm saying is that sanctions are there. They can be used. But just to go back and to put all of those back in place may create additional problems and not achieve the goal.

So look at this thing carefully. Use sanctions that are very targeted, that do put the appropriate pressure on Iran so that they will back away from many of the things.

But let me also put one more issue on the table and that is when the President said three weeks ago that we had completed the work on ISIS, he wanted to pull out the troops out of Syria, and that he wanted to leave Syria to others.

Well, it turns out that the others are Russia, Iran, Turkey, and the Gulf States. That creates an enormous vacuum of power that will be filled by Iran and that's not where we want to go. So you have to look at this thing in its total complexity.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GARAMENDI: And if we do, I think we can make progress, keep the nuclear deal in place. It is working and it will work for many years into the future.

And secondly, make sure that we do apply the appropriate pressure. Keep in mind, Syria in this entire equation.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Dagen -- did you want to say something?

MCDOWELL: No. I just -- Congressman, you said look at the complete deal and all that's going on in its entirety. The problem that a lot of Americans have with that nuclear deal with Iran in the first place is we handed $1.7 billion in pallets of cash to Iran. Where is that money going as a state sponsor of terrorism?

It's going to fund terrorist attacks. It's going to fund Hezbollah. So you can't really separate those two. We gave them the money before there was any evidence that they were really pulling back on the nuclear program. We actually -- we flew it to Iran in the secret of night. And the only reason we even know about it is because of the reporting of the "Wall Street Journal".

GARAMENDI: Well, that coffee has been spilled. That coffee's no longer in the cup. So what do we do going forward? The nuclear deal is in place and it is working. That's a good thing. That's a very, very important thing. Now, let's --

BARTIROMO: You keep saying it's working -- Congressman.

GARAMENDI: It is.

BARTIROMO: But all of these things that are not working are so obvious. And then a moment ago you said we have to be careful because Iran's going to buy all these jets, possibly from Boeing and from others and we have to be careful about that.

What's our goal? Is our goal to stop the nuclear capability or get business for Boeing and the jet makers?

GARAMENDI: Well, you're quite correct, our goal was to stop the nuclear capability. And that is happening.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: How is that happening if they're supporting Syria? They're supporting Hezbollah. They're threatening Israel. And they're using the $1.7 billion that we sent over there to do just that.

GARAMENDI: Calm down for a second and carefully take a listen to what you just said. The nuclear deal -- that was what we dealt with. The JCPOA was about Iran building a nuclear weapon and at that time --

HEGSETH: They're still building missiles -- Congressman. They're still testing and building missiles, delivery systems for nuclear capabilities.

(CROSSTALK)

GARAMENDI: Hang on a second. I want you to be very, very careful about what we're talking about here. Iran was on the cusp of actually building a nuclear weapon. They could have built one within one year, maybe less than one year. That's no longer the case. They do not now have the materials or the systems to build a nuclear weapon.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GARAMENDI: That's what the JCPOA was about. These other issues were not part of that deal. The important --

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, that was not smart. That was not smart.

GARAMENDI: -- the important -- excuse me.

(CROSSTALK)

GARAMENDI: Well, maybe so. But I want you to understand Iran does not have a nuclear weapon. If they did have a nuclear weapon and all these other things were going on, where would we be?

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's the bottom line. Congressman it's good to see you, sir. Thank you.

GARAMENDI: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks for (INAUDIBLE) it all out.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Well, the news keeps getting worse for Deutsche Bank -- a stunning first quarter loss for the company.

Cheryl Casone on it and details right now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Oh man, Maria -- yes.

We're watching shares of Deutsche Bank this morning, very closely. Net income for the first quarter tumbled nearly 80 percent. That is leading the bank to cut jobs in the investment bank as well as Deutsche Bank saying that they're going to focus investment banking on serving core European clients.

They're going to reduce commitments to the U.S. and Asia. These results are Deutsche Bank's first since they ousted chief executive John Cryan back on April 8th.

So here we go. The stock is actually -- it's actually doing a little bit better than it was earlier, we should say. It's now down a little more than a half a percent. But again, some pressure on this stock today -- coming back a little bit.

All right. Subway is planning to close 500 stores in the U.S. this year. This is after the company announced a turnaround plan requiring franchise owners to invest more in operations and this is also on the back of Subway facing intense competition from rivals like McDonald's and Starbucks. Subway's U.S. sales dropped more than 4 percent last year. so another stock to watch today.

Well, the European space agency has released the largest map of our galaxy ever. And it contains more than a billion stars -- it's actually really cool. The 360-degree map was compiled by the Guya Project over the last few years. It displays a full quarter of our galaxy.

It took photos from opposite sides of our planet's orbit to pinpoint each star's exact locations. The public release of this new map expected to keep scientists and astronomers really busy studying stars for years to come. They're very excited about this.

And then there is this, a new study taking a look at cringe-worthy office phrases.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Get out of here. I think I'm going to lose it.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Sounds like somebody's got a case of the Mondays.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Even though it's Thursday, maybe we do. All right. Researchers say seven in ten Americans confess to saying such things as "think outside the box" or perhaps "give 110 percent".

BARTIROMO: I mentioned that earlier.

MCDOWELL: There is no more than 100 percent. Just saying that -- I didn't even know that.

CASONE: No. There's more. "Hammer it out". Who likes that one, right? "Run this up the flag pole".

BARTIROMO: I hate that one.

CASONE: "Throw them under the bus". And this could be a "win-win situation". How many times have you heard that one -- Maria and Dagen?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CASONE: I've heard it a few times.

HEGSETH: I find this corporation specific stuff to be the worst. One is with a group that said we're not going to call them meetings anymore. We're going to call them "knowledge shares".

BARTIROMO: What?

HEGSETH: We're going to get together and do "knowledge shares".

MCDOWELL: "Knowledge shares".

BARTIROMO: "Knowledge shares". That's hilarious.

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: Is that (INAUDIBLE) run by a thought leader?

BARTIROMO: That's a good one.

MCDOWELL: And one more all men to avoid -- "calm down". When you tell a woman who is winning an argument with you to calm down -- generally stay away from that. We're going to hand you your business.

BARTIROMO: Hey, was I not calm?

HEGSETH: Of course, you were calm.

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: I think he didn't like the content.

BARTIROMO: I was calmly pushing back, saying no, I disagree, the Iran deal stinks.

MCDOWELL: It's called passion and accuracy.

BARTIROMO: All right. We're going to take a break.

Speaking of Wall Street debuts, Sonos reportedly preparing an IPO -- could come as soon as June. We're going to check that out.

And then Alexa is now teaching etiquette. Amazon's smart assistant now made to encourage kids to say "please" and "thank you", next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

The return of the trading desk -- according to the Wall Street journal U.S. banks are having their best year for trading revenue since the financial crisis because of the rise in volatility.

Joining us this morning Thomas H. Lee Partners co-president Scott Sperling. Scott -- good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

SCOTT SPERLING, CO-PRESIDENT, THOMAS H. LEE PARTNERS: Thank you -- Maria. Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Where do you see the growth right now? Tell us about your investing and how you're allocating capital -- Scott.

SPERLING: Well, I think the areas that people have been looking at are ones where there's stronger secular growth trends and the entire health care sector is one where that continues to be an interesting opportunity, particularly in areas where you can help bend the cost curve, be able to provide high quality services with a more cost efficient delivery mechanism.

Another area is obviously the entire technology world offers significant subsectors of opportunity. The software area has been one that has been incredibly popular.

One of the things that we always have to do is measure the secular growth against the pricing it takes to buy those kinds of companies and I think having a reasonable amount of discipline in today's world will be rewarded long-term.

BARTIROMO: Are you seeing that both on the public side and on the private side? We started the conversation talking about the return of the trading desk because of an increase in volatility.

Do you see that -- those growth areas both on the public side as well as private side, which is what you're doing obviously, private investing?

SPERLING: Yes. I think these areas are ones that will account for a bigger and bigger percentage of the economic activity in the country, regardless of whether you're looking at companies that are still private or on the public side. So I think these are areas that will be interesting in both the public market as well as the private markets.

The ability of investors in today's public market to buy these companies at multiples that look something like 16 to 17 times, down from probably 19 to 20 times, could be reasonably attractive. The fundamentals that we see in the economy right now continue to be relatively strong.

I think it's not unreasonable to expect 3 percent GDP growth. I think when you combine that with the stimulus and some of that's coming from the stimulus of the tax cut, but combine it with the longer term impact of the stimulus with the tax cut, you can see this playing out for a longer duration than we ever would have thought when you look at the tenor of this recovery period.

FREEMAN: Question, James Freeman here with the "Wall Street Journal", question on interest rates.

SPERLING: Yes.

FREEMAN: Some people get a little nervous when the yield on the 10-year treasury note hits 3 percent. As you know, we've had a lot of good years with that level -- good years for the economy, for the stock market. But I'm wondering what it means for you and your ability to do deals. Where do you get nervous in terms of that interest rate's going up or that number on the 10-year going up?

SPERLING: Sure. That is clearly part of the equation that we look at. We want to be in a world where the coverage ratios of our obligations is reasonably high. We never return to that '06 to '07 period when the coverage ratios had gotten well below 1.5x -- 1.5 times.

So as you look at the cost of debt, that comes into the calculation of what we're willing to pay for companies. Three percent as you point out is actually a relatively attractive rate when you look long-term at where those rates have been.

Oftentimes in our history it's been closer to 5 percent but certainly it's much higher than -- it's probably a hundred basis points higher than we have gotten used to over the last few years. So it has some impact on the value that will own the paper (ph) companies.

BARTIROMO: Scott -- what's your take on technology here? I mean smart speaker maker Sonos is reportedly going public. The "Journal" first reporting that the IPO could value the company as high as $3 billion. Your thoughts on the IPO landscape and where you see technology opportunities today.

SPERLING: The markets will fall in and out of love obviously with any kind of company and certainly the technology sector has benefited when you look at the so-called FANG stocks and the impact that that has had in terms of the growth of the equity market values. It's been reasonably overwhelming.

So technology, because it does have significant secular growth in an economy where growth has been hard has been very popular. I think the applicability of technology to everything we do in our lives, so Sonos for example has certainly made it easier to have audio that has a diverse number of sources available to people in their homes. That kind of technology is one that will scale very well in the consumer market and people will pay for that.

Now, what you have to look at is what the nature of the competition will be over time. And while the overall market for that type of product, that functionality will continue to grow very strongly and everyone will evaluate the specific competitors within that to see what kind of share that they will have Sonos clearly has benefited from the one of the early drivers of this trend and this technology --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SPERLING: -- and you see that, I think in the expected value I think they want for the IPO.

FREEMAN: We're talking about the Wall Street trading desk doing so well and also about Deutsche Bank not doing well. You know, there are a lot of these big U.S. banks that keep complaining that if regulators here demand, they hold too much capital. It'll be a big disadvantage versus their overseas competitors and yet the U.S. banks seem to be crushing it versus their international competition.

SPERLING: Yes, they sure do. I think you have -- look, you have smart people across the industry, I can't comment on Deutsche Bank. The people we deal with are on the investment banking side and been very good. I can't comment more broadly on D.B. but the banks have adapted very well to the new rules that have dramatically reduced the leverage ratios at our commercial banking system.

So, whereas in zero six zero seven you were looking at 20 to 30 times leverage. You know, today you're really looking at 10 to 12 times leverage. So, the ROE, the return on their equity is not going to be as good as it was then but they've adapted very well to that. You see Goldman for example, Lloyd Blankfein has been out there talking about the consumer opportunity that Goldman has, and --

BARTIROMO: Right.

SPERLING: -- markets has been a major effort for them to provide a set of services to the consumer market. So, they are looking at new areas of growth and at the same time, they continue to have very, very smart people who are very helpful to people like us, who are looking to them for financing and M&A advice.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's interesting. Goldman's trying to get it -- is into the retail market. Blackstone Group into the retail market. Scott, good to see you sir.

SPERLING: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Scott Sperling. ( CO-PRESIDENT, THOMAS H. LEE PARTNERS )

SPERLING: You're very welcome.

BARTIROMO: Joining us this morning.

SPERLING: Take care.

BARTIROMO: And to you. Coming up technology earnings blitz, Amazon, Microsoft, Intel all set to report results "AFTER THE BELL" tonight. We're breaking down what to expect.

Then policing your kids, watching the web. Google now updating its YouTube Kids app, to improve parental controls. Back in a moment, right here.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thank you so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday April 26th. Your top stories right now 07:30 a.m. on the East Coast. It is the single busiest day for first quarter earnings today. General Motors and Southwest Airlines among the companies reporting this morning. G.M. beat expectations while Southwest was mixed. There's a look at the stocks both under pressure today. G.M. down 2-1/2 percent, Southwest down 3-1/2 percent.

Investors are also waiting on big tech. AmazonIntel and Microsoft all reporting their quarter after the close tonight. Checking the broader markets this morning while we see those stocks trading up and the broader market up as well. The Dow snapped a five-day losing streak yesterday and the momentum continues this morning up 40 points on the Dow right now.

Boeing was a big earnings beat yesterday. That stock was strong and that lifted the Dow. Up about 60 points at the close yesterday. The S&P was up about five, but the Nasdaq was under selling crasher finishing lower by 3- 1/2.

In Europe this morning, stocks are trading up. FT-100 CAC Quarante and the DAX Index are higher. CAC Quarante in Paris is up a half a percent, the others are fractionally moving, but in the plus column.

Investors are waiting on the ECB decision, the European Central Bank news is going to be out in about 15 minutes. No change in rate expected. But we are watching the ECB President Mario Draghi during his news conference and what he says about stimulus going forward.

In Asia overnight markets were mixed. China was the weak spot. The Shanghai Composite down one and a third percent.

Big technology is now targeting kids. Amazon and YouTube making changes so that parents can breathe a sigh of relief, will tell you about it. And then it's NFL draft day. We're taking a look at the technology that's helping prevent player injuries. All that coming up.

But first this, technology earnings Blitz. Tech giants Amazon, Microsoft and Intel all do out "AFTER THE BELL" tonight.

Meanwhile Facebook and Alphabet both beating expectations this week. The two technology darlings posted a spike in digital ad dollars accounting for 91 percent of Facebook's revenue and 97 percent of Google parent company revenue. That could give us some information about Amazon, because Amazon will also report ad revenue with its prime business tonight. Joining us right now is AppNexus CEO, Brian O'Kelley. Brian, good to see you. Thank you so much for joining us.

BRIAN O'KELLEY, CEO, APPNEXUS: Thanks for having me

BARTIROMO: And you have a great read on advertising revenue. Explain AppNexus and tell us what you're seeing in ad revenue right now.

O'KELLEY: All right. So, AppNexus is the technology that helps companies who aren't Facebook get as much money for their content as possible. So, if you -- if you're watching FOX Business right now, you're seeing ads. Who decides what ads you see? Well, for many of the companies who aren't Facebook, that's app Nexus. We're trying to use machine learning and non- personal information to figure out which ads are the most effective to serve to all the consumers watching T.V. or reading articles on the web. So, that's what we do.

Now the big challenge in advertising right now, is that if your Facebook or Google you have an immense amount of data about consumers that they've -- in many cases freely given, and you can use that to micro-target ads. But of course, that also means that the consumer is the product. You're effectively selling the consumer their own data and monetizing that as you see in these earnings incredibly well.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly and that's what kept them in trouble.

O'KELLEY: Indeed.

PETE HEGSETH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Do you -- and you can avoid that because you're not holding anyone's personal data. You don't have the Facebook problem of how do I protect your privacy. Is that right?

O'KELLEY: That's correct. Of course, we have the opposite problem which is that we don't know who you are. And so, we have to use these macro techniques to figure out what ads you'll probably like if you're watching this show or if you're reading that article. But we don't know who you are.

FREEMAN: So, like we've seen in some recent years, Facebook and Alphabet, Google's parent capturing almost all the growth or all the growth in online advertising. I believe in mobile advertising. Is that trend changing?

O'KELLEY: Well, I think this last quarter we saw that decline a little bit. So, Google's share went down a little. So, we're starting to see that change. I think the biggest challenge is that if consumers continue to want to go to Facebook or see videos on YouTube that's where the advertisers are going to go. So, the challenge is if you're any other media company or content producer, how do you get the consumers to spend less time on Facebook or spend less time on YouTube?

HEGSETH: So, I mean that was part of the criticism of Facebook is there a monopoly effectively in a particular space. Do you anticipate competitors then? Would that would create that opportunity for other advertisers?

O'KELLEY: I'd love to see competitors. When you have a consumer backlash against Facebook, people were very upset with Facebook and yet where do you go? You know?

MCDOWELL: Right.

O'KELLEY: Tweet?

MCDOWELL: That goes -- that goes to what Sheryl Sandberg said on the call yesterday that they haven't had seen a meaningful trend of advertisers fleeing the platform. It was a little strange because there was so much advertiser outrage at YouTube when they found -- the advertisers found out that their commercials were appearing and videos of questionable, if not repugnant content. But this, it's like, as long as the advertisers attitude seems to be, as long as this benefits us we don't really care.

BARTIROMO: So, and as a P.R. move they have this latest apology, a promising to keep data safe. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: But then something happened we had to deal with spam, clickbait, fake news and data misuse. That's going to change.

From now on, Facebook will do more to keep you safe and protect your privacy. So we can all get back to what made Facebook good in the first place, friends.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Is that enough? I mean the stock is up today after the strong quarterly results because people are saying well maybe this didn't matter to investors and advertisers.

O'KELLEY: I think it matters a ton. I mean, when I talk to the largest advertisers in the world they say consistently, I want an alternative to YouTube and Facebook.

BARTIROMO: Really? OK.

O'KELLEY: I don't want to spend my money there but that's where people were spending all their time. So, I think the biggest challenge is really that, you can delete Facebook. And I wish you would because (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: I don't know if you can delete it. We were hearing that people try to delete the app and they couldn't.

O'KELLEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: It's like impossible to get rid of Facebook

O'KELLEY: That's a monopoly. So, what are we going to do?

FREEMAN: It's this is obviously a product that a lot of consumers have freely chosen to this point. But this is interesting that you're hearing from advertisers that they would like new options. Because you look at these earnings reports 50 percent growth in the ad revenue at Facebook. They're still writing and increasingly writing checks even if they seem to want more options.

O'KELLEY: Yes, well one thing to think about is that as television becomes more and more digital so, people cut the cord and we can actually do more intelligent ad insertion into T.V. Broadcast we show everyone the same ad. But increasingly we can choose different ads for different people. And that means we can get much better results for television advertising. And I think that gives people a real alternative, where on digital advertising right now YouTube has a huge monopoly of digital. But don't forget that's a small subset of all of the advertising that these big marketers are spending. So, it looks like a lot of digital but as we see T.V. come towards this, we're going to see a very, very different landscape.

MCDOWELL: But you need to figure out a better way to connect the viewer and the customer with the actual buying opportunity which is what Instagram which is owned by Facebook does so brilliantly. It's like they show you something and it's like click on this to click on this ad and you can purchase it immediately literally with your finger, and your thumb print on your iPhone. So, again that that's the challenge for traditional advertising. Even if the video is delivered on this device.

BARTIROMO: And then they can measure all of that.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: They measure it all and then that's what the advertisers want.

O'KELLEY: Yes, exactly.

BARTIROMO: Really, really important conversation. Brian, thank you. Thank you so much.

O'KELLEY: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Brian O'Kelly, joining us there, AppNexus.

Coming up, Alexa for kids. The new way Amazon is helping to teach your children manners. Then keeping kids safe on the web YouTube rules out improved parental controls as well. Back in a moment, right here.

BARTIROMO: Breaking news, the European Central Bank has left interest rates unchanged as expected. We're waiting on Mario Draghi and his press conference within the next hour to see if he has -- will reveal anything else about stimulus. No change in market action. This in fact was expected.

Meanwhile there's this, Amazon is releasing a kid-friendly Echo Dot with parental controls. Alexa may already be listening in. Gerri Willis, with the details now, Gerri.

GERRI WILLIS, FBN CORRESPONDENT: That's right, she is listening in. And don't forget that. But I'm a big fan. And if you're worried about Alexa's smart voice assistance eavesdropping on your conversations, well you probably should be concerned and here's why. By exploiting a coding error in Alexa's skills, the researchers found a way to get the device to continue listening even long after the software was activated.

Amazon said it's fixed this problem. But I have to tell you, she's listening in on what you're saying. And now Alexa may help you raise your kids. You're seeing the products right here. It's the new Echo Dot for kids. They encase it in rubber basically and they put special content on it just for kids. Now, $79.99 is the original price for this.

But if you want to buy the souped up version of this over time, you can get access to audio books, radio stations, just for kids, Disney content, Nickelodeon and National Geographic content, that will cost you extra after the first year, $2.99 a month per kid and of course we've seen Google, YouTube struggle with this very issue. They have an app for kids that hasn't worked very well and they're trying to make improvements to that. But the kids Amazon feature is so interesting because they're trying to get people to talk nice to Alexa. So, if children say please, then they get rewarded for it. They're told (INAUDIBLE) thank you very much for that, for speaking nicely to me. And I hear that the real concern about this isn't are you being nice to Alexa. The real concern was Alexa is always a woman's voice.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WILLIS: So, they didn't want people -- kids learning to be nasty to women.

BARTIROMO: I think -- I can't believe this, that they're listening even when you don't know that they're listening. This is an incredibly story Gerri, really. Thank you so much.

WILLIS: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: We want to leave it there. Because we have breaking news. We want to talk to you about this. Dr. Ronny Jackson is pulling out of the race for the V.A. Secretary. Pete Hegseth, we are just getting this news. Dagen, you saw it crossing. Anything else?

MCDOWELL: This is the reporting --

BARTIROMO: Ronny Jackson.

MCDOWELL: This is reporting from John Roberts, the Chief White House Correspondent at the FOX News Channel. But I think that this was expected, was it not?

HEGSETH: Yes, I mean, as of last night it looked like it was likely, too much stuff had come out. And people didn't know if it was verified or not. He was denying most of it. It was a quick pick from this president as well from a guy he truly respected with a -- with a proven record in the military and as a doctor in the White House through to multiple administrations.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

HEGSETH: I mean, he got a lot of praise from the Obama folks as well. Too much, too fast.

MCDOWELL: It was these revelation that were put out, and quite frankly when I put on Twitter, you know, it's an insult to snakes to call Washington, D.C. A snake pit, that all of this information started coming out in the press about allegations of drinking on the job, of pill prescribing, questionable practices prescribing medication to people within the White House. I just thought it was deeply unfortunate. And I don't know why anybody --

BARTIROMO: It's deeply unfortunate. But apparently, there was a trip that only a small cabal of people in the Obama administration was on and now we understand that this is getting out. I mean, it's really unfortunate what the previous administration is doing to this current administration in terms of leaks, in terms of trying hard to put all these barriers up in place. I actually think it's disgusting. I mean it's a -- but it feels like that's the only way this information could have gotten out. That's why I bring this up.

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: Well, it does show what a nasty town Washington can be. And also, the oddity of this story is this is not a nominee who came from somewhere else and these reports come out. This is someone that is -- the president has been working with closely, that the previous president worked with closely. You had a lot of people on the record from both parties saying this is a solid citizen, a great colleague, and so to now have off the record --

HEGSETH: Yes.

FREEMAN: -- allegations. Contrary to what the president and his predecessor have said they witnessed, I find it just beyond bizarre that this is what takes down a nominee. But that's the culture we live in now.

HEGSETH: No, go ahead.

MCDOWELL: No, there and -- you can speak to this. There are great entrenched interests.

HEGSETH: Yes.

MCDOWELL: In the way that the veterans administration operates, in terms of the way that money is doled out. So, if they think, these interests think that somebody's going to come in and change the status quo in terms of who gets the money and how much then --

HEGSETH: The veterans industrial complex is powerful. This guy was -- this president wants to shake it up. He would have as well. He never got his encore. He never got his confirmation hearing, said it was rumor and innuendo which is incredibly (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: Isn't that right.

FREEMAN: It's so awful. Why didn't Obama fire him? And why has President Trump had such a good working experience with him?

BARTIROMO: There's a cabal that wants to destroy Donald Trump.

HEGSETH: Correct.

BARTIROMO: And they want chaos around him. Your name has been floated out there.

HEGSETH: Yes, it has.

BARTIROMO: Would you want the job?

HEGSETH: If the president asked me to serve, great. But he hasn't at this point. So, we'll see.

BARTIROMO: We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The NFL draft kicks off tonight on FOX as new technology is helping players put their best foot forward. Cheryl Casone with all the details now, Cheryl.

CASONE: About the foot Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CASONE: There you go. NFL draft day is here, and as young athletes are preparing to enter the league, the NFL is looking at new ways to protect them. So, I went down to the New York Giants training facility to find out how a partnership with H.P. is helping them stay one step ahead of injury.

(BEGIN VIDEO TAPE)

CASONE: It's one of the biggest risks of playing in the NFL, injury. But it's not just concussions that take players out of the game. With nearly two-thirds of football injuries occurring in the lower limbs, the shoes athletes wear can determine a team's fate.

LEIGH WEISS, DIRECTOR OF REHABILITATION, NEW YORK GIANTS: Shoes are no longer seen as a piece of apparel. You know, they're a piece of protective equipment.

CASONE: Here at the New York Giants training facility, they are using this. Technology from H.P. with 3D scanning that creates digital profiles of players' feet.

JOE SKIBA, EQUIPMENT DIRECTOR, NEW YORK GIANTS: It's taking your foot, it's taking your length, it's taking your width.

CASONE: OK.

SKIBA: So, one of the most important things in today's game is players safety.

CASONE: Yes.

SKIBA: So, the first thing we want to do is we want to take a scan and make sure he's actually wearing the exact footwear he should be wearing to perform on the field.

CASONE: Quarterback Davis Webb showed me how it all works.

DAVIS WEBB, QUARTERBACK, NEW YORK GIANTS: Your right foot is a -- is a little bigger.

CASONE: OK, your right arch is bigger than your left. So, you do need custom shoes?

Turned out, he needed the equipment more than he thought.

SKIBA: So, we're going to put the recommendation right here.

WEBB: That's what I wear.

CASONE: Is this right?

SKIBA: Actually, this is not -- this is actually not a set-up. This is actually the cleat that Davis actually wears.

CASONE: H.P. technology puts million-dollar players together with high end shoes from Nike, Adidas and Under Armour, boosting performance and health.

RON COUGHLIN, PRESIDENT, H.P. PERSONAL SYSTEMS: There's probably no shoe that has more pressure than a 300-pound linemen on a cleat. And so, having the best fit for them and the support, they probably have the highest need in the world. So, it was a great place for us to test our technology.

CASONE: Every player from all 32 NFL teams are being scanned for this season.

JENNIFER LANGTON, VICE PRESIDENT, NFL HEALTH AND SAFETY: We can help bring innovation to the space, i.e. You know, the H.P. fit scanner, so they are in the best cleat available for themselves.

CASONE: And the Giants are hoping their partnership with H.P. will give them a shoe-in to the Super Bowl.

WEISS: So, at the end of the day, you know, the healthy football teams are usually more successful football teams and that's -- and that's what we started for.

CASONE: So, a healthy team is a winning team?

WEISS: Yes, that's what keeps me up at night.

CASONE: And since I'm a runner, I had to try it.

COUGHLIN: Wow, you have a big width difference. Do you know that?

CASONE: No.

COUGHLIN: Really?

CASONE: Yes, look at that.

UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN: But you did come up with two cleats.

COUGHLIN: In case, you are going to go out there.

(END VIDEO TAPE)

CASONE: All right, so yes, I learned a few things about my own feet as well, Maria, when I went out and shot the story. But --

BARTIROMO: So, you need custom made shoes?

CASONE: I need custom-made shoes. I have a low arch on my left and a right -- a high arch on my right. I had no clue. I have whacky feet. But so are they. So, I feel better about it. Anyway, the draft is tonight, we're really excited.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Cheryl. Don't forget to catch the live coverage of the NFL draft tonight, 8:00 p.m. Eastern time. Showtime. Cheryl, thank you. Still ahead, Kanye West causes a stir again after the rapper tweets his praise of president Trump and has a new not so kind words of former president Obama, next hour, right here.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it its Thursday, April 26th. Your top stories right now.

urn:contentItem:5P4B-2YM1-DY0W-450H-00000-00Earnings Blitz; Health Care Battle; Foxconn Coming To Wisconsin; Health Care Reform Timeline; Eyeing Tech Earnings; Sports Car Enthusiasts2017-07-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:30ZLexisNexisEarnings Blitz; Health Care Battle; Foxconn Coming To Wisconsin; Health Care Reform Timeline; Eyeing Tech Earnings; Sports Car EnthusiastsLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thank you so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, July 27th. Your top stories right now, 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. There's an earnings blitz happening on Wall Street, Twitter shares are following down seven percent this morning after reporting a second quarter earnings. The company reported it had 328 million monthly active users but that showed no growth from the previous quarter, ad revenue was also down 14 percent even though it was better than expected. The stock, selling off down at lows right now, down better than nine percent.

It is a packed earnings week this week and it's the markets to all-time highs. The Dow, the NASDAQ, and the S&P 500 all close in record territory yesterday.
