PENN: I don't know much about the book but I can say the American public now has two minds on these investigations, almost two-thirds say these investigations are hurting the country, all of them. Second, when I asked them, should they investigate something like, Clinton's uranium one deal, almost two-thirds also say yes, just as 75 percent said yes to an independent council.

So the public says, yes, investigate, yes, investigate leaks, yes, investigate Clinton's uranium one deal, yes, investigate Trump and then they turn around and say, you know what, we've got too many investigations. I really want taxes and infrastructure and all those good things that'll keep our economy growing.

BARTIROMO: It's funny. That is funny because you're hearing both sides of that in the polls. Look, these polls are really important that you're doing, these surveys are indicating where the American people stand on all of the stuff. So thanks for that, Mark.

PENN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: All right, good to see you, Sir Mark Penn, joining us there. Tune in tomorrow morning. I will sit down with House Speaker Paul Ryan, to talk health care tax reform and a lot more. That's tomorrow right here, 6:00 a.m. Eastern on MORNINGS WITH MARIA, our exclusive interview with the house speaker.

First, though, coming up next, protest in Venezuela continuing against President Nicolas Maduro as the U.S. ordered new sanctions for administration officials in the country and now look on foreign relations between the two countries, straight ahead. And then Starbucks brews up earnings after the bell tonight and analysis of the coffee-chain's revenue expectation. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Record highs on Wall Street again. The Dow, the S&P 500, the NASDAQ all hitting all-time highs at the close yesterday. The momentum is continuing this morning. Take a look at Futures indicating a gain at the opening of trading as the averages continue to trade in all- time unchartered territory.

We're looking at a couple of names this morning. Dunkin' brands, one to watch. The company reported second-quarter earnings earlier this hour. Earnings per share topped expectations but revenue was a slight miss at Dunkin', the stock up 15 percent over the last year. We're also watching Starbucks this morning. The coffee giant is also set to release its fiscal third-quarter earnings after the bell. Analysts are looking for earnings of $0.55 a share. Starbucks stock up five percent this year.

The U.S. government imposing sanctions on more than a dozen Venezuela officials, ahead of the country's controversial vote. Cheryl Casone with the story now. Cheryl, good morning.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. That's right. So, the Trump administration has hit 13 senior Venezuelan officials with sanctions as the country plans to hold a national vote this Sunday. Sanctions freeze the U.S. assets of all of those affected and it stops U.S. entities from doing business with those same people. The Venezuelan government is holding the vote to rewrite the country's constitution. Opposition groups launched a 48-hour strike yesterday. Of course, more protest against the vote, but, again, the situation in Venezuela and there's video from Caracas continues to deteriorate by the day.

Well, back here at home, U.S. travelers that are going down to Mexico are being warned not to drink the alcohol. The State Department added the warning to its Web site after a 20-year-old Wisconsin woman died after being pulled out of a pool at a Mexican resort. The Milwaukee Journal said to investigated that incident reports that more than three dozen travelers have become sick after drinking allegedly tainted or substandard alcohol while in the country. So, that warning has now gone out to travelers.

OK. Well, the headlines about Samsung this past year just they continue to get worst for the company, frankly. The leader jailed as part of a corruption scandal; The Galaxy Note 7 smartphones, the focus of that big recall after fires in the phones, but even after all that, Samsung is reporting record quarterly earnings, and they're putting the company on track to overtake Apple as the world's most profitably company. And that would end Intel's dominance in the semiconductor industry as well. So, some finally good news for Samsung shareholders.

And Goldman Sachs is expanding its presence in retail. The bank is teaming up with Fidelity Investment to offer loans to about 6 million investors. The company says the loans of between 75,000 to 25 million will be secured by the borrower's portfolios, stocks, and funds. This is Goldman's latest attempt to reach mainstream investments without brick and mortar branches. The stock down more than seven percent so far in 2017, excuse me, Maria. And obviously, Goldman is trying to take a cue from the success over at Morgan Stanley, focusing on those clients.

BARTIROMO: Yes, apparently. I mean, for the -- thank you, Cheryl -- forever, for the longest time, we look at Goldman as really an institutional firm, Michael. But little by little, last couple of years, they've been trying to do -- trying to experiment in the retail sector.

BLOCK: The bar or the lenders as we saw nine years ago, the taxpayers. So, we shall see.

MCDOWELL: Are you -- really? Are you suggesting that, say, the stock market is a bubble on par with what we saw in housing?

BLOCK: Not now.

MCDOWELL: And loans made -- and loans made against these assets will just blow up in the face of Goldman Sachs?

BLOCK: I quote Bane from Batman, "Now is not the time for fear, that comes later." So, something is going to happen here. It's boom-bust cycle. I'm a big believer in that. We don't know what it's going to be. It's probably not going to be housing because everyone's watching that, maybe it's going to be stocks, maybe it's going to be the bond market, maybe it's going to be peer-to-peer lending. It could be anything and I spend a lot of my waking hours trying to figure out what's coming next. That's a long- term gain. And we'll see.

BARTIROMO: Well, you're spending time looking at what's coming next. Meanwhile, the market is hitting record after record and we're in unchartered territory once again. And it's apparently based on fundamentals. We don't have a health care solution yet, we don't have tax reform yet, and yet this market is at all-time high.

BLOCK: Yes. And, you know, what I'm saying here shouldn't stop anybody. But at the same time, at some point, things are going to come along. Look in 2005 and '06, there were -- there were folks who were short in financial stocks. Do you know what that's called? That's called early and that's also called wrong. So, saying the sky is falling right now and getting short right now, probably the wrong decision but we'll see.

MCDOWELL: And be careful what you wish because some of that -- what if the Congress passes some kind of nauseating health care reform that doesn't really do a whole lot, like this market selloff because of that. If the Trump administration rolls out higher taxes on wealthier Americans, does that hurt the market rather than help it?

BARTIROMO: Would he do that after all of those promises to take taxes down and the biggest tax cut ever in history?

MCDOWELL: Well, I think we learned yesterday with the announcement on transgender individuals in the military that he just like all politicians, backs away from promises made on the campaign trail.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll take a quick break. And then there's Julio, Julio Jones that would be, pulls out all the stops to find an earring worth $150,000 that he lost in a lake. The extreme measures the Atlanta Falcons player took to find the missing jewelry, next. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. It was a big night last night for the U.S. men's national soccer team. Jared max with all the details -- Jared.

MAX: Hey, good morning, Maria. While the San Francisco 49ers will hold their first practice at training camp tomorrow, last night their home, Levis Stadium was a football stadium as in soccer. Over 63,000 squeezed into Levi's for the Gold's Cup final against Jamaica, scoreless 45th minute of this match until a free kick attempt by Jozy Altidore, a gorgeous goal from 28 yards out, 1-0 USA.

Now, Jamaica leader tied the match so it was 1-1 until the 88th minute when American Jordan Morris scores the go-ahead goal and the United States wins the match 2-1 against Jamaica. First title in four years for team USA in the sixth CONCACAF Gold Cup title, one behind Mexico for the all-time lead.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOZY ALTIDORE, FORWARD, TORONTO FOOTBALL CLUB: It means a lot. You know, obviously everybody knows there's no secret, I haven't had the best luck when it comes to playing international tournaments. So, this meant a lot to me, to be out here and to be in this moment, a great atmosphere and it's to play a part in the game, and to have cup this -- to have this cup, it means everything.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Yes. In the last match he had been bitten by another player. A question, how quickly do you think you could run around the bases on a Major League diamond? I know some snakes move fast but watch how quickly Diamondback shortstop Ketel Marte did it last night. He's got to go 90 feet to first, 90 more to second, another 90 to third, and 90 more feet home, all after hitting a baseball 360 feet, 120 yards, two run inside-the- park home run completed in under 15 seconds. The Diamondbacks blasted the Braves, 10-3.

And the Texas Rangers 22-10 loss to Miami Marlins, Adrian Beltre of the Texas Rangers was hanging out behind home plate. You see him back there on left side. It only was supposed to be in the on deck circle. So, the second base umpire Jerry Davidson says go back where you belong, and instead, Adrian Beltre says we'll circle back to that. He takes the on deck curcle and brings it toward home plate, and for that, the guy who is now four hits away from 3,000 was ejected last night from the game.

BARTIROMO: Wow. Oh, my god.

MAX: Shenanigans on the baseball diamond, Maria.

MCDOWELL: I like -- I like how we're making -- make -- paying attention to, oh, you see a baseball player running fast. We're just not used to see it. Oh, there are actual athletes who play professional baseball.

MAX: After hitting -- I mean, that's really quick. I was right on the base on the Yankee Stadium, I nearly died by third base, seriously.

MCDOWELL: You don't get paid seven figures to basically --

MAX: No, but I mean I'm not a complete (INAUDIBLE) you know, I mean, thought I could move around a little bit.

MCDOWELL: No, I'm just saying the baseball players get a free pass about their fitness level, generally.

BARTIROMO: Should we talk -- wait, should we talk about the big -- who they're calling big spender this morning? Atlanta Falcons wide receiver Julio Jones hires an entire dive team, all the divers went in the water to look for a $150,000 earring. Jones lost the earing while he was riding a jet ski. Unfortunately, the dive team has still not located the missing piece of jewelry. What do you make of it?

ORTAGUS: Wait, they were his earrings?

BARTIROMO: It was his earrings.

ORTAGUS: I thought maybe it was his girlfriend's --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: He lost it on the jet ski.

ORTAGUS: How big could his earrings be?

MCDOWELL: And how do you see $150,000.

BARTIROMO: Are they really going to find one stud of a diamond in the bottom of the ocean? Come on.

MAX: There's trees down there, too, they're trying to find them through. Not for nothing, but how dumb can you be to take $150,000 piece of jewelry in the water.

BARTIROMO: When you go jet skiing.

MAX: Going jet skiing.

BARTIROMO: No, Jared, he's got it on, he's wearing it, he's not going to take off his jewelry when he goes on the jet ski. You have it on, you have it on.

(CROSSTALK)

MAX: Oh, I disagree.

ORTAGUS: But the divers didn't have him cost a lot.

MAX: I used to have a family heirloom, a piece of jewelry that my grandparents had, and the only time I would ever take it off would be when I go to the beach. So, you know and that thing wasn't worth $150,000.

BARTIROMO: Wow. All right. Well, good point. Jared, thank you.

ORTAGUS: Good luck finding it.

MAX: Good price to pay.

BARTIROMO: Catch Jared's sports reports on Fox News headlines 24/7, Sirius XM 115. Don't miss my interview with Pro-football hall of famer president, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for being here. Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, July 27th. Your top stories right now 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast. There's an earnings blip on Wall Street today. This is the --

END

urn:contentItem:5W2T-RYR1-DY0W-41CY-00000-00Earnings Blitz; Tax Reform Push; Uranium One Deal Questions; Courting Amazon; Saudi Investment Conference; Tech Stocks Retreat; Aramaco2017-10-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:29ZLexisNexisEarnings Blitz; Tax Reform Push; Uranium One Deal Questions; Courting Amazon; Saudi Investment Conference; Tech Stocks Retreat; AramacoLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Thanks so much for joining us. It is Tuesday, October 24th. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings splits on Wall Street, among the big names set to report earnings this morning, General Motors, Caterpillar, McDonald's, and United Technologies. We are bringing you all of the numbers as soon as they hit the tape and we will have the analysis as they come in. What do the numbers mean to you?

Futures meanwhile showing the markets are looking higher this morning, take a look at what we've got, this momentum lives on. DOW Industrial set to open up about 45 points today, Nasdaq, S&P500 also in positive territory.

In Europe, a bit of a different story, stocks are searching for some direction this morning. Take a look at the euro zone where the FTSE100 is up just a fraction and the CAC Krones and the DAX Index are up just about a quarter of a percent or so.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly higher as you'll see taking at cue once again. From the U.S., the Shanghai Composite, the Nikkei Average and the Kospi all fractionally better on the session. The Hang Seng lower by half a percent.

Well the Saudi Aramco IPO is on track apparently, the public investment fund managing director giving some hopes to big investors saying that the oil giant's public debut is still on schedule for next year despite the speculation that we are going to see some private investors getting on this deal like the Chinese which may very well still be likely.

The push for tax reform is on back in the U.S., President Trump set to head to Capitol Hill today again to something of a pep talk to encourage republican senators to move forward on tax reform.

First daughter, Ivanka Trump spoke about the importance of getting that reform passed, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

IVANKA TRUMP, FIRST DAUGHTER: The tax reform is so critical. We're doing it administratively deregulation. Really fueling entrepreneurship in this country and you see it in terms of optimism, you see it in terms of the stock market.

I would hear it in every conversation I had with the people through the course of the day and in the room. So that's what fuels us and that's what we're fighting for.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

The very latest as the House prepares to vote on that budget later this week which will move the process forward.

Uranium One, well the deal in question. The House is investigating reports this morning that an FBI informant was blocked by Obama Era Attorney General Loretta Lynch from testifying on information that Russian nuclear officials were involved in fraudulent dealings back in 2009. Why he was reportedly threatened with criminal action, we are on it this morning.

And then the quest for Amazon, the technology giant has already received 238 bids from cities hoping, looking to host the company's second U.S. headquarters. The details on who has the inside track coming up.

But first, I'm coming to you live this morning from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. We are at the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh this morning, 2,500 delegates are here all looking to get a piece of this action.

There is something of a revolution going on in Saudi Arabia right now. They are starting from scratch hoping to build industries from tourism to medical devices, to all sorts of things that people want.

Basically every weekend lot of Saudis leave this area and go elsewhere to have some entertainment. They go to Dubai, they go to Qatar, other places other than Saudi Arabia. Now, the leadership here is saying, "We want our people to spend their money here and we want foreign investments already."

So you're looking at an environment right now where you've got the titans of business here on the ground in Riyadh hoping to get a piece of this buildup. Buildup in infrastructure, buildup in medical technologies, buildup in tourism.

The area is absolutely beautiful, they are creating a new city which is going to be on the border of Egypt and Jordan right on the water and they're hoping to put hotels, really a change in terms of culture and a change in terms of perception.

That's why we're here today, we're getting an inside look at what's happening, and certainly all of the names that we will be speaking with today are going to tell us what specifically to expect as this country goes through dramatic change in the next five years.

We'll tell you all about it in the program this morning. Coming up, I'll be talking with the chairman of the country's sovereign wealth fund, the public investment fund, his royal highness Prince Mohammed bin Salman al- Saud.

I will speak with the crown prince, I've spent some time with him yesterday as he explained what is taking place. His royal highness has a vision, of course, blessed by the king of Saudi Arabia and they are putting that vision to work. That is why it has attracted so many dignitaries and delegates from around the world here this week.

I'm also speaking with Former Chairman and CEO of Arconic, Klaus Kleinfeld, he is going to be joining me on stage along with the Chairman and CEO of Softbank, Masayoshi Son, he is going to, of course, talk about he's allocating capital. He's got that $100 billion vision fund, everybody wants to get some investment from that vision fund.

He's going to talk to us about why it is so important to invest here. The Saudis gave him $45 billion as part of that $100 billion vision fund.

Also here the Blackstone Chairman and CEO, Stephen Schwarzman, he's going to join me coming up as well. He's on stage with me coming up along with Boston Dynamic CEO, Marc Raibert.

Raibert is basically talking about robotics, they're going to get robotics, drone, the whole host of new innovative technologies working on the ground here in Saudi. So we're going to hear about all the investment opportunities from this group coming up when I sit down with them on stage momentarily.

We will bring you that conference live as it happens.

First though, joining me from New York this morning, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Kelly and Company Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly. And TheBlaze TV Host, Lawrence Jones. Great to see everybody.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Great to see you Maria.

LAWRENCE JONES, THEBLAZE TV HOST: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: You look fantastic as always.

BARTIROMO: Dagen, incredible. I mean markets, here we are in Saudi Arabia, you can't believe the number of people here trying to get a piece of the action basically because they're starting from scratch.

This is a completely changed idea in terms of what Saudi has been, a close society, they're trying to hard to open it. Question is, are they moving too fast? Will it be able to change the perception and get foreign money coming into the country?

MCDOWELL: Right. There's a front page article in "The Wall Street Journal" about that very thing today Maria. It's so amazing that you're there that this is such a huge shift in terms of moving from investment fund if you will that invested in the Saudi Arabia and economy.

Investing in only domestic interest say banks, even a fish farm at one point but now trying to shift from being solely dependent on oil to technology investment. And the "Journal" points out that $3.5 billion investment in Uber sometime last year that didn't go that well with the ouster of the CEO of that company recently.

But I think that the amount of money at stake and the number of attendees at this conference, it's proof of how much money Saudi Arabia is going to be investing for decades to come.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're absolutely right. And you know, the Saudis gave Softbank $45 billion Kevin Kelly of that $100 billion vision fund. Don't forget, Alibaba was a big portion of the performance of that fund.

So are there other Alibaba's out there Kevin in terms of really hitting it big to keep up that incredible performance of the vision fund?

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: What I think is pretty interesting and unique is that most sovereign wealth funds or public investment funds they actually go very safe and conservative route.

They have a lot of stocks, a lot of stocks, a lot of bonds, if you look at another one that's Norway, they are very conservative. They have almost $1 trillion. And so this shows you the different tech that you need to do in today's environment.

And the Saudis are leading that, right? They're getting into venture capital, they're getting on the edge of technology which is so important today because we have such a dynamic shift that's happening in the marketplace.

And I think it's important to note that this is a smart move. Back in 2015 they realized they needed to cut their dependency on oil. And so for 40 years they were solely focused on it. So it 2015 they got aggressive and they got smart and the decided to diversify.

And that's what they need to do. So we'll have to see, there is another Alibaba out there, can they do it with Softbank? You know what, if history is any guide, they're going to have a good chance.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well can we talk about tech for a second guys? I mean what's going on with this rollover? We saw the worst week since around the election for stocks like Google, Alphabet, as parents of Google, Amazon.

Going into these earnings, Amazon and Alphabet earnings, these stocks are really rolling over. What's going on with the broader market trading up and technology trading down?

KELLY: I think you're seeing a sector rotation and it's natural. I mean the market is up pretty significantly for the year and technology has led that. So people are getting into other areas of the market.

Financials actually took that leadership after they had a great earning season but it's also important to note that there's a lot of regulatory risk on the horizons for these technology companies.

When you started to see at Facebook, a lot of the Russian ads came in due effect, there's talk about Amazon and whether they need to be broken up. I mean we didn't hear that before and that actually weighed on big tech titans like IBM in the '60s as well as Microsoft back in the late '90s.

So this is pretty telling. The regulatory effects is actually what's worrying investors right now for putting new capital to work.

MCDOWELL: Maria, real quick in terms of earnings one thing to watch which dovetails with where you are and the upcoming Aramco IPO that the energy sector for the third quarter is trending up the most in terms of earnings growth.

Earnings are expected to be up 136 percent from one year ago. This is the energy sector in the United States, that's up from 129 percent growth just one month ago. So a big rebound for energy earnings and expectations are going up as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. Wow. One of the biggest headlines to come out of this conference so far was that Saudi ARamco IPO was actually on track.

We think it's going to be one of the most impactful and then profitable technology revolution that the world has ever seen.

BARTIROMO: Fascinating stuff. Seth, thank so much for sharing.

BANNON: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you, sir. Thank you so much, Seth Bannon, joining us there. Coming up, I will have much more live from the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. I'll be talking with the Chairman of the country's Sovereign Wealth Fund, the Public Investment Fund, his Royal Highness, the Crown Prince, Mohammad bin Salman al-Saud, will join me on stage along with Steve Schwartzman, and Masayoshi Son from Softbank, we will talk about the new ambitious plans coming out of Saudi Arabia coming up next, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: Live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative, here's Maria Bartiromo with the special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

BARTIROMO: Good Tuesday morning, everybody, welcome back! Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Tuesday, October 24th. Your top stories right now 7:00 a.m. on the east coast. Earnings split on Wall Street. Big week for third-quarter earnings; among the big names set to report this morning: General Motors, Caterpillar, McDonald's. This will likely set the tone for the markets. United Technologies just hit the tape moments ago; both earnings and revenue topped expectation. We're going to check the stock right here. And as you can see, it is at 120.89. We will tell you what it's doing in premarket momentarily. Futures indicating a pretty good rally at the start of trading today. We've got the momentum for stocks and that continues. Dow Industrials up 60 points right now; NASDAQ, S&P500 also in positive territory.

END

urn:contentItem:5PT9-T9G1-DY0W-443G-00000-00Earnings Blitz; Tax Reform Push; Uranium One Deal Questions; Courting Amazon; Saudi Investment Conference; Tech Stocks Retreat; Aramaco2017-10-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:29ZLexisNexisEarnings Blitz; Tax Reform Push; Uranium One Deal Questions; Courting Amazon; Saudi Investment Conference; Tech Stocks Retreat; AramacoLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Thanks so much for joining us. It is Tuesday, October 24th. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings splits on Wall Street, among the big names set to report earnings this morning, General Motors, Caterpillar, McDonald's, and United Technologies. We are bringing you all of the numbers as soon as they hit the tape and we will have the analysis as they come in. What do the numbers mean to you?

Futures meanwhile showing the markets are looking higher this morning, take a look at what we've got, this momentum lives on. DOW Industrial set to open up about 45 points today, Nasdaq, S&P500 also in positive territory.

In Europe, a bit of a different story, stocks are searching for some direction this morning. Take a look at the euro zone where the FTSE100 is up just a fraction and the CAC Krones and the DAX Index are up just about a quarter of a percent or so.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly higher as you'll see taking at cue once again. From the U.S., the Shanghai Composite, the Nikkei Average and the Kospi all fractionally better on the session. The Hang Seng lower by half a percent.

Well the Saudi Aramco IPO is on track apparently, the public investment fund managing director giving some hopes to big investors saying that the oil giant's public debut is still on schedule for next year despite the speculation that we are going to see some private investors getting on this deal like the Chinese which may very well still be likely.

The push for tax reform is on back in the U.S., President Trump set to head to Capitol Hill today again to something of a pep talk to encourage republican senators to move forward on tax reform.

First daughter, Ivanka Trump spoke about the importance of getting that reform passed, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

IVANKA TRUMP, FIRST DAUGHTER: The tax reform is so critical. We're doing it administratively deregulation. Really fueling entrepreneurship in this country and you see it in terms of optimism, you see it in terms of the stock market.

I would hear it in every conversation I had with the people through the course of the day and in the room. So that's what fuels us and that's what we're fighting for.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

The very latest as the House prepares to vote on that budget later this week which will move the process forward.

Uranium One, well the deal in question. The House is investigating reports this morning that an FBI informant was blocked by Obama Era Attorney General Loretta Lynch from testifying on information that Russian nuclear officials were involved in fraudulent dealings back in 2009. Why he was reportedly threatened with criminal action, we are on it this morning.

And then the quest for Amazon, the technology giant has already received 238 bids from cities hoping, looking to host the company's second U.S. headquarters. The details on who has the inside track coming up.

But first, I'm coming to you live this morning from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. We are at the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh this morning, 2,500 delegates are here all looking to get a piece of this action.

There is something of a revolution going on in Saudi Arabia right now. They are starting from scratch hoping to build industries from tourism to medical devices, to all sorts of things that people want.

Basically every weekend lot of Saudis leave this area and go elsewhere to have some entertainment. They go to Dubai, they go to Qatar, other places other than Saudi Arabia. Now, the leadership here is saying, "We want our people to spend their money here and we want foreign investments already."

So you're looking at an environment right now where you've got the titans of business here on the ground in Riyadh hoping to get a piece of this buildup. Buildup in infrastructure, buildup in medical technologies, buildup in tourism.

The area is absolutely beautiful, they are creating a new city which is going to be on the border of Egypt and Jordan right on the water and they're hoping to put hotels, really a change in terms of culture and a change in terms of perception.

That's why we're here today, we're getting an inside look at what's happening, and certainly all of the names that we will be speaking with today are going to tell us what specifically to expect as this country goes through dramatic change in the next five years.

We'll tell you all about it in the program this morning. Coming up, I'll be talking with the chairman of the country's sovereign wealth fund, the public investment fund, his royal highness Prince Mohammed bin Salman al- Saud.

I will speak with the crown prince, I've spent some time with him yesterday as he explained what is taking place. His royal highness has a vision, of course, blessed by the king of Saudi Arabia and they are putting that vision to work. That is why it has attracted so many dignitaries and delegates from around the world here this week.

I'm also speaking with Former Chairman and CEO of Arconic, Klaus Kleinfeld, he is going to be joining me on stage along with the Chairman and CEO of Softbank, Masayoshi Son, he is going to, of course, talk about he's allocating capital. He's got that $100 billion vision fund, everybody wants to get some investment from that vision fund.

He's going to talk to us about why it is so important to invest here. The Saudis gave him $45 billion as part of that $100 billion vision fund.

Also here the Blackstone Chairman and CEO, Stephen Schwarzman, he's going to join me coming up as well. He's on stage with me coming up along with Boston Dynamic CEO, Marc Raibert.

Raibert is basically talking about robotics, they're going to get robotics, drone, the whole host of new innovative technologies working on the ground here in Saudi. So we're going to hear about all the investment opportunities from this group coming up when I sit down with them on stage momentarily.

We will bring you that conference live as it happens.

First though, joining me from New York this morning, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Kelly and Company Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly. And TheBlaze TV Host, Lawrence Jones. Great to see everybody.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Great to see you Maria.

LAWRENCE JONES, THEBLAZE TV HOST: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: You look fantastic as always.

BARTIROMO: Dagen, incredible. I mean markets, here we are in Saudi Arabia, you can't believe the number of people here trying to get a piece of the action basically because they're starting from scratch.

This is a completely changed idea in terms of what Saudi has been, a close society, they're trying to hard to open it. Question is, are they moving too fast? Will it be able to change the perception and get foreign money coming into the country?

MCDOWELL: Right. There's a front page article in "The Wall Street Journal" about that very thing today Maria. It's so amazing that you're there that this is such a huge shift in terms of moving from investment fund if you will that invested in the Saudi Arabia and economy.

Investing in only domestic interest say banks, even a fish farm at one point but now trying to shift from being solely dependent on oil to technology investment. And the "Journal" points out that $3.5 billion investment in Uber sometime last year that didn't go that well with the ouster of the CEO of that company recently.

But I think that the amount of money at stake and the number of attendees at this conference, it's proof of how much money Saudi Arabia is going to be investing for decades to come.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're absolutely right. And you know, the Saudis gave Softbank $45 billion Kevin Kelly of that $100 billion vision fund. Don't forget, Alibaba was a big portion of the performance of that fund.

So are there other Alibaba's out there Kevin in terms of really hitting it big to keep up that incredible performance of the vision fund?

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: What I think is pretty interesting and unique is that most sovereign wealth funds or public investment funds they actually go very safe and conservative route.

They have a lot of stocks, a lot of stocks, a lot of bonds, if you look at another one that's Norway, they are very conservative. They have almost $1 trillion. And so this shows you the different tech that you need to do in today's environment.

And the Saudis are leading that, right? They're getting into venture capital, they're getting on the edge of technology which is so important today because we have such a dynamic shift that's happening in the marketplace.

And I think it's important to note that this is a smart move. Back in 2015 they realized they needed to cut their dependency on oil. And so for 40 years they were solely focused on it. So it 2015 they got aggressive and they got smart and the decided to diversify.

And that's what they need to do. So we'll have to see, there is another Alibaba out there, can they do it with Softbank? You know what, if history is any guide, they're going to have a good chance.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well can we talk about tech for a second guys? I mean what's going on with this rollover? We saw the worst week since around the election for stocks like Google, Alphabet, as parents of Google, Amazon.

Going into these earnings, Amazon and Alphabet earnings, these stocks are really rolling over. What's going on with the broader market trading up and technology trading down?

KELLY: I think you're seeing a sector rotation and it's natural. I mean the market is up pretty significantly for the year and technology has led that. So people are getting into other areas of the market.

Financials actually took that leadership after they had a great earning season but it's also important to note that there's a lot of regulatory risk on the horizons for these technology companies.

When you started to see at Facebook, a lot of the Russian ads came in due effect, there's talk about Amazon and whether they need to be broken up. I mean we didn't hear that before and that actually weighed on big tech titans like IBM in the '60s as well as Microsoft back in the late '90s.

So this is pretty telling. The regulatory effects is actually what's worrying investors right now for putting new capital to work.

MCDOWELL: Maria, real quick in terms of earnings one thing to watch which dovetails with where you are and the upcoming Aramco IPO that the energy sector for the third quarter is trending up the most in terms of earnings growth.

Earnings are expected to be up 136 percent from one year ago. This is the energy sector in the United States, that's up from 129 percent growth just one month ago. So a big rebound for energy earnings and expectations are going up as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. Wow. One of the biggest headlines to come out of this conference so far was that Saudi ARamco IPO was actually on track.

So the public investment funds managing director, the oil giant's public debut he said is still on schedule for the second half of the year, this sovereign wealth fund is going to become one of the world's largest investors.

And you said the "Journal" story today points out that the fund already had some trouble in terms of lack (INAUDIBLE) or performances like Uber. So you've got Uber there, you've got this fund looking for the big highlights in terms of where the growth comes from next.

They are all setting their sites on innovation, technology, things like drones. Lawrence Jones, what's on your radar this morning?

JONES: When I look at what's on my radar, it's this stuff with Russia considering that the Clintons had something going on that the Congress did not know about that the FBI knew about it and now they're trying to conduct and investigation.

But we did not know. So that's problematic for me. I'm interested to see what's going to come out of it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we're going to have more on that coming up on the program. As you know, I interviewed John Podesta about this very subject a long time ago. And so we pointed out that there's something about Russia and the democrats to talk about.

Not necessarily this administration and the Russians but we're investigating both sides of it, so we'll come up -- come back with more on that coming up.

Meanwhile, a lot of earnings on the table, that's going to set the tone for markets today as soon. As soon as those numbers come out, we're going to bring them to you and, of course, there's all this anticipation about the tech earnings after the bell.

We'll take a short break. When we come back, Uranium One deal in question, the House investigating reports that an FBI informant was blocked from testifying on information that Russian nuclear officials were involved in fraudulent deals back in 2009 under Hillary Clinton's watch as she was Secretary of the State.

And then let the games begin, from Coast-to-Coast, from cities big and small, find out just how many cities are battling and trying to get Amazon's attention for Amazon's new headquarters.

All that coming right here live from Riyadh and New York this Tuesday morning.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Tuesday morning. Welcome back everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo coming to you live this morning from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

President Trump is set to announce today a title cap on the number of refugees entering the United States. Cheryl Casone on headlines right now with details. Cheryl, good morning to you.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: And good morning Maria. So under these new rules the U.S. would limit refugee admissions to 45,000 down from 110,000.

The president also expected to call for tougher vetting rules. This comes as the Trump Administration's 120 day refugee ban actually expires today.

Programming note for all of you, President Trump is going to be "Lou Dobbs Tonight" for an exclusive interview. That is tomorrow, 7:00p.m. Eastern Time right here on the FOX Business Network, don't miss that interview.

Well, Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson is in Pakistan today. He told reporters he's going to pressure Pakistani leaders to stop the support of the Taliban and other terrorist groups that they receive in that country.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REX TILLERSON, SECRETARY OF STATE: We have made some very specific request at Pakistan, this is the conditions-based approach. And so our relationship with Pakistan will also be conditions-based.

It will be based upon whether they take action that we feel is necessary. The Pakistan needs I think take a clear eye view of the situation that they're confronted with in terms of the number of terrorist organizations that find safe haven inside of Pakistan.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: We should add that Pakistan still denies providing a safe haven for terrorists.

Well, Amazon says 238 cities and regions have submitted bids for its second headquarters. The cities include New York, Boston, Atlanta, Nashville, Tennessee, even Austin, Texas. And get this, Puerto Rico. Amazon says it's going to make a decision on the location at some point next year.

Now technology stocks have been sinking ahead of Amazon's earnings. Those earnings due out Thursday after the bell. Of course, we're going to have them for you on FOX Business.

And Delta Airlines is putting up the help wanted sign. The carrier looking to hire about a thousand flight attendants for next year and there is no shortage of applicants, 125,000 applications have been received so far. Delta shares about eight percent for 2017.

Also Delta is ditching Microsoft in favor of Apple. A technology website is reporting that Delta's only 30,000 crew members are going to get iPad and iPhones reversing a deal with Microsoft that the carrier had announced just four years ago.

iPads in the cockpit, I don't know Maria. And those are your headlines from New York. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much Cheryl. We are looking at this market, really continue the momentum. Dagen, Lawrence, Kevin, what is it going to do at this point given that we still haven't seen the policy but it feels like the president is trying to move up the tax reform deadline. How do you see it?

MCDOWELL: I think that this market does hinge on what comes out of Washington at this point because of the continued run with stocks closing at all time highs on Friday but DOW, Nasdaq, and the S&P500.

I think that one thing that people aren't factoring in, the possibility of the new Federal Reserve chief that because, again, as you have a Fed that is tightening monetary policy with higher rates but also I'm trying to unwind or begin to unwind that is $4.5 trillion balanced sheet.

They hear a lot of unknowns in there that people are not really facing at this point and then you have like foul ups like that 401K contribution limit that the GOP was talking about dramatically cutting and then President Trump had to come out and say, "No" and put the icksnay on that. So I think that there's a lot of room for error.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You know what, you make a real -- incredible points that you're making. In terms of the Fed chairman, when I spoke with the president at the end of last week, he basically narrowed it down, right?

He narrowed it down to two players as well as Janet Yellen. He talked about Jay Powell and he talked about John Taylor. It looks like those are the two favorite picks.

KELLY: Maria, and I think one thing that came really across well in that interview is that that was very presidential of Donald Trump to give kudos to Janet Yellen and say that he likes her.

I mean she is the sitting Fed chairman and that's very important because you want a nice continuity. So should he not pick her, at least it was a great signal to the market and I think that's why you saw the market not selloff.

But when we were talking about the markets, I mean I don't think tax reform is as important. And one of the reasons why we're seeing in the earnings cycle, people are talking about how global growth is doing.

Well look at the price of copper, it's over $7,000 a ton. It's almost near its 20 -- late 2013 peak of $7,430. That's showing the global growth is strong and these companies are benefiting from it. Should we get tax reform? It's icing on the cake.

JONES: But Maria, I do think that people are --

BARTIROMO: Yes, I think this is a great point. Yes.

JONES: Yes. Maria, I think people in the markets are optimistic about tax reform but I think all eyes are on the city. Remember, 200 bills passed about the House that have died of (INAUDIBLE) in the Senate.

So a lot of people are worrying when it comes to the Senate. But Americans in the markets are optimistic that we could get something done. I mean this is something that democrats and republicans should be able to agree on and it only strengthens the market when they see Washington working together.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You would think so. And he made the point of saying Rand Paul will vote yes for tax reform. He's focused on the Senate for sure.

All right. We are live form Riyadh this morning. Let me take a short break and come right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. It's Tuesday morning everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo coming to you live this morning from the Future Investment Initiative Conference in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

We are looking at markets which are trading higher this morning. Plus, new allegations this morning of collusion between Russia and the Clintons. The House Oversight Committee is now investigating an Obama Era deal in which a Russian-backed company bought a uranium firm with mines in the United States.

The former FBI informant who could offer more details about the deal, well he's under a gag order apparently that prevents him from testifying before the Congress. The informant's lawyer question the legality of the order on "Lou Dobb's" program last night, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

VICTORIA TOENSING, LAWYER: If it does and it is unconstitutional and it's invalid if it prohibits my client from giving information to the legislature. The executive cannot say to people, "Hey, you can't give information to another body of the government."

So you can tell what all the Russians were talking about during the time that all this bribery payments were made.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And then, of course, there's House Oversight Committee Member, Florida Congressman Ron DeSantis, he appeared on FOX News over the weekend, he calls for the Justice Department to remove the nondisclosure agreement which prevents the former informant from testifying about the bribery scheme before Congress.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RON DESANTIS (R-FL), HOUSE OVERSIGHT COMMITTEE MEMBER: This informant wants to tell his story but he's currently under a nondisclosure agreement that was signed with the (INAUDIBLE) Justice Department.

He came forward in 2016, was threatened with reprisal from the Loretta Lynch Justice Department. Clearly it's in the interest, in the public's interest that this individual be able to tell the story to congress.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, during my exclusive interview at the end of last week with President Trump, he told me that Special Counsel Robert Mueller should stop probing the Uranium One deal.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The uranium situation with Russia getting uranium, they better look into that. That is looking like a very serious situation.

BARTIROMO: Is he going to look into it?

TRUMP: I don't know. I mean, I don't know. That's up to them but I can tell you Senator Grassley wants to look into it and others do but that's to me a very, very serious charge.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So Lawrence Jones, let's talk about this for a second because for years before the Clinton State Department, for years the Russians wanted to buy uranium. Let's just call this what it is. Uranium is used to make a nuclear bomb.

JONES: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: So they wanted to buy uranium. They wanted to buy uranium and president after president said, "No, no, no, no, no, no we're not going to sell our uranium."

All of a sudden under Hillary Clinton State Department, she --

JONES: A deal was cut.

BARTIROMO: -- approves 20 percent of the U.S.'s stock pile of uranium and then she gets $140 million sent to her Clinton Foundation?

JONES: A lot of shady business. Now, we don't know if there was evidence of wrong doing but there's a lot of smoke there that should have been investigated.

And I think it's particularly concerning Maria that Congress didn't know anything about this but a lot of people within the department for eight years knew this was going on and didn't report. We've had leaks on everything else and here was no leaks on this particular problem.

What we didn't know after looking into this when it come -- concerning this whole uranium thing is that Obama knew as well. He knew this and still didn't tell Congress ,didn't notify the proper channels in this until I think that's problematic.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well it looks like a quid quo pro going on and she's getting all that money. She sells the uranium. And by the way, we should point out that the company that bought the uranium is Kremlin backed. I mean this was a government backed company that wanted the uranium.

JONES: That's correct. And we also know now Maria because of more investigation that the Russians were also trying to influence Hillary Clinton as well. That's more developments that we got out of this particular story particularly from the Hill.

So now we know that it wasn't just Donald Trump that all these players were trying to influence, it was everyone.

BARTIROMO: Well, we also should point out that around that same time Bill Clinton, Former President Clinton was getting paid, what, $500,000 for a speech in Moscow?

JONES: Which they did not disclose.

BARTIROMO: And he was getting other money. Yes.

JONES: Exactly. Which they did not dis --

BARTIROMO: Separating apart from the $140 million.

JONES: Correct Maria. And remember, they had an agreement when this first started that they were supposed to notify the Obama Administration to prevent this type of wrong doing from happening. And it looks like they knew and didn't say anything.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All of this exchange of money and yet we're still talking about potential collusion with the Trump Administration, incredible.

All right. We will keep following that for you. We're going to take a short break. When we come back, is it a Snap flop? Snap's vision for spectacles not so clear. We will tell you about that.

And then the fall classic may have to get a new name this year. Why the world series maybe hotter than ever but not for the reason that you think. We're on it, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: Here again is Maria Bartiromo with a special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA, live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative.

BARTIROMO: Good Tuesday morning, everybody! Thanks so much for joining us. Welcome back! We are live this morning, it is Tuesday, October 24th, we're coming to you from Riyadh. Your top stories right now 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast. And earnings (INAUDIBLE) and starts on Wall Street this morning.

We've got General Motors, Caterpillar, McDonald's, United Technology, just a few of the names due out before the opening bell -- that is what's going to set the tone for markets today. We'll have the numbers as soon as they hit the tape. Eli Lili just reported minutes ago; the company beat expectation on both earnings and revenue. Take a look at the shares, Eli Lili now at 87 and change.

Earnings expected to drive markets today. Futures are pointing higher today, got a pretty good, firmer tone this morning on Wall Street. Take a look, we're at the highs of the morning right here; Dow Industrials set to open about 55 points -- that's a quarter of a percent higher. NASDAQ, S&P500 also higher this morning, as you see there.

In Europe, stocks are searching for direction. In fact, the FTSE100 is not so far away from breaking even right now. Take a look at European indices with the FTSE up five points; the CAC Quarante is up a third of a percent, 16 points higher; and Dax Index in Germany, up 24 right now. In Asia overnight, markets closed mostly higher, as you will here. Best performer overnight was the Nikkei Average, up half-of-a-percent in Japan. Some real momentum going on in Japan, recently. Shanghai Composite up a quarter-of- a-percent as well.

Tackling tax reform; that is the focus in the U.S. President Trump is taking his tax cut quest to Capitol Hill today, with something of a pep talk to Republican Senators. He talked about the chances of getting through during my one-on-one exclusive interview just this week.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think we have the votes. We have tremendous enthusiasm this time. Healthcare, I was told it was tougher, but it was close. I mean, so far, I would say it's not even a contest.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're going to break down the timeline for tax reform; it could happen sooner than you think. We'll tell you what we know now.

Plus, reducing the reach: Facebook is testing a new feature that would split its news feed varying publishers that don't pay up. The social media giant's response to the controversy this morning, coming up.

And not sorry, Ms. Jackson; why the NFL is denying that the lead band, Janet Jackson, amid backlash over Justin Timberlake upcoming Super Bowl half-time show. Remember the wardrobe malfunction a couple years ago? All right. We'll get into it.

Plus, the World Series; the hottest men ticking in town, literally. Tonight's game, one could be the hottest start to the fall classic you've ever seen. We will have a preview of Astros-Dodgers showdown in Los Angeles, coming up this morning.

But, first, I am coming to you live this morning from the Future Investment Initiative in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Among the big names I'll be speaking with, coming up this morning: The Chairman of the Country's Sovereign Wealth Fund, the Public Investment Fund, the PIF, his royal highness, Prince Mohammad bin Salman al-Saud, is with me. I met with his royal highness yesterday and he explained to me what the goal is, how they are trying to get new money into the country and create some of a tourist spot in Saudi Arabia. We're going to tell you all about it.

But, first, our top stories right now this half an hour: tax reform on Capitol Hill, President Trump is set to meet with Republican Senators at the weekly public lunch today -- that is the policy lunch. At the top of the agenda, a tax overhaul. This, as Ivanka Trump touted the administration's tax plan during a town hall event last night in Pennsylvania, watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

IVANKA TRUMP, ADVISOR TO PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: This tax reform really couples two things that are really core values as a country which is work and supporting the American family. There are many elements of this tax plan that, I think, are squarely targeted at creating jobs in this country, creating growth in this country, and offering relief to our middle-income families.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now to talk about that and the impact on business, the engineering and infrastructure company AECOM CEO Michael Burke. Michael, it's good to have you on the program today.

MICHAEL BURKE, CEO, AECOM: Great! Thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us. So, I want to ask you, really, why you would come to an investment conference like this. I know that infrastructure is very important all around the world, first, though, you think the big opportunity for infrastructure is in the United States?

BURKE: Sure, the infrastructure opportunity right now is clearly in the United States. And there are many countries around the world, sovereign wealth funds like the kingdom of Saudi Arabia here today that's looking to invest their capital in infrastructure in the United States. But additionally, we are working on infrastructure projects here in the country like the Riyadh Metro System right here.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Now you are -- I want to ask you about that because this is, like, a whole new cultural change that's going on here. But, first, in terms of the U.S., and the tax plan, and infrastructure plan, do you expect -- when I asked the president about this, this week, he said, yes, I'm going to do an infrastructure plan in 2018, you wanted to see it sooner rather than later, obviously?

BURKE: Certainly.

BARTIROMO: But you think it's coming?

BURKE: It's definitely coming. I was hoping for it to come much sooner. I really thought it was going to be the top priority of the administration. We have broad bipartisan support in Washington on both sides of the aisle on Capitol Hill, and we have administrative support. And so, we had really a strong, strong support, and I thought it would've been top of the agenda, but that's not the course that it took.

BARTIROMO: So, where do you see the opportunity in the U.S. in terms of infrastructure, what do you want to see done? I mean, are you talking about roads, bridges, what's the big -- big idea?

BURKE: Yes, transportation is probably the single area that requires the most focus, to reduce the friction on the economy but we also have an outdated water infrastructure system across the country, we have rural broadband that is way behind the urban environment that needs infrastructure support. And I really think the big idea is incenting the private sector to bring these large pools of capital. You hear it here today in Riyadh; there's $22 trillion of assets represented by the people persuaded in this conference that want to invest in infrastructure.

BARTIROMO: So, infrastructure, obviously, important for this administration; what about tax reform? How big of an impact is that going to have on business and on economic growth?

BURKE: Tax reform is critical. As you know, we have the highest corporate tax rate among all the OECD countries, so it's critical to make sure that the U.S. is competitive from a business attractiveness perspective. And ultimately, GDP growth will contribute to infrastructure growth. So, we have to get the economy growing, we need to have a competitive tax rate, and that will produce jobs, produce GDP that will then fund infrastructure.

BARTIROMO: Do you think that they're going to get caught up in the debates or the pushback, like for example on the state and local tax deduction? A lot of people are saying, look, I'm not going to vote, yes, for that, that means a tax increase for some of our constituents. So, is that going to hold up tax reform?

BURKE: It's one of the many challenges of tax reform. And I think right now, we do have both sides of the aisle that are interested in the lower corporate rate, but we need to pay for us. And the state tax deduction is one of those items that are on the table, and somebody's going to have to compromise significantly to get this across the finish line, and I expect they'll get it done by December.

BARTIROMO: All right. Take me to Saudi Arabia, then, tell me what you're doing here, what you want to do here? This is some grand ambitions to turn Saudi Arabia into a tourist spot, open it up to foreign investment, fix in infrastructure or create to infrastructure that doesn't exist right now in some cities, is it doable, can they pull this off?

BURKE: You know, I think they can. You know, it's an exciting time here. They've set forth the long-term 2030 vision, and that's the start of the plan. And they are really focused on diversifying away from oil and they have the right vision, and we're seeing some great ideas and we're working on some great ideas for the country to develop new cities. And they have to have not only a vision, but a real differentiator, and so we're looking at cities that will bring in robotics, and bring in a whole new host of technologies that will differentiate them. We're looking at new cities that will bring entertainment into Riyadh which has long been avoided. And so, it's an exciting time here.

BARTIROMO: It really is. I remember saying earlier that a lot of people, they leave every Friday, they want entertainment, and they go find it; they find it in Dubai and elsewhere. And now, the Saudi leadership is saying, why are we doing this, why are we allowing all of our money to leave?

BURKE: We're seeing it up on the Red Sea. And the Red Sea has beautiful, beautiful beach fronts. And I think these developments will be our aim to keeping Saudis in the country when they want to take holiday.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's an important plan and certainly ambitious. Michael, we'll be watching. Great to have you on the program today.

BURKE: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Michael Burke, joining us there. We'll take a break. When we come back, remember Janet Jackson? There's a new Super Bowl controversy right now. The NFL is issuing a new statement about the superstar, 14 years after that wardrobe malfunction with Justin Timberlake, find out why. And then, hungry for good news? Well, we're keeping an eye on Chipotle as the company reports earnings after the bell tonight. We'll tell you what people are expecting after a tough period for that stock, back in a minute right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back! I'm Maria Bartiromo, thanks for being with us this morning. Happy Tuesday! We are coming to you live today from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Market is looking higher; we're at the highs of the morning right now. Dow Industrials set to open up 60 points; earnings in focus, obviously.

A couple of names we're watching related earnings. We are watching the companies set to report before the open today, 3M, and also looking earnings of 2.21 a share, that, of course, the third-quarter. Shares of 3M are up nearly 25 percent this year.

Also watching shares of Chipotle; the company set to report its third- quarter earnings after the bell tonight. It's had a rough year. Analysts are looking for earnings of $1.63 a share. The stock down better than 20 percent over the last year.

Facebook, meanwhile, downplaying a test on its news feed. You have to hear this one, Cheryl Casone with the details in now New York, Cheryl.

CASONE: It's interesting, Maria, that Facebook test removed page post from the news feed to a separate feed called explore. But it's harder to find, and the move cost a big drop in traffic in six different countries, including Sri Lanka, Bolivia, Slovakia. Facebook said it doesn't plan to expand this test any further for now. So, the test is over. Meanwhile, the company is said it's also experimenting with splitting its news feed in two -- separating commercial posts from the personal news. And its bid to boost advertising from business -- there's the stock in the premarket up slightly.

Snapchat parent company, Snap, reportedly is stuck with hundreds of thousands of unsold spectacles, that's because demand for those spectacles quickly fell after last year's holiday shopping season. Snap also let off about a dozen employees that supported that division that was making the spectacle, that happened just last month. Taking a look at the stock, Snap's down about 40 percent so far since the IPO, 40 percent.

All right, now that Justin Timberlake is performing at Super Bowl, everyone is wondering if Janet Jackson has been banned for making a guest appearance. You know, it's been almost 14 years since that infamous wardrobe malfunction at the 2004 Super Bowl. Well, speculation was rising that the NFL had banned her. The NFL is saying, though, in a statement, nonsense, "There's no ban. We are not going to comment on any speculation regarding potential guests. There may be no guests. Along with Pepsi, we're excited to have Justin Timberlake." Super Bowl 52, set for February 4th, guys, in Minneapolis.

And baseball is hot right now, literally. Los Angeles is in the grips of a heat wave just as world series is getting underway tonight in Los Angeles. Forecasters calling for temperatures to be near 100-degrees at game time. The World Series record, we should add, for the hottest first-pitch temperature was 94-degrees. That was set in Phoenix, Arizona during game one back in 2001, so we shall see. First pitch tonight 8:00 p.m. Eastern Time. And, of course, Maria, the game is going to be on Fox, back to you.

BARTIROMO: Cool, all right, Cheryl, thank you. We'll take a break when we come back, companies such as Memphis Meats, they want to revolutionize the way we eat. The Venture Capital Company, 50 years, wants to revolutionize the way we invest as well over the next 50. Millennials and social investing, that's next, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back! Live from the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia this morning, we're talking about investing globally, doing good in the world, making money in the process, that is the idea behind venture capital firm, 50 Years, which is backing companies that will have global impact for the next 50 years and beyond. Joining us right now for the first time in Fox Business Interview is 50 Years' Founding Partner, Seth Bannon. And Seth, it's good to have you on the program. Thank you so much for joining us.

SETH BANNON, FOUNDING PARTNER, 50 YEARS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We were talking during the commercial break about how millennials don't necessarily care about making money only, they want a purpose, they want to make sure they're doing the right thing. Most people want to make wealth, and then commit to solving the world's problems, why do you think you could do this both?

BANNON: Well, millennials certainly think: you can. So, if you ask any other generation: what is the purpose of business, the vast majority of them would say, some version of to make money -- of course, that's what a job is for. But if you ask millennials this, and (INAUDIBLE) actually did a study of 7,700 millennials across 29 countries, and they asked them the open-ended question: what is the purpose of business?

In a plurality, 47 percent said some version of to improve society or protect the environment. Now, millennials also think that they should make money, but they want to have it all in careers. And so, our fund actually believes that companies, if they want to recruit and retain the top talent of tomorrow, we're going to have to offer millennials what they want, which is to combine their values with their careers.

BARTIROMO: How do you do it? What should we be aware of in terms of doing just that?

BANNON: So, I mean, there's a plethora of problems in the world. And hence, a plethora of ways that you can both make money and do good. So, I think we're facing an incredible climate crisis, we're facing health problems throughout the world, we're failing to feed the world, all of these represent massive, massive industries where you can build business that both make billions of dollars a year, and also do a lot of good in the process.

BARTIROMO: Who's doing it well?

BANNON: Well, I always turn to our own portfolio. One of the companies that have been in the news recently called Memphis Meats, so they essentially produce meats without the animal. And so, you know, it's crazy that in 2017 --

BARTIROMO: Explain how you do that: produce meat without the animal, I don't get it.

BANNON: Yes, so they essentially farm cells directly. So, you can sort of think about it this way: so, a cow is essentially being used as a piece of technology to take plant protein inputs and then convert them into outputs that we like to eat, drink, or wear -- in this case, meat. And inside the cows, there are certain biological processes happening that are causing that transition. And so, the idea of Memphis Meats is what if we took the same biological processes, we'll just bring them outside of the cow so that we can the same delicious we want just without the animals.

BARTIROMO: And we should point out that Richard Branson and Bill Gates have invested in this company, right?

BANNON: They did. And even more interestingly, we think, is Cardio invested in -- it's one of the largest players in conventional meat actually investing in our last round. And the CEO Cargo was on this network, recently, and talked about clean meat as an inevitability, as something that's going to happen -- it'll happen in the next couple of years.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I was laughing when I was looking at some of the research -- well, not laughing, but you're a part of the vegan mafia in Silicon Valley, is that true? Is that what they call it?

BANNON: Yes, exactly, yes. So, the food system is broken from top to bottom. And one of the largest problems is actually animal agriculture itself. So, many people don't know this but animal agriculture contributes more to greenhouse gas emissions than all planes, trains, trucks, boats, and motorcycles combined.

BARTIROMO: No, I didn't know that.

BANNON: That's worse than all the transportation. And it's failing to see the world. And factory farming has reached limits of scale, but it's still not getting people in. So, the vegan mafia believes that there are some interesting solutions in either plant-based alternatives or clean meat or what we call cellular agriculture to actually help solve these problems.

BARTIROMO: What's the next big wave of technology companies that you see taking form in Silicon Valley right now? Is this part of it, do they have the vision to combine profit and social impact, tell us who is hot right now, and where the next wave of growth is?

BANNON: We're very bullish on computational synthetic biology, we're very bullish on space tech, we're bullish on medical devices. Obviously, machine learning is showing its face in every industry. But I would say, the single industry is we're most excited about called Cellular Agriculture, and it's along the same lines. It's essentially a new crop of companies that are making the products that we all love from animals just without the animals.

So, we had personally invested in a company doing it for meat, the company doing it for leather, company doing it for gelatin, company doing it for milk proteins. There are other companies doing it for eggs, for fish, even for spider silk. We think it's going to be one of the most impactful and then profitable technology revolution that the world has ever seen.

BARTIROMO: Fascinating stuff. Seth, thank so much for sharing.

BANNON: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you, sir. Thank you so much, Seth Bannon, joining us there. Coming up, I will have much more live from the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. I'll be talking with the Chairman of the country's Sovereign Wealth Fund, the Public Investment Fund, his Royal Highness, the Crown Prince, Mohammad bin Salman al-Saud, will join me on stage along with Steve Schwartzman, and Masayoshi Son from Softbank, we will talk about the new ambitious plans coming out of Saudi Arabia coming up next, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: Live from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia at the Future Investment Initiative, here's Maria Bartiromo with the special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

BARTIROMO: Good Tuesday morning, everybody, welcome back! Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Tuesday, October 24th. Your top stories right now 7:00 a.m. on the east coast. Earnings split on Wall Street. Big week for third-quarter earnings; among the big names set to report this morning: General Motors, Caterpillar, McDonald's. This will likely set the tone for the markets. United Technologies just hit the tape moments ago; both earnings and revenue topped expectation. We're going to check the stock right here. And as you can see, it is at 120.89. We will tell you what it's doing in premarket momentarily. Futures indicating a pretty good rally at the start of trading today. We've got the momentum for stocks and that continues. Dow Industrials up 60 points right now; NASDAQ, S&P500 also in positive territory.

END

urn:contentItem:5W2T-RYR1-DY0W-41D0-00000-00Earnings Blitz; Tax Reform Push; Uranium One Deal Questions; Courting Amazon; Saudi Investment Conference; Tech Stocks Retreat; Aramaco2017-10-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:30ZLexisNexisEarnings Blitz; Tax Reform Push; Uranium One Deal Questions; Courting Amazon; Saudi Investment Conference; Tech Stocks Retreat; AramacoLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Thanks so much for joining us. It is Tuesday, October 24th. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings splits on Wall Street, among the big names set to report earnings this morning, General Motors, Caterpillar, McDonald's, and United Technologies. We are bringing you all of the numbers as soon as they hit the tape and we will have the analysis as they come in. What do the numbers mean to you?

Futures meanwhile showing the markets are looking higher this morning, take a look at what we've got, this momentum lives on. DOW Industrial set to open up about 45 points today, Nasdaq, S&P500 also in positive territory.

In Europe, a bit of a different story, stocks are searching for some direction this morning. Take a look at the euro zone where the FTSE100 is up just a fraction and the CAC Krones and the DAX Index are up just about a quarter of a percent or so.

In Asia Overnight, markets closed mostly higher as you'll see taking at cue once again. From the U.S., the Shanghai Composite, the Nikkei Average and the Kospi all fractionally better on the session. The Hang Seng lower by half a percent.

Well the Saudi Aramco IPO is on track apparently, the public investment fund managing director giving some hopes to big investors saying that the oil giant's public debut is still on schedule for next year despite the speculation that we are going to see some private investors getting on this deal like the Chinese which may very well still be likely.

The push for tax reform is on back in the U.S., President Trump set to head to Capitol Hill today again to something of a pep talk to encourage republican senators to move forward on tax reform.

First daughter, Ivanka Trump spoke about the importance of getting that reform passed, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

IVANKA TRUMP, FIRST DAUGHTER: The tax reform is so critical. We're doing it administratively deregulation. Really fueling entrepreneurship in this country and you see it in terms of optimism, you see it in terms of the stock market.

I would hear it in every conversation I had with the people through the course of the day and in the room. So that's what fuels us and that's what we're fighting for.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

The very latest as the House prepares to vote on that budget later this week which will move the process forward.

Uranium One, well the deal in question. The House is investigating reports this morning that an FBI informant was blocked by Obama Era Attorney General Loretta Lynch from testifying on information that Russian nuclear officials were involved in fraudulent dealings back in 2009. Why he was reportedly threatened with criminal action, we are on it this morning.

And then the quest for Amazon, the technology giant has already received 238 bids from cities hoping, looking to host the company's second U.S. headquarters. The details on who has the inside track coming up.

But first, I'm coming to you live this morning from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. We are at the Future Investment Initiative here in Riyadh this morning, 2,500 delegates are here all looking to get a piece of this action.

There is something of a revolution going on in Saudi Arabia right now. They are starting from scratch hoping to build industries from tourism to medical devices, to all sorts of things that people want.

Basically every weekend lot of Saudis leave this area and go elsewhere to have some entertainment. They go to Dubai, they go to Qatar, other places other than Saudi Arabia. Now, the leadership here is saying, "We want our people to spend their money here and we want foreign investments already."
