urn:contentItem:60YR-ND41-JBSS-S058-00000-00Earnings expected to plunge again but there are hopeful signs2020-10-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:29ZLexisNexisEarnings expected to plunge again but there are hopeful signsNEW YORK (CNN Business)

NEW YORK (CNN Business) -- The third quarter is over and Corporate America will soon be reporting just how awful their latest earnings were during the Covid-19 pandemic and recession.

The bad news: Profits probably fell more than 20% compared to a year ago -- the second-worst drop since 2009.

The good news: That's actually an improvement over the second quarter, when earnings suffered a more than 30% plunge. That was the worst since the Great Recession in 2009.

But investors have gotten some hopeful signs lately: Wall Street analysts have boosted their earnings forecasts slightly for the third quarter, according to FactSet Research. Typically, Wall Street cuts its projections the closer companies get to reporting their numbers.

On September 1, analysts were predicting a profit drop of 22.2% in the third quarter. Now, Wall Street is expecting a 21% drop. That's still a notable contraction, of course, but slightly less bad than the forecasts of just a month ago.

The same thing has happened with sales estimates. Revenue for the third quarter is currently expected to decline 3.6% from a year ago versus forecasts of a 4.1% drop at the start of September.

Have to admit it's getting better

Sure, these may sound like subtle, incremental changes. And they are. But it's all part of a bigger trend. Analysts also expect continued improvement for earnings in the fourth quarter, with a projected profit drop of 12.7% and sales decrease of 1.2%.

So Corporate America might be slowly turning the corner.

Wall Street is forecasting a sizable rebound in earnings and revenue for the first half of 2021, too, with profits set to rise nearly 13% in the first quarter of next year and soar 44% in the second quarter.

This earnings comeback is a big reason why stocks have skyrocketed from their March lows -- despite lingering concerns about coronavirus, worries about whether more stimulus is coming from Washington and, of course, questions about the upcoming presidential election (and how long it may take until a victor is declared).

"The market is taking a lot of comfort from the fact that even though we are going to get a big decline in the third quarter, it was much worse three months ago" said Deepak Puri, chief investment officer of the Americas for Deutsche Bank Wealth Management.

"We are moving in the right direction. That is the comforting factor. Economies and businesses are starting to reopen," he added.

Puri also noted that it's encouraging to see that Big Tech companies like Apple, Amazon, Facebook, Microsoft and Google owner Alphabet, which make up a bulk of the S&P 500, are unlikely to suffer much of a hit to sales and profits.

In addition, earnings are starting to improve for companies in cyclical sectors that were hardest hit during the early part of the spring slump, such as industrials, materials and energy.

Still, there are many wild cards in play that could wreak havoc on earnings going forward.

Could a Joe Biden win over President Trump lead to higher taxes and more regulations on banks? Possibly. A second wave of Covid-19 cases in America also could cripple earnings growth and the broader economy.

That's why Puri concedes that investors have to take current forecasts with a grain of salt.

"Estimates could go higher in 2021 due to expectations for a fast recovery. But the outlook is highly uncertain," he said. "Reality almost never syncs up with the early estimates from analysts."

urn:contentItem:5W2T-RYR1-DY0W-41D6-00000-00Earnings Extravaganza; Big Tech Crushes Earnings; CVS Eyes Aetna; The Missing Files; X Marks the Spot; Amazon Earnings; Earnings in Focus;2017-10-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:30ZLexisNexisEarnings Extravaganza; Big Tech Crushes Earnings; CVS Eyes Aetna; The Missing Files; X Marks the Spot; Amazon Earnings; Earnings in Focus;LanhamFULL TEXT

RIVA GOLD, REPORTER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Thanks for having me.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN HOST: All right. That is it for "FBN:am." We now turn it over to the lovely, the talented Dagen McDowell and say good morning. "Mornings With Maria" start now.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Back at you Cheryl. We'll see you in a little bit. Thank you so much.

Good morning everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, October 27th. Your top stories at 6:00a.m. Eastern.

Earnings extravaganza, we are awaiting reports from big names including Merck, ExxonMobil and Chevron this morning. This comes after one stellar afternoon for some tech titans, Amazon, Microsoft, and Google all delivering better than expected earnings results.

Amazon shares jumping on the news making CEO Jeff Bezos $6 billion richer. By the way, Google and Microsoft hitting all time highs in the post market. And it wasn't the only good news for the retailer, Amazon gaining wholesale pharmacy licenses in multiple states.

The move, part of the driving force behind CBS reported proposal to buy health insurer Aetna for a staggering $66 billion.

Futures are showing this in the markets right here right now, gains across the board. The DOW Industrial Futures up 42 points at the moment. This is after gains yesterday in the markets.

Later this morning we get the first reading on how fast the U.S. economy was growing in the last quarter. Investors are also eyeing key developments out of Washington, of course, including the House passing a budget paving the way forward for highly anticipated tax reform.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. PAUL RYAN, (R-WI) SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: I am very, very excited because today, we passed a budget that is physically responsible, it strengthens our national defense, and it's really good for taxpayers.

That means more jobs, fairer taxes, too long the American people have been living under a broken system. So much time and money is wasted just complying with this incredibly complicated tax code, it's unsustainable.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: More on the prospect of getting that deal done straight ahead.

In Europe, we have -- looking at the markets in England, France and Germany. We have gains across the board, the biggest winner so far into Friday's trading day there. The CAC Krones in France up more than one percent.

In Asia Overnight, stock ending the day higher as well. Gains in Hong Kong and Shanghai, the Nikkei, and Japan, and the Kospi in South Korea across the board. The Nikkei the biggest winner.

And the truth is out there but not all of it. Conspiracy theorist outrage after the White House continues to keep some JFK's assassination files under wraps. The biggest revelations from what was released coming up.

Plus, iPhone lovers braving the early morning hours to get the iPhone X, the latest as preorders for the highly anticipated device go up online.

And furor on the field, the tensed moments after Miami Dolphins linebacker Kiko Alonso hits Ravens quarterback Joe Flacco in the head knocking him out of the game. Awful hit.

All of that coming up this morning and so much. Joining me all morning long, FOX News Correspondent, Lea Gabrielle. Kelly and Company Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly. Republican Strategist, Former Trump Surrogate, Erin Elmore. Great to see you Erin as always.

ERIN ELMORE, FORMER TRUMP SURROGATE: You as well.

MCDOWELL: Lea, I see you everyday even in the hall. And I know you are so fired up about -- because there is so much news in the markets from earnings. We have the first reading on the third quarter GDP coming up which could be a huge market mover as well.

KEVIN KELLY, KELLY AND COMPANY MANAGING PARTNER: I don't --

MCDOWELL: Even though (INAUDIBLE) I say it is a market mover.

KELLY: I couldn't sleep last night. I mean it was just like I was so excited, there's so much happening. And the people we have coming on today to talk about it, I mean that's what I'm even more excited about.

MCDOWELL: Well, let's tee that up. Thank you for teeing it up Kevin.

KELLY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And coming up this morning, Venture Capitalist and Partner of (INAUDIBLE) Peter Thiel. His conversation with Maria. New York Stock Exchange president, Tom Farley. Softbank Investment Advisor CEO and Board of Director, Rajeev Misra. And TV And Film star, Kevin Sorbo on his new movie and so much more coming out.

By the way, I'll be on "Outnumbered " later with Kevin Sorbo as the one lucky guy.

But first, we are keeping an eye on earnings, a big day for interview with Exxon, Chevron, and Phillips 66 all out with quarterly numbers before the bell.

The pharmaceutical giant, Merck also expected to report within the hour. And, of course, we're watching shares of Amazon after the company reported record quarterly revenue. Amazon also reportedly getting into the pharmacy business.

That was according -- I love being able to attribute stories to individual newspapers. There's a story in the" St. Louis Post-Dispatch" that Amazon has received approval for wholesale pharmacy licenses in at least 12 states.

This as the drugstore giant CVS is said to be in talks to buy the nation's third largest health insurer Aetna for more than $66 billion. Kevin, where do you want to start? Do you want to start with Amazon and then this deal because they kind of go one -- they go together.

KELLY: I think it's pretty interesting to report on Amazon right now and given the fact that Amazon even (INAUDIBLE) is 52-week high. So we actually saw it reached $1,082 a share.

The interesting aspect about Amazon is the biggest threat to them is regulation. We see that they don't even really pay taxes. When you look at Walmart, they're paying billions of dollars of taxes every single quarter.

So the big play here on Amazon is their Amazon web services. They continuously dominate in that facet. The clear number one -- Microsoft is number two really in cloud services but they don't even compete.

What they're trying to compete on is really what's called hybrid cloud. So what that means is companies that have servers on site, they can actually replicate it up in the cloud too so they can pull from the cloud as well as on site.

Now what's interesting is, Amazon did a deal with VMware last October to compete against Microsoft on that. And Amazon web services, they continuously cut their cost to be the number one player in that space.

So it's so interesting how Amazon conducts business and then you start to see it play out into the pharmacy side, right, because they have the delivery mechanisms, right, the logistics. Their -- 50 percent of their sales are third party distributors on the e-commerce sites, so that's pretty telling.

MCDOWELL: Huge move up in Aetna stock on those report yesterday. And by the way, it is the top story in "The Wall Street Journal" today. Boo, there you go, $66 billion offer.

Multiple meetings between the two CEOs of CVS and Aetna, how could this potentially change not just CVS's business? Because CVS has been moving toward more of a healthcare business as their overall retail sales as a percentage of their revenue have been falling, the smaller percent of their revenue.

But this could do -- in the "Journal" they point out, this could leverage negotiations with drug makers for CVS over -- it would get a great deal, more health data from owning Aetna and it would be -- give an ability to strike new deals that tie drug prices to patient outcomes.

I just think that the possibilities are limitless when you have a pharmacy like this buying a health insurance company.

KELLY: Yes. And the -- yes. And that's the interesting aspect, right? CVS has no experience whatsoever in the insurance business. And then they're coming out the gate and they're buying one of the largest health insurers.

And this goes back to drug pricing, right? We've seen a lot of chatter about pharmacy benefit managers and what the rebates are being. On drug pricing you have the drug makers pointing to the pharmacy benefit manufacturers and you have the insurers pointing it back at them.

So it's such an interesting dynamic and this shows you how much it's going to change over the next couple years and CVS is trying to get in front of that.

MCDOWELL: I think that it's fascinating to just think about the possibility with Amazon filing these wholesale pharmacy licenses that -- because people in Washington, even President Trump has talked about on the campaign trail driving down the cost to prescription medications.

Well how about letting the private industry to it with the license -- Amazon coming and becoming a major negotiator with these drug company.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: And I think one of the things that we'll see is how regulators get involved and how lawmakers get involved.

As you mentioned in regulations if Amazon does move in, but I think that that will be balanced by the potential for drug prices to come way down if Amazon does get into pharmaceuticals.

ELMORE: Well Amazon does everything right. But I sort of feel that --

MCDOWELL: Until they don't. That day is coming, we just don't know when that might happen.

ELMORE: Well I think Amazon has captured a lot of CVS's market share in terms of their retail products. And now that Amazon is the one that's getting into the pharmaceutical world, is CVS sort of the one that the cat chasing its tail?

KELLY: Yes. I think the interesting aspect about Amazon and what they're trying to do here is that they are -- the next leg of growth for them in their stock price and that's what we need to focus on is their ad sales, right?

So they just are opening a new headquarters here for ad sales. What they're going to do is server replacement on the front page. So if you're a company, they've got what you listen to on your -- on Amazon Music, they've got instant prime video, now they're going to see what you buy at the pharmacy, they have -- they're delivering it to you.

MCDOWELL: People talk about Amazon's getting too big but if you read into these earnings reports from Microsoft and Google's parent company Alphabet, there is still a competition out there for Amazon in myriad ways.

Alphabet reported a 40 percent increase and non-advertising revenue, that's strength of its cloud competing business, that was $3.4 billion there. And then Microsoft had a huge surge and two critical components of its cloud computing business as your infrastructure services in the Office 365 online.

Both of those, the revenue there respectively up 90 percent and 42 percent. So there is competition for some of Amazon's businesses.

KELLY: Yes. Well, there's -- they're broken up differently. Which Microsoft --

MCDOWELL: Right. Which you've mentioned earlier.

KELLY: Right. So Microsoft is sort of the utility play and they actually pay a dividend like that. Think about how Google doesn't even pay a dividend, okay? And they're constantly reinvesting.

So what Microsoft did is they switched their business from one time enterprise sales into subscriptions, right? So for Office 365 you now pay on a yearly basis it automatically updates, you rollover, you get the latest edition.

So they're all trying to transition. And what they do best for all these companies is they have the best leaderships. (INAUDIBLE) came out, Microsoft finally got to -- off to the races and dominating in their actually core competencies.

MCDOWELL: And one thing I'll point out because I'm a stats nerd, in one hour after the close of trading yesterday after the earnings came out for Alphabet, Amazon, and Microsoft, $80 billion in market value was added.

I said that at the top of the show, $80 billion in one hour for three companies. Really incredible -- again, you want to know why the markets moving up despite D.C. doing nothing on tax reform so far or healthcare reform is because of these earnings.

KELLY: Yes, exactly. Largest sector in the S&P500 and they've also benefited from the weak dollar.

MCDOWELL: Thank you sir. So much more to talk about. I didn't even get - - we didn't even get -- we didn't even get to talk about the new iPhone X which was I watching online to see what the delivery times are now.

They were out to five weeks in delivery times. They don't even start shipping until early November, November 3rd I think.

We're going to talk about all of that. Coming up, newly released government records about President John F. Kennedy's assassination are released but there still more questions than answers. Were the Russians involved?

And sold out, if you are planning to preorder an iPhone X before you started your day this morning, you are officially too late. More on that ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The White House delaying the release of some of the JFK assassination documents sighting national security concerns. Cheryl Casone has the details, Cheryl --

CASONE: Where's Kevin Costner when you need him Dagen? Historians, conspiracy theorists upset that President Trump didn't release the entire collection.

A 1992 law mandated that all the documents be publicly disclosed this year. But the CIA and the FBI asked that some information be withheld. President Trump put those files under a six-month review saying that he basically had no choice.

But the 20,000 pages that were released reveal some pretty interesting new details like Lee Harvey Oswald meeting a KGB agent in Mexico two months before the shooting. And get this, the CIA had been involved in assassination plots against Cuba's Fidel Castro.

So like I said, there will be movies and TV shows about these new documents I'm sure coming out.

Okay. Preorders for the Apple iPhone X starting today but you're probably going to have trouble getting your hands on one. Sources say supplies of a hot new phone already sold out. Shipping estimates are slipping well beyond November 3rd launch date.

In fact, we're talking weeks, maybe months. The news coming on weak sales of the iPhone8. Two research firms say that the iPhone8 posted the weakest sales of any of the company's new smartphones. People are still getting the 7 basically. Shares of Apple trading higher in the premarket.

Well, a costly win for the Baltimore Ravens against the Miami Dolphins last night. Second quarter, watch the hit on quarterback Joe Flacco. Kiko Alonso nailed him, knocks of Flacco's helmet. A fight ensues after all this goes down. Just waiting for the fight.

Anyway, unnecessary roughness got called against Alonso. Now he crushed Flacco as he goes for the quarterback flight. Flacco would go straight into the locker room. He had a concussion, he did not come back to the game.

Meanwhile, the National Football League has also taken some hits these days. A new FOX News poll finds that the league's favorable rating is dropping. Forty six percent of voters have a positive view of the NFL now but that's down eighteen points from four years ago.

Forty one percent view it in a negative way, that's an increase. Fans are also starting to come around the NFL players kneeling for the national anthem. Yes, forty four percent think kneeling is appropriate. That's up from forty one percent who felt that way last month and thirty two percent who didn't really -- they liked in September.

But basically still a majority think that it's inappropriate Dagen to kneel during the national anthem at a football game.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much Cheryl. Kevin, so we see the favorability ratings clutching with the earnings -- the ratings haven't fallen that much. They're down year-over-year but -- were earlier in the season but they're not down that much.

KELLY: No, it's not. And I mean there's so much business and entertainment that revolves around the NFL that you really wouldn't see it come down from fantasy football to sports betting, to everything that revolves around it.

I mean even think about the Super Bowl half time show, right? I mean it's such a big production put on by Pepsi that we talk about how, "Oh my gosh, Justin Timberlake is coming up."

ELMORE: Commercial -- the commercials are half of the fun too, right?

MCDOWELL: Not anymore. I'm tired because you see all the commercials beforehand, here's my favorite tweet from Pat Sajak yesterday. He said, "Staying away from politics and social issues on my birthday. I'll just relax and watch an NFL game and maybe a couple of late night talk show."

GABRIELLE: That's funny.

ELMORE: I love it.

GABRIELLE: And even the point is, if you want to hit them where it counts, you hit the ratings, you turn off your televisions, you hit the pocketbooks and ultimately it trickles down. So that's the way you do it.

ELMORE: But since rating are down, what do you think we attribute that to? Is it the CTE and the brain injury scandals or --

MCDOWELL: I think some of it is -- I think some of it is that people are switching off television and they're watching programming differently. But also it's certainly impacted it somewhat is that they're just tired of seeing the political shenanigans in sports.

ELMORE: And "ESPN" is sort of a thing in the past these days.

MCDOWELL: They got a lot of work to do. I was watching "ESPN" yesterday and "ESPN" has a lot of work to do in a lot of ways. Like not covering breaking news, but that's what we do here is cover breaking news.

And coming up, just four votes, it was a narrow win for the budget resolution that clears the way for the president's tax plan. Now, the real drama begins, can the GOP come together to get this done by year's end?

And Harvey Weinstein suing the company that bears his name to get his personal files. The fired movie executive is trying to get documents to defend himself against a mountain of sexual harassment allegations.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Turning now the road to tax reform, President Trump's tax plan clearing another major hurdle, the house narrowly approving the Senate's $4 trillion budget measure yesterday paving the way for tax reform.

The plan was passed with a vote of 216 to 212, 20 republicans voting nay on this. Here's what Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross and House Ways and Means Committee Chairman, Kevin Brady had to say yesterday after the vote.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILBUR ROSS, SECRTARY OF COMERCE: I think the negative votes that came were probably mostly over the deductibility of state and local.

KEVIN BRADY, (R-TX) HOUSE WAYS AND MEANS COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: We're proposing to flatten the brackets, lower the tax rates for everybody in every state. Lawmakers in very high tax states, New York, New Jersey would -- Illinois and California, others as well.

They are worried because their state and local politicians are just hammering them with taxes and so they worry about that burden. We're working with those lawmakers --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The tax writing committee will hold a markup for the GOP tax plan in the following weeks. Speaker of the House Paul Ryan says he wants the House to pass a tax bill before Thanksgiving.

Joining us now is --

SCOTT RASMUSSEN, EDITOR-AT-LARGE, BALLOTPEDIA: Ballotpedia

MCDOWELL: Ballotpedia Editor-at-Large, Political Analyst, Scott Rasmussen. I knew I was going to foul that up. Can the G -- can the tax reform get done by the end of the year?

RASMUSSEN: It has to. I mean if it doesn't, there will be some republican senators who loosen their primaries. And the base is so angry with the inability pass -- to repeal ObamaCare, they're looking for something to be done.

What yesterday's vote did, it said we need to have a procedure that will let us pass something with 51 votes, that's all it was and we're going to see lots of horse trading between now and the end of the year.

MCDOWELL: Yes. But senators who aren't up for reelection don't care. I'll point to John McCain, John McCain won his seat last year and you saw the -- on the healthcare bill --

RASMUSSEN: John --

MCDOWELL: And I -- so I push back on that that there are a lot of senators who don't care what happened.

RASMUSSEN: But the republican senators are more united on a desire for tax reform than they were on the -- on changes to ObamaCare.

This is an issue that really does unite the republicans of the idea of lower tax rates, the idea of growing the economy through tax cuts and through a different approach. It's something that will get done. But I don't think it's going to look anything like the framework we saw yesterday.

MCDOWELL: I want to get to these pieces down because this is something that I have lost my head over. My eye have been in a full rage for the last week over the GOP tinkering or messing with or taking a hatchet to 401(k) contribution.

So the president -- President Trump and the GOP has been battling over these 401(k) plan details. Chairman Brady of House Ways and Means told Lou Dobbs last night that he and the president were not planning to make any cuts to 401(k) plans, listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRADY: He wants to increase the amount of savings in 401(k)'s limit, so do I. We want to encourage more people to save sooner in life and save more. He and I are going to work together on this effort.

Within the day, if we can't find consensus in the country on how best to do that, we'll leave them as they are --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: That's a -- that's tap dance, verbal tap dancing. I hear it's - - because listen, they in Washington have been talking about cutting in a contribution limit from $18,000 a year, it's $18,500 next year to $2,400, that's a fact. And now you get this response.

RASMUSSEN: And I think it's something that shouldn't furiate you. It's also a great example though of what the problem is with trying to predict tax reform and what it will end up being.

401(k)s themselves were never intended to be what they became. It was a mistake written to the law, a guy named Ted Benna actually read the law and figured out somehow Congress had made this mistake and we now have tens of millions of people who see this is a cornerstone of retirement.

MCDOWELL: Well because it is. Because they lost --

GABRIELLE: It is. It absolutely is.

RASMUSSEN: That's correct.

GABRIELLE: And they're talking about those pretax contribution limits are going to be huge issue. You say that this has to get done, this tax plan has to be done but the devil's going to be at the details when they hash this out.

And yesterday, we saw 20 noes and that was because of the state and local taxes and those deductions. So I guess my question is, you see it has to get done, how can it get done when we have seen no details yet?

RASMUSSEN: What you will see happening is state and local deductions, there's a big issue for people who live in New York and New Jersey, that affects higher income earners more to lower income people.

And that's where the money is. So that's why these fights will be so intense. The popular support around the country is to get rid of these things that benefit high income people. High income earners are the ones with the most influence.

So I think you'll end up seeing is something will be done on state and local deductions but it will not be a full of a nation. I think you'll see the same thing with 401(k)s, they will trim something back, not as much as they're talking about right now.

And they're going to do it with one goal in mind, it has nothing to do with economics, it will all be, "Where's the 50 first votes?"

MCDOWELL: Thank you Scott. We need to go. Sorry Erin. Great to see you. But if they tinker even a little bit with 401(k) plans, my issue is it's not worth the little bit of revenue that it will raise. Based on the plan right now, it would only raise a quarter of a trillion over 10 years. It's not worth it.

RASMUSSEN: And you're talking substance, I'm just talking politics. They have to pass something.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Because there is no substance in politics.

RASMUSSEN: That's right.

MCDOWELL: Scott Rasmussen, great to see you. In case you missed it, here's some of this week's top moments from the show.

(BEGIN VIDEO TAPE)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: From Riyadh, Saudi Arabia we are at the Future Investment Initiative. There is something of a revolution going on in Saudi Arabia right now. They are starting from scratch hoping to build industries, you've got the titans of business here on the ground in Riyadh hoping to get a piece of this build up. His royal highness, Prince Mohammad bin Salman.

MOHAMMAD BIN SALMAN, CROWNED PRINCE OF SAUDI ARABIA: The opportunity is unimaginable. A region that is almost vacant, there are many dreams from the Saudi leadership, many of the Saudis and many -- and our partners and of large companies are individuals.

Thousands of dreams that will be established, 70 percent of the Saudi people are less than 30-years-old. And quite frankly, we will not waste 30 years of our lives in dealing with extremist ideas. We will be starting today.

ALAN SCHWARTZ, EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, GUGGENHEIM PARTNERS: The crowned prince and everybody really announcing that they are changing the whole nature of the way they think about this economy and this culture.

If they take the reforms that they're talking about, this whole Gulf Coast and Saudi as a leader could have a real revival going forward.

BARTIROMO: Investors are watching the Saudi Aramco deal. It is going to be the largest IPO in the world.

XAVIER ROLET, CEO, LONDON STOCK EXCHANGE: This potential transaction needs to be looked in the context of an overall strategy of effectively promoting the growth of Saudi economy. Overtime, reducing, of course, it's reliance on the export of hydrocarbons.

Maria Do you agree with what the president is saying in terms of Canada and Mexico having this great deal that the U.S. is at a disadvantage?

ANDREW LIVERIS, CEO, DOW CHEMICAL:I do. I do think it's because of our mindset. We've spend six decades since the martial plan the consumer. I would tell you over and over we haven't given much thought to being an investor now in economy in things like manufacturing.

The president is putting emphasis on what can I do to create jobs in America as an exporter of manufactured goods? And I'm all for that.

MCDOWELL: House republicans were reportedly considering a plan to sharply reduce the amount of money that Americans can save in their 401(k) plans.

GROVER NORQUIST, PRESIDENT, AMERICANS FOR TAX REFORM: If having higher tax bracket was a stupid idea, and it is, going after savings for people's retirement is a particularly god-awful stupid idea. We've got to get away from punishing people's ability to save for their own retirement.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer is waging a war of words against you. His statements are outlandish and he seems just to want to, I don't know if I'm allowed today use this word, I think I am, suck up to Trump.

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY OF THE UNITED STATES: I was kind of shocked that he'd be saying that about me or about any Secretary of the Treasury and, you know, I restrained myself. And, look, it's factual, if we get the growth, it will pay down the debt. So we can debate whether we get the growth or not. But i was quite surprised of his comments.

THOMAS BARRACK JR., CEO OF COLONY CAPITAL: What we've witnessed is not a misfire by President Trump, his voice playing badly in the sandbox. The machinery is working and these politicians know that it's a necessity for them on behalf of their constituencies to get something done and to stop bickering. And nobody toys with President Trump.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, October 27th, your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern. An earnings blitz on Wall Street, Merck, Exxon, Chevron, just a few of the names closing out the busiest week of earning season. We bring you the numbers as they come out. And it comes after a huge day for three tech titans, Amazon, Microsoft and Google parent, Alphabet, all delivering better than expected results. Turning to broader markets, you have Futures pointing to a higher open 43 point gain on the Dow Futures.

The likes of Microsoft and Alphabet, parent of Google actually hit an all- time high in post market trading yesterday. Later this morning, we get the first reading on how fast the economy was growing last quarter, not quite three percent of the expectation, but pretty close for the U.S. economy. We head to Europe, we have gains across the board in England, France and Germany. In Asia overnight, stocks ending the week higher as well, gains there in the fourth major market that we watched. Declaring a crisis, President Trump setting his sights on the rise of opioid addiction in America.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: This epidemic is a national health emergency. In our lifetime, nobody has seen anything like what's going on now. As Americans, we cannot allow this to continue. It's time to liberate our communities from discourse of drug addiction. Never been this way.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: How the President plans to combat that epidemic, ahead. A disgraced Hollywood heavyweight hits back, why Harvey Weinstein is suing his former company in the wake of his sexual harassment scandal. A real deal or a box office flop, Regal Theatres testing surge pricing charging more for the biggest blockbusters, we will look at how it will work.

A Cool Hand Luke's wristwatch does not come cheap, the record-breaking amount that Paul Newman's legendary Rolex, brought in at auction. And if I had the coin, I would pay it. Our top story this half hour, Maria sat down with Venture Capitalist and Founder Fund Partner, Peter Thiel at the Saudi Investment Conference yesterday. She asked him about everything from Artificial Intelligence to investment communities or opportunities. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: When you first founded PayPal, we were in a different time. Today, we are talking about data, we're talking about the Cloud, we're talking about digitizing our life and technology is the under pending of every industry whether it's driverless cars or collecting data. So zero in for us on industries, where are you finding opportunity to invest in industry?

PETER THIEL, PARTNER OF FOUNDERS FUND: Certainly, you know, for example, Airbnb, SpaceX, Facebook earlier on, you know, investments I made and each of these companies, you can describe them as part of the trends or the sharing economy or social networking for Facebook. But, that's a misleading way to describe it. It was much better to think of them as solving a very specific problem.

Airbnb was, sort of, a hotel room substitute. It's not the sharing economy obstruction. It's the hotel room substitute. It's the only company that's doing that on a worldwide scale and that makes it a one of a kind company. Facebook somehow figured out real identity.

BARTIROMO: One scene that we've been talking about, of course, here, is what his Highness is doing with NEOM and all of the technology that is going to be in this new city of the future. Where do you see the opportunities in terms of starting from scratch? When you have a city, what kind of technologies are going to be most needed?

THIEL: Well, it's -- there's a tremendous amount that one can do when one starts something new from scratch, because one thing that is striking about the great cities of the world, like London, New York, you know, Silicon Valley, very many other places. It is but -- even though there are these incredibly dynamic economic places, it's extremely hard to change things. And so, you know, New York City, it costs $1 billion to build one mile of subway, or something like that.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

THIEL: In San Francisco, you can't -- you can't build new highways or anything new. The transportation grid is set, and so there is -- there is this very weird transportation problem with the big cities where in effect, it becomes incredibly hard to build new transportation once the basic city has been built. If the transportation systems are inadequate and i would say they are badly inadequate in all of our major cities even in the developed world, emerging world, the catastrophic developed world, they are generally inadequate.

The self-driving car trend, it's against the trend. It's a very important trend for the economy, for -- and change consumer behavior tremendously. If you have self-driving cars, maybe you could have a longer commute because you could work in the car or, you know, maybe some things -- some things would change. I'm not sure it's a good investment because there are a lot of companies doing similar technologies in self-driving cars. It's hard to know exactly how to differentiated they are.

BARTIROMO: And people are worried that the more A.I. and machine learning you have, in a situation, the fewer jobs you have. So, are robots going to be taking our jobs?

THIEL: Well, it's -- one of the things -- you know, I'm always nervous about the abstractions, A.I. is one of the greatest abstractions of all because Artificial Intelligence can mean the next generation of computers or the last generation of computers or anything in between. We can mean things that are like a little bit in the future or, you know, very far in the future.

If you had generalized Artificial Intelligence, this, sort of, where you had a computer that was smarter and more able in every way possible, I would say that the problem with that is not economic but political. It'll be like an alien from another planet landing and the question, if aliens landed on earth, would not be, what does this mean for the unemployment rate, the question would be, are they friendly, are they unfriendly, things like that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a good point.

THIEL: And so -- and so I think to the extent the economic question is serious, it's much more the political question.

BARTIROMO: What can we do to protect ourselves in this new world where we feel like everyone's getting hacked and data has become so much more powerful?

THIEL: Well, there is a -- there's a tremendous amount that we can do in combining computers with humans. And, you know, a lot of the approaches in crime, defense, areas like this, and security, have been -- we either have all human solutions or all computer solutions and I think the truth is, that there's a lot to be done with these intermediate hybrid solutions.

And what we did at PayPal, and what we've done at pounds here, is figure out a good division of labor between human analysts and automated computer systems. And it turns out that if you get the division of labor right, you can do a lot. One of the challenges with cybersecurity is that it's -- there is something about it where it's very asymmetric. That, you know, in most forms of defense, military technologies, the defense side is pretty good.

But in cybersecurity, it's very hard to defend. It's very easy to attack. And so if you have something where it's incredibly easy to attack, incredibly hard to defend, that creates some very unusual challenges. I think -- I think we haven't quite figured out what to do about them. We certainly are not able to defend as well as we can, we're not willing to take the precautions that are needed and it really calls out for some big - - a lot more work in the decade ahead.

BARTIROMO: You've been really successful in terms of watching where the growth is in the world, and identifying the companies that are, you know, solving important problems, what excites you right now?

THIEL: I do think people are a little bit -- maybe underestimating Bitcoin, specifically, because it is like -- it's like a reserved form of money, it's like gold and it's just a store value, you don't actually need to use make payments, and it's been, you know, there's about $70 billion worth of Bitcoin in the world.

There's $9 trillion worth of gold and if Bitcoin ends up being the cyber equivalent of gold, and it has -- it has a -- it has a great potential left, so that's -- and it's a very different kind of thing from what people in Silicon Valley normally focus on, companies, not, you know, algorithms or protocols but, this may be -- this may be one exception that's very underestimated.

FARLEY: Yes. I mean I was just waiting to sit down with you and impromptu was able to have a conversation with Secretary Mnuchin, Steve Schwarzman, Howard Marks. And it is the great and the good of financing and finance all around the world.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. Now, one of the big reasons obviously is this Saudi Aramco deal. They are going to take their state oil company public -- could be the biggest IPO ever. It could be up to $75 billion.

You have Alibaba which is what -- a $24 billion deal. This would be a huge piece of business for the New York Stock Exchange.

FARLEY: So, you know, people see me in the halls here as the head of the New York Stock Exchange. Everyone assumes that my relationship is totally about the Aramco IPO. I've actually known the -- from the minister level to the company Saudi Aramco -- I've known the company for many years long before the IPO was even a notion because as you know the New York Stock Exchange is owned by Intercontinental Exchange, the largest energy exchange in the world. I'm one of the managers of that business and Saudi Aramco is a partner and a customer in that respect.

Regarding the IPO, we will compete for any IPO of a great global business. I can't say too much about Saudi Aramco in particular other than anyone you meet from the company or the ministry -- and I know you've met several of them just this week. They are professional. They are sophisticated. And no surprise, they are carrying out a very disciplined, due diligence process to make the right decision for Saudi Arabia as a whole.

BARTIROMO: So you think you're going to get the deal.

FARLEY: I'm not going to comment in particular because I don't want to prejudice any decision that they make. But for any great global IPO, look, first of all we want them to make the right decision for them. We won't try to corner them in to make something we think is a wrong decision.

Clearly the New York Stock Exchange is the leading exchange in the world for listings. We have something like $34 trillion of market caps. The next closest exchange is a tiny, tiny fraction of that.

And so in terms of the deepest liquidity in the world that's in the United States. Brand name -- you get that from the New York Stock Exchange. It's also a rigorous governance test to be listed in the New York Stock Exchange. So if you list there, you're holding yourself out to be a very well-run, well-governed company.

That is kind of the decision criteria that benefits what the New York Stock Exchange brings. But I have no doubt other exchanges around the world have their own unique benefits as well.

BARTIROMO: What are the implications of such a huge deal? I mean if you're looking at Alibaba being the biggest deal at $24 billion and this deal is as high as $75 billion, give us a sense. Give our viewers a sense of why this is so important and what the global implications are for a company this size to go public or to sell 5 percent of it to the public?

FARLEY: So large IPOs are nerve-racking. We do them a lot. Of the top 20 IPOs of all time, I think the number is 13 have been on the New York Stock Exchange. And even those companies that fall on the other seven many of them have ultimately listed in the New York Stock Exchange.

We know a lot about big deals and the New York Stock Exchange is purpose- built for those big deals. We combine humans and technology but we still spend a lot of time getting ready for those IPOs because there is a lot of bids and offers that come in that. There's a lot of complexity on that moment the stock opens. And you need to make sure that stock opens smoothly so that the management team of the IPO doesn't spend the next six months or two years explaining what went wrong on IPO day.

BARTIROMO: So let me ask you what you're seeing right now at the New York Stock Exchange in terms of listings. Obviously there has always been a massive competition between NYSE and Nasdaq. What can you tell us in terms of business year-to-date?

FARLEY: Well, apropos of our interview location halfway around the world from our normal home base, our shared home base it's a very global story. The IPO market is booming in the U.S. and at the New York Stock Exchange. We've had twice as many roundabouts, twice as many IPOs as all of last year. We've had this year twice as much in terms of dollar value and from all around the world.

Last week alone we had a great company from Southeast Asia and we had another company from China. This week we have an Argentinian company, next week a Brazilian company. And so we are seeing great global companies choosing the New York Stock Exchange.

BARTIROMO: Are you seeing more global companies relative to the U.S.? Because the truth is there are a lot of start-ups who are saying, you know what, I don't want to go public. The regulatory environment is too tight. And I'm not going to.

So that's why there was a problem. People were wondering why the IPO market was not so busy earlier this year. The start-ups were not going public.

FARLEY: I'm glad you asked that. You know, the American audience likes to make a big deal out of a story. There are not as many American tech companies going public. And that's true. Some of the great American tech companies have chosen to stay private.

The last week alone, we had a young man who started a company three years ago to provide a technology that allows for consumer lending in China -- that company is now worth over $10 billion. It's an amazing tech story. And the Friday company, too was a technology company that offers gaming, e- commerce and payments from Singapore. We just don't talk about it as much frankly because it's not American.

But these are great tech companies choosing to go public, choosing the New York Stock Exchange fortunately. I'm appreciative that they did choose the New York Stock Exchange.

BARTIROMO: Well, here is a stat for you -- listed public companies in the U.S. down 50 percent over 20 years because of the regulatory environment. I mean the President has said he is calling for IPOs, the bar for IPOs to be lowered.

The Treasury came out with a report. They're basically saying the regulatory environment is way too hard for companies to go public.

What are you doing in terms of lowering the bar, in terms of lowering the standards, making it easier for companies to go public?

FARLEY: You know, I think you are referring to our press report that came out. And if you work your way down that press report the next paragraph starts with some of the efforts of the New York Stock Exchange and I personally have engaged in, to push the administration to make it easier to engage in IPOs.

You mentioned the number of public companies. It is down by about half.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FARLEY: But the average market cap is up by over three times -- The aggregate market cap. So the average company is five or six times bigger. The public market works great for big companies. It's not working as well for small companies.

BARTIROMO: That's exactly right.

FARLEY: And we need to acknowledge that because small companies are the life blood of free enterprise. They give the inspiration to even smaller companies. They create jobs.

BARTIROMO: So what can you do? What can you do to get more small companies to go public then?

FARLEY: Simple things. The pendulum has swung too far on regulation with Dodd-Frank and Sarbanes-Oxley. Big companies can handle it. Small companies can't. So if you can allow the small companies during the IPO process to meet more with investors and analysts, you can reduce the Sarbanes-Oxley requirements on small companies.

Like for example, not require an external audit for the first few years that a company is public. And you could extend that to all new companies not just the tiniest ones but expand the envelope a little bit and have it be for all new companies that are new to public market.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean one thing is create a longer window of time in which companies can be in the emerging growth category.

FARLEY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FARLEY: Exactly. And what that emerging market growth category does is it just requires less regulation for small companies.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FARLEY: You know, regulation is like taxes. No regulation isn't the answer and complete government control isn't the answer -- somewhere in between is the right answer, and the pendulum is going to swing. We have swung too far towards heavily regulating small companies and we need to swing it back aggressively to make sure that that IPO engine is there for those young entrepreneurs.

BARTIROMO: What does the sentiment feel like to you when you go down on the floor, when you speak to big investors? Because how do you like the way the President is constantly tweeting that market has gained $5.3 trillion in market value since Election Day? We are at record highs -- 23000 and counting.

Do you feel like things are getting overheated? Do you feel the same sentiment when you talk to investors that you did a year ago?

FARLEY: I walk in on the floor and I look up at the indices every morning and it's amazing what has happened since November.

BARTIROMO: Don't you think?

FARLEY: We're 17400 that night, if you remember because the indices really cratered and now they had zipped back up. However I will note, it's also a global story. This isn't just America. In the last two weeks alone the DAX, the CAC, the (INAUDIBLE) -- they have all hit all-time highs.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible.

FARLEY: So there is a really -- this is a really good moment globally.

BARTIROMO: So do you feel like sentiment is still there? The bullishness or are people getting worried that things are getting over priced?

FARLEY: People are bullish. That doesn't mean there won't be a pullback but people are bullish without question.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Tom -- it's great to see you.

FARLEY: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much.

FARLEY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Tom Farley is the president of the New York Stock Exchange.

VARNEY: That's right. Let's weigh this up, shall we? Do I join the marking global economy and buy into technology stock and then my money goes through the roof or do I lend -- as you say, lend to Uncle Sam and get me two percent? Which do I do? OK. I'm dead safe with Uncle Sam, I got it but I'm going nowhere. I'm taking a risk with technology, but I'm going somewhere. As for putting new money in now, that I'm not so sure of. I'm going to hold off on that, but as everybody knows, I do I own some Microsoft and my point today is I'm not selling at this point.

MCDOWELL: Do you think Satya Nadella of Microsoft makes better decisions with your money or Congress? We already pay taxes, that's -- I know that's a little simplistic but I always think --

(CROSSTALK)

VARNEY: No, it's a loaded question. That's what it is. You know where I'm coming from too.

MCDOWELL: You're fantastic each and every day.

VARNEY: I do.

MCDOWELL: Stuart is coming up in almost exactly 15 minutes. A reminder, "VARNEY & COMPANY" every day, 9:00 a.m. Eastern time. Three whole hours of Mr. Stuart Varney.

The first reading on how fast the economy was growing last quarter coming in much better than expected. Nicole Petallides on floor at the New York Stock Exchange. Hey, Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN HOST: Hey, good Friday morning, Dagen. Yes, that's right. We're seeing the economy here in the U.S. in the latest quarter grow faster than expected, at three percent rate faster than the 2.5 percent rate that was expected. Why did that happen? That was consumer and also business spending that helped it along and that's why you did see that growth there despite Harvey and Irma.

Taking a look at Futures right now, up 17 points for the Dow Jones Industrial Average. We'll see if we can make some records today. Taking a look at Merck, though, Dow component, Merck, that is to the downside this morning, sales dropped three percent overall. It did very well with KEYTRUDA. That is their U.S. long -- that's a cancer patient -- U.S. cancer -- lung cancer and that really helped them along but not enough to break through. Stock down 2-1/2 percent, profit beat, they raised the outlook but a sales miss overall.

Then there's Colgate-Palmolive, so that was relatively flat. Let's take a look at that. It did ramp up ad spending, about 20 percent ramped that up, and that cut into the numbers. That is down one-third of one percent. And good old G.E., well, G.E., of course, you know, we reported recently how it's dropped out of the dividend portfolio for Morgan Stanley. Well, now, they're exiting and saying that they want to exit out of the railroad business. Just not seeing the demand, it is a seasonal business, it is -- is it inconsistent, and they have so many others from aviation to power, health care, just to name some.

So, this morning, we're seeing it up one-quarter of one percent, but we did see those new lows as to -- on 10.26 of 21.20. We're not too far off of that, so people are holding to this one for the long term, they've been ultimately very disappointed, and there is talk (INAUDIBLE) outlook they might be cutting the dividend, too. And that's why Morgan Stanley, ultimately, tried to pull them out of that portfolio for wealth management because it's not really what they're looking for big picture.

We have much more, MORNINGS WITH MARIA, coming up right after this, happy Friday to you. Keep it here on Fox Business.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: If Tesla wants to revolutionize how we drive, Zero Motorcycles who wants to take your love of the road to the next level. No noise, no vibrations, but all the power and torque of the best bikes out there. It's electric and it's the next great American brand, completely made in the United States. Joining me now, is Zero Motorcycles' CEO, Sam Paschel. Tell me about the bike, Sam, because I'm a Harley fan, that's a regular old-fashioned and internal combustion engine.

SAM PASCHEL, ZERO MOTORCYCLES CEO: It is.

MCDOWELL: And this is not anything like that.

PASCHEL: It is. This is -- it's the most innovative motorcycle in the world. If you're familiar with a Harley, something like a Harley Sportster 1200. Will have about 73 foot-pounds of torque. That's basically how much force is being applied to that back tire to really give you the acceleration. Zero Motorcycles -- the bike right in front of us has about 116 foot-pounds of torques. So, you're getting the acceleration and performance out of a, like a modern day superbike out of one of these electric motorcycles.

MCDOWELL: Are you going after the audience that Harley Davidson goes after? What's your key demographic?

PASCHEL: The key demographics, we have three basic types of riders that make up the majority of who we reach out to. First, we have riders that tend to have more than one motorcycle in the garage. You know, the electric motorcycle phenomenon, electric vehicles overall are still pretty new. In 2011, there were about 2,000 plugin vehicles sold in the United States overall, four wheels, two wheels, everything else. Flash forward it last year, and there were about 160,000 plugin vehicles sold in the United States and about 780,000 globally. So, this phenomenon is catching on. But within the motorcycle community, it's still relatively new. So, the three types of riders we generally get are riders who have a quiver of bikes that have more than one motorcycle in the garage. We get new riders, people, that don't have that established connection with any one brand. And throw a leg over a Zero and just fall in love with it.

And three, and actually, probably the most common, we have riders who love motorcycle riding at one point in their life, and then for one reason or another, had a family, had kids, moved away from it, and now it's the lure of electric and the differentiated ride that's really drawing them back.

MCDOWELL: I've been on a Harley or eight in my days, and these bikes, they don't have the roar and the rumble of a Harley that Harley riders and devotees really crave.

PASCHEL: It's true. It's true. If you think about riding a motorcycle, and you've been on one, it's a -- it's an experience that uses all five senses. Three of those senses on an electric motorcycle are going to be completely different than they are on a gas bike. First, as you mentioned, is the -- is the audio, the sound. You're not going to have that same rumble. You're not going to have that same sense of sound. You're going to hear your surroundings a lot better. You can hear what's going on around you but you're not going to have that roar.

Number two, the smell and the fumes of a gas bike aren't really going to be there.

MCDOWELL: Which is my cologne.

PASCHEL: Which is your cologne. It's not mine today. It's not mine today. It's the reason --

MCDOWELL: I'm just kidding.

PASCHEL: -- I'm stepping on further way. But third, and I think most important is all the -- all the vibration that you tend to feel with the gas bike, you don't feel with an electric motorcycle. So the only thing you're really feeling is your connection to the road and the ride. For me --

MCDOWELL: These are made in the United States, made in America just like the Harley, so is that a selling point, too.

PASCHEL: It's a huge point for our consumers. The bikes have been engineered from the ground up, designed and are all built in the bay area, in Northern California.

MCDOWELL: How -- what are your sales like year-over-year, how much are they growing?

PASCHEL: They were growing in about a 35 percent compound annual growth rate. It's similar to what's happening in the E.V. space. And two dynamics at play, one, is a motorcycle market that tends to be a bit flat. The second is an E.V. market that's growing rapidly. Luckily for us, we're tending to follow a curved of the E.V. market.

MCDOWELL: What about other products that you might be looking at outside of motorcycles?

PASCHEL: So, we have -- we have three basic business segments. The first is the commercial motorcycles which are for sale to consumers and motorcycles for us --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: And I interviewed the founder of the company years ago when the first bikes were rolling out.

PASCHEL: Yes. Neal was fantastic; he was a NASA-funded engineer at one point, and a mountain bike and a motorcycle enthusiast.

MCDOWELL: Right.

PASCHEL: The second segment for us is fleets and military. It's a great application for local police forces. And third is this powertrain business, where their companies that realize they're a little bit behind the curve on electrification, we've got millions of miles underneath the bikes, we've got 11 years of experience and they're coming to us to help them electrify the products that they have already created.

MCDOWELL: Sam, good to see you. Please come back.

PASCHEL: Thanks so much for having us.

MCDOWELL: I wish I would get on one but -- I'm not wearing my motorcycle pants today. Sam Paschel, thank you so much.

PASCHEL: Thank you so much. (INAUDIBLE) come out to California and we'll get your leg throw over a bike.

MCDOWELL: Yes, on a day like today, it's a little chilly, I'll take even Northern California, the coldest place on the planet in the middle of July. Thank you so much, Sam.

PASCHEL: Thank you very much.

MCDOWELL: It's really good to see you. Coming up, final thoughts from our all-stars.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: I don't know why that song reminds me of Kevin Kelly but it does. Final thoughts right now. Erin, to you first.

ELMORE: I drank a whole Starbucks, it's obvious, Frappuccino, so I'm all juiced up today. My vote is for Trump to keep yelling as a (INAUDIBLE). Have a happy weekend.

MCDOWELL: Kevin?

KELLY: I'm going to bring -- wear my piano key necktie next time I'm out here, and also it's important to note that CVS, only 14.5 percent of their customers use mail order subscription through their pharmacy, Amazon is coming for you.

MCDOWELL: And Lea, final thoughts

GABRIELLE: So the Congress, the budget resolution, well, that was due back in April. It's almost Halloween, if they get started on next year's now, then they might get it done by Independence Day. So I'd say, get it moving.

MCDOWELL: And here's my final thought to the people in Congress, the GOP who are writing that house -- that tax reform bill, if you touch 401(k) plans and make this market tank, you're going to own that, and you will feel the wrath of President Trump for your remaining days in Congress. A big thanks to Erin Elmore, Kevin Kelly, and Lea Gabrielle. Have a great weekend, everybody. Mr. Varney starts right now with "VARNEY & COMPANY."

Stuart, I don't know it if I'm early or late, but it's all yours.

VARNEY: I'll take it. I'll take it, Dagen, gratefully. Thank you very much indeed, Dagen. All right.

END

urn:contentItem:5PVC-P6H1-JBHT-D0M0-00000-00Earnings Extravaganza; Big Tech Crushes Earnings; CVS Eyes Aetna; The Missing Files; X Marks the Spot; Amazon Earnings; Earnings in Focus;2017-10-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:30ZLexisNexisEarnings Extravaganza; Big Tech Crushes Earnings; CVS Eyes Aetna; The Missing Files; X Marks the Spot; Amazon Earnings; Earnings in Focus;LanhamFULL TEXT

RIVA GOLD, REPORTER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Thanks for having me.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN HOST: All right. That is it for "FBN:am." We now turn it over to the lovely, the talented Dagen McDowell and say good morning. "Mornings With Maria" start now.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Back at you Cheryl. We'll see you in a little bit. Thank you so much.

Good morning everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, October 27th. Your top stories at 6:00a.m. Eastern.

Earnings extravaganza, we are awaiting reports from big names including Merck, ExxonMobil and Chevron this morning. This comes after one stellar afternoon for some tech titans, Amazon, Microsoft, and Google all delivering better than expected earnings results.

Amazon shares jumping on the news making CEO Jeff Bezos $6 billion richer. By the way, Google and Microsoft hitting all time highs in the post market. And it wasn't the only good news for the retailer, Amazon gaining wholesale pharmacy licenses in multiple states.

The move, part of the driving force behind CBS reported proposal to buy health insurer Aetna for a staggering $66 billion.

Futures are showing this in the markets right here right now, gains across the board. The DOW Industrial Futures up 42 points at the moment. This is after gains yesterday in the markets.

Later this morning we get the first reading on how fast the U.S. economy was growing in the last quarter. Investors are also eyeing key developments out of Washington, of course, including the House passing a budget paving the way forward for highly anticipated tax reform.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. PAUL RYAN, (R-WI) SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: I am very, very excited because today, we passed a budget that is physically responsible, it strengthens our national defense, and it's really good for taxpayers.

That means more jobs, fairer taxes, too long the American people have been living under a broken system. So much time and money is wasted just complying with this incredibly complicated tax code, it's unsustainable.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: More on the prospect of getting that deal done straight ahead.

In Europe, we have -- looking at the markets in England, France and Germany. We have gains across the board, the biggest winner so far into Friday's trading day there. The CAC Krones in France up more than one percent.

In Asia Overnight, stock ending the day higher as well. Gains in Hong Kong and Shanghai, the Nikkei, and Japan, and the Kospi in South Korea across the board. The Nikkei the biggest winner.

And the truth is out there but not all of it. Conspiracy theorist outrage after the White House continues to keep some JFK's assassination files under wraps. The biggest revelations from what was released coming up.

Plus, iPhone lovers braving the early morning hours to get the iPhone X, the latest as preorders for the highly anticipated device go up online.

And furor on the field, the tensed moments after Miami Dolphins linebacker Kiko Alonso hits Ravens quarterback Joe Flacco in the head knocking him out of the game. Awful hit.

All of that coming up this morning and so much. Joining me all morning long, FOX News Correspondent, Lea Gabrielle. Kelly and Company Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly. Republican Strategist, Former Trump Surrogate, Erin Elmore. Great to see you Erin as always.

ERIN ELMORE, FORMER TRUMP SURROGATE: You as well.

MCDOWELL: Lea, I see you everyday even in the hall. And I know you are so fired up about -- because there is so much news in the markets from earnings. We have the first reading on the third quarter GDP coming up which could be a huge market mover as well.

KEVIN KELLY, KELLY AND COMPANY MANAGING PARTNER: I don't --

MCDOWELL: Even though (INAUDIBLE) I say it is a market mover.

KELLY: I couldn't sleep last night. I mean it was just like I was so excited, there's so much happening. And the people we have coming on today to talk about it, I mean that's what I'm even more excited about.

MCDOWELL: Well, let's tee that up. Thank you for teeing it up Kevin.

KELLY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And coming up this morning, Venture Capitalist and Partner of (INAUDIBLE) Peter Thiel. His conversation with Maria. New York Stock Exchange president, Tom Farley. Softbank Investment Advisor CEO and Board of Director, Rajeev Misra. And TV And Film star, Kevin Sorbo on his new movie and so much more coming out.

By the way, I'll be on "Outnumbered " later with Kevin Sorbo as the one lucky guy.

But first, we are keeping an eye on earnings, a big day for interview with Exxon, Chevron, and Phillips 66 all out with quarterly numbers before the bell.

The pharmaceutical giant, Merck also expected to report within the hour. And, of course, we're watching shares of Amazon after the company reported record quarterly revenue. Amazon also reportedly getting into the pharmacy business.

That was according -- I love being able to attribute stories to individual newspapers. There's a story in the" St. Louis Post-Dispatch" that Amazon has received approval for wholesale pharmacy licenses in at least 12 states.

This as the drugstore giant CVS is said to be in talks to buy the nation's third largest health insurer Aetna for more than $66 billion. Kevin, where do you want to start? Do you want to start with Amazon and then this deal because they kind of go one -- they go together.

KELLY: I think it's pretty interesting to report on Amazon right now and given the fact that Amazon even (INAUDIBLE) is 52-week high. So we actually saw it reached $1,082 a share.

The interesting aspect about Amazon is the biggest threat to them is regulation. We see that they don't even really pay taxes. When you look at Walmart, they're paying billions of dollars of taxes every single quarter.

So the big play here on Amazon is their Amazon web services. They continuously dominate in that facet. The clear number one -- Microsoft is number two really in cloud services but they don't even compete.

What they're trying to compete on is really what's called hybrid cloud. So what that means is companies that have servers on site, they can actually replicate it up in the cloud too so they can pull from the cloud as well as on site.

Now what's interesting is, Amazon did a deal with VMware last October to compete against Microsoft on that. And Amazon web services, they continuously cut their cost to be the number one player in that space.

So it's so interesting how Amazon conducts business and then you start to see it play out into the pharmacy side, right, because they have the delivery mechanisms, right, the logistics. Their -- 50 percent of their sales are third party distributors on the e-commerce sites, so that's pretty telling.

MCDOWELL: Huge move up in Aetna stock on those report yesterday. And by the way, it is the top story in "The Wall Street Journal" today. Boo, there you go, $66 billion offer.

Multiple meetings between the two CEOs of CVS and Aetna, how could this potentially change not just CVS's business? Because CVS has been moving toward more of a healthcare business as their overall retail sales as a percentage of their revenue have been falling, the smaller percent of their revenue.

But this could do -- in the "Journal" they point out, this could leverage negotiations with drug makers for CVS over -- it would get a great deal, more health data from owning Aetna and it would be -- give an ability to strike new deals that tie drug prices to patient outcomes.

I just think that the possibilities are limitless when you have a pharmacy like this buying a health insurance company.

KELLY: Yes. And the -- yes. And that's the interesting aspect, right? CVS has no experience whatsoever in the insurance business. And then they're coming out the gate and they're buying one of the largest health insurers.

And this goes back to drug pricing, right? We've seen a lot of chatter about pharmacy benefit managers and what the rebates are being. On drug pricing you have the drug makers pointing to the pharmacy benefit manufacturers and you have the insurers pointing it back at them.

So it's such an interesting dynamic and this shows you how much it's going to change over the next couple years and CVS is trying to get in front of that.

MCDOWELL: I think that it's fascinating to just think about the possibility with Amazon filing these wholesale pharmacy licenses that -- because people in Washington, even President Trump has talked about on the campaign trail driving down the cost to prescription medications.

Well how about letting the private industry to it with the license -- Amazon coming and becoming a major negotiator with these drug company.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: And I think one of the things that we'll see is how regulators get involved and how lawmakers get involved.

As you mentioned in regulations if Amazon does move in, but I think that that will be balanced by the potential for drug prices to come way down if Amazon does get into pharmaceuticals.

ELMORE: Well Amazon does everything right. But I sort of feel that --

MCDOWELL: Until they don't. That day is coming, we just don't know when that might happen.

ELMORE: Well I think Amazon has captured a lot of CVS's market share in terms of their retail products. And now that Amazon is the one that's getting into the pharmaceutical world, is CVS sort of the one that the cat chasing its tail?

KELLY: Yes. I think the interesting aspect about Amazon and what they're trying to do here is that they are -- the next leg of growth for them in their stock price and that's what we need to focus on is their ad sales, right?

So they just are opening a new headquarters here for ad sales. What they're going to do is server replacement on the front page. So if you're a company, they've got what you listen to on your -- on Amazon Music, they've got instant prime video, now they're going to see what you buy at the pharmacy, they have -- they're delivering it to you.

MCDOWELL: People talk about Amazon's getting too big but if you read into these earnings reports from Microsoft and Google's parent company Alphabet, there is still a competition out there for Amazon in myriad ways.

Alphabet reported a 40 percent increase and non-advertising revenue, that's strength of its cloud competing business, that was $3.4 billion there. And then Microsoft had a huge surge and two critical components of its cloud computing business as your infrastructure services in the Office 365 online.

Both of those, the revenue there respectively up 90 percent and 42 percent. So there is competition for some of Amazon's businesses.

KELLY: Yes. Well, there's -- they're broken up differently. Which Microsoft --

MCDOWELL: Right. Which you've mentioned earlier.

KELLY: Right. So Microsoft is sort of the utility play and they actually pay a dividend like that. Think about how Google doesn't even pay a dividend, okay? And they're constantly reinvesting.

So what Microsoft did is they switched their business from one time enterprise sales into subscriptions, right? So for Office 365 you now pay on a yearly basis it automatically updates, you rollover, you get the latest edition.

So they're all trying to transition. And what they do best for all these companies is they have the best leaderships. (INAUDIBLE) came out, Microsoft finally got to -- off to the races and dominating in their actually core competencies.

MCDOWELL: And one thing I'll point out because I'm a stats nerd, in one hour after the close of trading yesterday after the earnings came out for Alphabet, Amazon, and Microsoft, $80 billion in market value was added.

I said that at the top of the show, $80 billion in one hour for three companies. Really incredible -- again, you want to know why the markets moving up despite D.C. doing nothing on tax reform so far or healthcare reform is because of these earnings.

KELLY: Yes, exactly. Largest sector in the S&P500 and they've also benefited from the weak dollar.

Clearly the New York Stock Exchange is the leading exchange in the world for listings. We have something like $34 trillion of market caps. The next closest exchange is a tiny, tiny fraction of that.

And so in terms of the deepest liquidity in the world that's in the United States. Brand name -- you get that from the New York Stock Exchange. It's also a rigorous governance test to be listed in the New York Stock Exchange. So if you list there, you're holding yourself out to be a very well-run, well-governed company.

That is kind of the decision criteria that benefits what the New York Stock Exchange brings. But I have no doubt other exchanges around the world have their own unique benefits as well.

FARLEY: So large IPOs are nerve-racking. We do them a lot. Of the top 20 IPOs of all time, I think the number is 13 have been on the New York Stock Exchange. And even those companies that fall on the other seven many of them have ultimately listed in the New York Stock Exchange.

We know a lot about big deals and the New York Stock Exchange is purpose- built for those big deals. We combine humans and technology but we still spend a lot of time getting ready for those IPOs because there is a lot of bids and offers that come in that. There's a lot of complexity on that moment the stock opens. FARLEY: I'm glad you asked that. You know, the American audience likes to make a big deal out of a story. There are not as many American tech companies going public. And that's true. Some of the great American tech companies have chosen to stay private.

It's an amazing tech story. And the Friday company, too was a technology company that offers gaming, e- commerce and payments from Singapore. We just don't talk about it as much frankly because it's not American.

But these are great tech companies choosing to go public, choosing the New York Stock Exchange fortunately. I'm appreciative that they did choose the New York Stock Exchange.

BARTIROMO: Well, here is a stat for you -- listed public companies in the U.S. down 50 percent over 20 years because of the regulatory environment. I mean the President has said he is calling for IPOs, the bar for IPOs to be lowered.

FARLEY: You know, I think you are referring to our press report that came out. And if you work your way down that press report the next paragraph starts with some of the efforts of the New York Stock Exchange and I personally have engaged in, to push the administration to make it easier to engage in IPOs.

You mentioned the number of public companies. It is down by about half.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FARLEY: But the average market cap is up by over three times -- The aggregate market cap. So the average company is five or six times bigger. The public market works great for big companies. It's not working as well for small companies.

BARTIROMO: That's exactly right.

FARLEY: And we need to acknowledge that because small companies are the life blood of free enterprise. They give the inspiration to even smaller companies. They create jobs.

BARTIROMO: So what can you do? What can you do to get more small companies to go public then?

FARLEY: Simple things. The pendulum has swung too far on regulation with Dodd-Frank and Sarbanes-Oxley. Big companies can handle it. Small companies can't. So if you can allow the small companies during the IPO process to meet more with investors and analysts, you can reduce the Sarbanes-Oxley requirements on small companies.

Like for example, not require an external audit for the first few years that a company is public. And you could extend that to all new companies not just the tiniest ones but expand the envelope a little bit and have it be for all new companies that are new to public market.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean one thing is create a longer window of time in which companies can be in the emerging growth category.

FARLEY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FARLEY: Exactly. And what that emerging market growth category does is it just requires less regulation for small companies.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FARLEY: You know, regulation is like taxes.
