KELLY: Well, I'm glad you brought up tax receipts because I'm extremely worried because the Fed keeps saying we haven't had inflation but they're looking at the wrong indicators. Look at asset inflation, it's been unbelievable, look at health care, the price of health care has gone up exponentially. The price of getting a college education has gone up significantly. So when they're talking about the PCE and they're talking about CPI, those are all just like, you know, areas for them to deflect. Asset inflation they've even been worried about. Now, do you see headwinds coming about because now we're at -- I'm looking where recession highs for the dollar, 10-year yields are going up. I mean, do you see that this could be the only two-quarter GDP for that we get that's good given the headwinds?

POMBOY: Well, this is what I worry about, you know, I'm glad you talked about the rising cost of health care intuition, housing expenses have gone up a lot in the couple of years. So if you strip out housing in health care, you know, that's 40 percent of the increasing in consumer spending. So discretionary spending as I said, you know, has been slowing and actually, people are now relying more on credit cards and transfer payments to, you know, cover their everyday necessities. So I think it's a major issue and then you've got the Fed doing Q.T. which isn't going to help in terms of, you know, tightening credit conditions, et cetera. So this is why again, I come back to the urgency of really getting these tax cuts through and getting some relief because right now, clearly the trend toward decelerating growth notwithstanding this current GDP, the third quarter is, you know, going to continue.

MCDOWELL: This is the best six-month stretch since mid-2014 for the economy in terms of GDP, and the commerce department said that this was particularly interesting or strong, because of the hurricane. We were still able to grow at three percent for the quarter. And this is the first reading, it could be revised downward or upward, but, again, it was particularly spectacular for that reason because of the weather.

POMBOY: Yes. I mean I think the things to watch going forward is what's happening obviously on the consumer spending front, like you said, you know, I think some of the data actually, the monthly data had been surprisingly strong over that hurricane period. We did see yesterday, retail inventories were much weaker though when you saw auto inventories thankfully, you know, post their largest decline since the recession and that's sort of a silver lining of this hurricane, and you might have provided all these producers some relief on the inventory front because they've been dealing with very high --

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: Yes, here we go. Consumer spending gain was driven by motor vehicles as Americans replaced cars damaged by the storms and then services spending by contrast flow to its weakest since 2013, so that goes into your kind of discretionary spending outside of housing and health care.

MCDOWELL: What about inventories and --

KELLY: Yes. I'm pulling that out.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Can I ask you real quick about the Fed and the plan to unwind balance sheets the Fed, what risk do you see in terms of future GDP from that?

POMBOY: Well, I think we are credit dependent economy, you know, I always talk about how it's the car basically, and credit is the fuel that gets it going, and we've actually reached the point where we rely -- we're getting worse mileage basically, we need gas in the tank go each additional GDP mile. So if you're to start to reduce the supply of fuel in the economy, the credit fuel which is what the Fed is basically going to do but natural tendency of the economy is going to be to grow with a slower rate. And we're already, you know, in the deceleration phase and the interesting thing on that too is bank credits, total bank lending has already rolled over sharply ahead of Q.T. So, we haven't gone to see the real Fed tightening and yet credit conditions are already starting to slow down. So this again, you know, just underscore why I'm really focused on the tax cuts because, you know, we got to pass the baton from monetary to fiscal policy, and right now, you know, it's a nail-biter.

KELLY: Yes. And trading inventories added a combined 1.14 to the growth.

POMBOY: OK. Yes. It was supposed to add about .8, so that's a substantially larger ad.

KELLY: Yes.

POMBOY: So real final sales been were one-six.

KELLY: Yes.

POMBOY: So that's not, you know, that's not from 2.9 last quarter. That's a pretty big slowdown. So -- anyway, totally we'll get this tax cut.

POMBOY: (INAUDIBLE) in the --

KELLY: Real economy.

POMBOY: In the real economy. That would be nice.

MCDOWELL: Stephanie, it's so good to see you always. Because you all -- every time we talk to you, you always tell us something that we don't know and it's just a different --

(CROSSTALK)

POMBOY: Well, that's my job. I think, you know, let's focus on the stuff these people are focused on.

MCDOWELL: Some people kind of tell you what you've already heard 800 times. Not you, Stephanie Pomboy. Good to see you. Thank you so much.

POMBOY: Thank you so much.

MCDOWELL: Have a great weekend. Big oil in focus this morning as well, Exxon and Chevron reporting earnings, both companies topping expectations. Joining us now is price futures group senior market analyst, fox business contributor, Mr. Phil Flynn. Mr. Flynn, what do you see in these earnings?

PHIL FLYNN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Yes. Oh my gosh. We're putting the big back in big oil. How about that? I mean, these are companies that a couple years ago were given up for dead, ExxonMobil used to be the biggest energy company in the world, moved down to number four, Chevron, of course, had some major problems with earnings, but what a comeback right now, especially if you look at ExxonMobil, what an amazing earnings quarter when you consider the fact that their entire refining operation on Gulf Coast was under water last quarter.

They're saying that their earnings would have been even better, you know, four cents better if it weren't for that situation. So we're seeing something going on that's reflected not only in oil prices but in the GDP. You know, sometimes this comeback in oils really reflective of what we've been seeing in the economy and the economy that's recovering not only here but around the globe, and that's why I'm really excited about big oil and big earnings because that means the economy is feeling, demand for oil and natural gas is going up, that means people are working so this is great news for the economy today.

MCDOWELL: Phil, great to see you as always. Phil Flynn.

FLYNN: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Take care. Coming up. An electrifying performance from tech. Stuart Varney weighing in on the huge gains from industry giants like Amazon, Microsoft, Google. And is the key to getting back on track going off the rails? Why General Electric is said to be considering an exit from its railroad business.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Titans of tech, Amazon, Microsoft, Google, are they more powerful than we thought? Joining me now with his thoughts, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Mr. Stuart Varney.

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: Even more powerful than we thought. Well, yes, I guess they are. I mean, turning in a performance like that yesterday afternoon, those profit gains and now the stock price gains, I mean, for those of you who are listening too what's on the radio, let me read this out. Amazon is $81.00 a share, Microsoft is up $5.00 a share, that's about seven percent by the way, and Alphabet up is $43.00 per share. Did anybody see this coming? I didn't. I don't know about these analysts but I certainly didn't, that was an absolutely blowout performance. And it extends the power of the American technology into whole new industries. Why CVS is looking at Aetna, a corner drugstore with a health insurer, why? Because Amazon is just around the corner coming on strong when may be the delivery prescription drugs. They are everywhere, these five technology companies, they're just astonishing and quite frankly, Dagen, I am blown away by it, period.

MCDOWELL: Stuart, because the decision if you're an investor, it literally -- and we have talked about this for years. It literally comes down to do I want to own a piece of a great American business that's getting even big -- bigger that is dominating a variety of fields or do I want to lend Uncle Sam the Federal government, money for 10 years, and only get paid less than 2-1/2 percent in yield because that's really the decision if you're buying a treasury versus a stock.

VARNEY: That's right. Let's weigh this up, shall we? Do I join the marking global economy and buy into technology stock and then my money goes through the roof or do I lend -- as you say, lend to Uncle Sam and get me two percent? Which do I do? OK. I'm dead safe with Uncle Sam, I got it but I'm going nowhere. I'm taking a risk with technology, but I'm going somewhere. As for putting new money in now, that I'm not so sure of. I'm going to hold off on that, but as everybody knows, I do I own some Microsoft and my point today is I'm not selling at this point.

MCDOWELL: Do you think Satya Nadella of Microsoft makes better decisions with your money or Congress? We already pay taxes, that's -- I know that's a little simplistic but I always think --

(CROSSTALK)

VARNEY: No, it's a loaded question. That's what it is. You know where I'm coming from too.

MCDOWELL: You're fantastic each and every day.

VARNEY: I do.

MCDOWELL: Stuart is coming up in almost exactly 15 minutes. A reminder, "VARNEY & COMPANY" every day, 9:00 a.m. Eastern time. Three whole hours of Mr. Stuart Varney.

The first reading on how fast the economy was growing last quarter coming in much better than expected. Nicole Petallides on floor at the New York Stock Exchange. Hey, Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN HOST: Hey, good Friday morning, Dagen. Yes, that's right. We're seeing the economy here in the U.S. in the latest quarter grow faster than expected, at three percent rate faster than the 2.5 percent rate that was expected. Why did that happen? That was consumer and also business spending that helped it along and that's why you did see that growth there despite Harvey and Irma.

Taking a look at Futures right now, up 17 points for the Dow Jones Industrial Average. We'll see if we can make some records today. Taking a look at Merck, though, Dow component, Merck, that is to the downside this morning, sales dropped three percent overall. It did very well with KEYTRUDA. That is their U.S. long -- that's a cancer patient -- U.S. cancer -- lung cancer and that really helped them along but not enough to break through. Stock down 2-1/2 percent, profit beat, they raised the outlook but a sales miss overall.

Then there's Colgate-Palmolive, so that was relatively flat. Let's take a look at that. It did ramp up ad spending, about 20 percent ramped that up, and that cut into the numbers. That is down one-third of one percent. And good old G.E., well, G.E., of course, you know, we reported recently how it's dropped out of the dividend portfolio for Morgan Stanley. Well, now, they're exiting and saying that they want to exit out of the railroad business. Just not seeing the demand, it is a seasonal business, it is -- is it inconsistent, and they have so many others from aviation to power, health care, just to name some.

So, this morning, we're seeing it up one-quarter of one percent, but we did see those new lows as to -- on 10.26 of 21.20. We're not too far off of that, so people are holding to this one for the long term, they've been ultimately very disappointed, and there is talk (INAUDIBLE) outlook they might be cutting the dividend, too. And that's why Morgan Stanley, ultimately, tried to pull them out of that portfolio for wealth management because it's not really what they're looking for big picture.

We have much more, MORNINGS WITH MARIA, coming up right after this, happy Friday to you. Keep it here on Fox Business.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: If Tesla wants to revolutionize how we drive, Zero Motorcycles who wants to take your love of the road to the next level. No noise, no vibrations, but all the power and torque of the best bikes out there. It's electric and it's the next great American brand, completely made in the United States. Joining me now, is Zero Motorcycles' CEO, Sam Paschel. Tell me about the bike, Sam, because I'm a Harley fan, that's a regular old-fashioned and internal combustion engine.

SAM PASCHEL, ZERO MOTORCYCLES CEO: It is.

MCDOWELL: And this is not anything like that.

PASCHEL: It is. This is -- it's the most innovative motorcycle in the world. If you're familiar with a Harley, something like a Harley Sportster 1200. Will have about 73 foot-pounds of torque. That's basically how much force is being applied to that back tire to really give you the acceleration. Zero Motorcycles -- the bike right in front of us has about 116 foot-pounds of torques. So, you're getting the acceleration and performance out of a, like a modern day superbike out of one of these electric motorcycles.

MCDOWELL: Are you going after the audience that Harley Davidson goes after? What's your key demographic?

PASCHEL: The key demographics, we have three basic types of riders that make up the majority of who we reach out to. First, we have riders that tend to have more than one motorcycle in the garage. You know, the electric motorcycle phenomenon, electric vehicles overall are still pretty new. In 2011, there were about 2,000 plugin vehicles sold in the United States overall, four wheels, two wheels, everything else. Flash forward it last year, and there were about 160,000 plugin vehicles sold in the United States and about 780,000 globally. So, this phenomenon is catching on. But within the motorcycle community, it's still relatively new. So, the three types of riders we generally get are riders who have a quiver of bikes that have more than one motorcycle in the garage. We get new riders, people, that don't have that established connection with any one brand. And throw a leg over a Zero and just fall in love with it.

And three, and actually, probably the most common, we have riders who love motorcycle riding at one point in their life, and then for one reason or another, had a family, had kids, moved away from it, and now it's the lure of electric and the differentiated ride that's really drawing them back.

MCDOWELL: I've been on a Harley or eight in my days, and these bikes, they don't have the roar and the rumble of a Harley that Harley riders and devotees really crave.

PASCHEL: It's true. It's true. If you think about riding a motorcycle, and you've been on one, it's a -- it's an experience that uses all five senses. Three of those senses on an electric motorcycle are going to be completely different than they are on a gas bike. First, as you mentioned, is the -- is the audio, the sound. You're not going to have that same rumble. You're not going to have that same sense of sound. You're going to hear your surroundings a lot better. You can hear what's going on around you but you're not going to have that roar.

Number two, the smell and the fumes of a gas bike aren't really going to be there.

MCDOWELL: Which is my cologne.

PASCHEL: Which is your cologne. It's not mine today. It's not mine today. It's the reason --

MCDOWELL: I'm just kidding.

PASCHEL: -- I'm stepping on further way. But third, and I think most important is all the -- all the vibration that you tend to feel with the gas bike, you don't feel with an electric motorcycle. So the only thing you're really feeling is your connection to the road and the ride. For me --

MCDOWELL: These are made in the United States, made in America just like the Harley, so is that a selling point, too.

PASCHEL: It's a huge point for our consumers. The bikes have been engineered from the ground up, designed and are all built in the bay area, in Northern California.

MCDOWELL: How -- what are your sales like year-over-year, how much are they growing?

PASCHEL: They were growing in about a 35 percent compound annual growth rate. It's similar to what's happening in the E.V. space. And two dynamics at play, one, is a motorcycle market that tends to be a bit flat. The second is an E.V. market that's growing rapidly. Luckily for us, we're tending to follow a curved of the E.V. market.

MCDOWELL: What about other products that you might be looking at outside of motorcycles?

PASCHEL: So, we have -- we have three basic business segments. The first is the commercial motorcycles which are for sale to consumers and motorcycles for us --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: And I interviewed the founder of the company years ago when the first bikes were rolling out.

PASCHEL: Yes. Neal was fantastic; he was a NASA-funded engineer at one point, and a mountain bike and a motorcycle enthusiast.

MCDOWELL: Right.

PASCHEL: The second segment for us is fleets and military. It's a great application for local police forces. And third is this powertrain business, where their companies that realize they're a little bit behind the curve on electrification, we've got millions of miles underneath the bikes, we've got 11 years of experience and they're coming to us to help them electrify the products that they have already created.

MCDOWELL: Sam, good to see you. Please come back.

PASCHEL: Thanks so much for having us.

MCDOWELL: I wish I would get on one but -- I'm not wearing my motorcycle pants today. Sam Paschel, thank you so much.

PASCHEL: Thank you so much. (INAUDIBLE) come out to California and we'll get your leg throw over a bike.

MCDOWELL: Yes, on a day like today, it's a little chilly, I'll take even Northern California, the coldest place on the planet in the middle of July. Thank you so much, Sam.

PASCHEL: Thank you very much.

MCDOWELL: It's really good to see you. Coming up, final thoughts from our all-stars.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: I don't know why that song reminds me of Kevin Kelly but it does. Final thoughts right now. Erin, to you first.

ELMORE: I drank a whole Starbucks, it's obvious, Frappuccino, so I'm all juiced up today. My vote is for Trump to keep yelling as a (INAUDIBLE). Have a happy weekend.

MCDOWELL: Kevin?

KELLY: I'm going to bring -- wear my piano key necktie next time I'm out here, and also it's important to note that CVS, only 14.5 percent of their customers use mail order subscription through their pharmacy, Amazon is coming for you.

MCDOWELL: And Lea, final thoughts

GABRIELLE: So the Congress, the budget resolution, well, that was due back in April. It's almost Halloween, if they get started on next year's now, then they might get it done by Independence Day. So I'd say, get it moving.

MCDOWELL: And here's my final thought to the people in Congress, the GOP who are writing that house -- that tax reform bill, if you touch 401(k) plans and make this market tank, you're going to own that, and you will feel the wrath of President Trump for your remaining days in Congress. A big thanks to Erin Elmore, Kevin Kelly, and Lea Gabrielle. Have a great weekend, everybody. Mr. Varney starts right now with "VARNEY & COMPANY."

Stuart, I don't know it if I'm early or late, but it's all yours.

VARNEY: I'll take it. I'll take it, Dagen, gratefully. Thank you very much indeed, Dagen. All right.

END

urn:contentItem:5PVC-P6H1-JBHT-D0J6-00000-00Earnings Extravaganza; Big Tech Crushes Earnings; CVS Eyes Aetna; The Missing Files; X Marks the Spot; Amazon Earnings; Earnings in Focus;2017-10-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:30ZLexisNexisEarnings Extravaganza; Big Tech Crushes Earnings; CVS Eyes Aetna; The Missing Files; X Marks the Spot; Amazon Earnings; Earnings in Focus;LanhamFULL TEXT

RIVA GOLD, REPORTER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Thanks for having me.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN HOST: All right. That is it for "FBN:am." We now turn it over to the lovely, the talented Dagen McDowell and say good morning. "Mornings With Maria" start now.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Back at you Cheryl. We'll see you in a little bit. Thank you so much.

Good morning everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, October 27th. Your top stories at 6:00a.m. Eastern.

Earnings extravaganza, we are awaiting reports from big names including Merck, ExxonMobil and Chevron this morning. This comes after one stellar afternoon for some tech titans, Amazon, Microsoft, and Google all delivering better than expected earnings results.

Amazon shares jumping on the news making CEO Jeff Bezos $6 billion richer. By the way, Google and Microsoft hitting all time highs in the post market. And it wasn't the only good news for the retailer, Amazon gaining wholesale pharmacy licenses in multiple states.

The move, part of the driving force behind CBS reported proposal to buy health insurer Aetna for a staggering $66 billion.

Futures are showing this in the markets right here right now, gains across the board. The DOW Industrial Futures up 42 points at the moment. This is after gains yesterday in the markets.

FARLEY: I'm glad you asked that. You know, the American audience likes to make a big deal out of a story. There are not as many American tech companies going public. And that's true. Some of the great American tech companies have chosen to stay private.

The last week alone, we had a young man who started a company three years ago to provide a technology that allows for consumer lending in China -- that company is now worth over $10 billion. It's an amazing tech story. And the Friday company, too was a technology company that offers gaming, e- commerce and payments from Singapore. We just don't talk about it as much frankly because it's not American.

BARTIROMO: Well, here is a stat for you -- listed public companies in the U.S. down 50 percent over 20 years because of the regulatory environment. I mean the President has said he is calling for IPOs, the bar for IPOs to be lowered.

The Treasury came out with a report. They're basically saying the regulatory environment is way too hard for companies to go public.

What are you doing in terms of lowering the bar, in terms of lowering the standards, making it easier for companies to go public?

FARLEY: You know, I think you are referring to our press report that came out. And if you work your way down that press report the next paragraph starts with some of the efforts of the New York Stock Exchange and I personally have engaged in, to push the administration to make it easier to engage in IPOs.

You mentioned the number of public companies. It is down by about half.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FARLEY: But the average market cap is up by over three times -- The aggregate market cap. So the average company is five or six times bigger. The public market works great for big companies. It's not working as well for small companies.

BARTIROMO: That's exactly right.

FARLEY: And we need to acknowledge that because small companies are the life blood of free enterprise. They give the inspiration to even smaller companies. They create jobs.

BARTIROMO: So what can you do? What can you do to get more small companies to go public then?

FARLEY: Simple things. The pendulum has swung too far on regulation with Dodd-Frank and Sarbanes-Oxley. Big companies can handle it. Small companies can't. So if you can allow the small companies during the IPO process to meet more with investors and analysts, you can reduce the Sarbanes-Oxley requirements on small companies.

Like for example, not require an external audit for the first few years that a company is public. And you could extend that to all new companies not just the tiniest ones but expand the envelope a little bit and have it be for all new companies that are new to public market.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean one thing is create a longer window of time in which companies can be in the emerging growth category.

FARLEY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FARLEY: Exactly. And what that emerging market growth category does is it just requires less regulation for small companies.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FARLEY: You know, regulation is like taxes. No regulation isn't the answer and complete government control isn't the answer -- somewhere in between is the right answer, and the pendulum is going to swing. We have swung too far towards heavily regulating small companies and we need to swing it back aggressively to make sure that that IPO engine is there for those young entrepreneurs.

BARTIROMO: What does the sentiment feel like to you when you go down on the floor, when you speak to big investors? FARLEY: I walk in on the floor and I look up at the indices every morning and it's amazing what has happened since November.

BARTIROMO: Don't you think?

FARLEY: We're 17400 that night, if you remember because the indices really cratered and now they had zipped back up. However I will note, it's also a global story. This isn't just America. In the last two weeks alone the DAX, the CAC, the (INAUDIBLE) -- they have all hit all-time highs.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible.

FARLEY: So there is a really -- this is a really good moment globally.

BARTIROMO: So do you feel like sentiment is still there? The bullishness or are people getting worried that things are getting over priced?

FARLEY: People are bullish. That doesn't mean there won't be a pullback but people are bullish without question.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Tom -- it's great to see you.

FARLEY: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much.

FARLEY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Tom Farley is the president of the New York Stock Exchange.

PASCHEL: It is. This is -- it's the most innovative motorcycle in the world. If you're familiar with a Harley, something like a Harley Sportster 1200. Will have about 73 foot-pounds of torque. That's basically how much force is being applied to that back tire to really give you the acceleration. Zero Motorcycles -- the bike right in front of us has about 116 foot-pounds of torques. So, you're getting the acceleration and performance out of a, like a modern day superbike out of one of these electric motorcycles.

MCDOWELL: Are you going after the audience that Harley Davidson goes after? What's your key demographic?

PASCHEL: The key demographics, we have three basic types of riders that make up the majority of who we reach out to. First, we have riders that tend to have more than one motorcycle in the garage. You know, the electric motorcycle phenomenon, electric vehicles overall are still pretty new. In 2011, there were about 2,000 plugin vehicles sold in the United States overall, four wheels, two wheels, everything else. Flash forward it last year, and there were about 160,000 plugin vehicles sold in the United States and about 780,000 globally. So, this phenomenon is catching on. But within the motorcycle community, it's still relatively new. So, the three types of riders we generally get are riders who have a quiver of bikes that have more than one motorcycle in the garage. We get new riders, people, that don't have that established connection with any one brand. And throw a leg over a Zero and just fall in love with it.

And three, and actually, probably the most common, we have riders who love motorcycle riding at one point in their life, and then for one reason or another, had a family, had kids, moved away from it, and now it's the lure of electric and the differentiated ride that's really drawing them back.

MCDOWELL: I've been on a Harley or eight in my days, and these bikes, they don't have the roar and the rumble of a Harley that Harley riders and devotees really crave.

PASCHEL: It's true. It's true. If you think about riding a motorcycle, and you've been on one, it's a -- it's an experience that uses all five senses. Three of those senses on an electric motorcycle are going to be completely different than they are on a gas bike. First, as you mentioned, is the -- is the audio, the sound. You're not going to have that same rumble. You're not going to have that same sense of sound. You're going to hear your surroundings a lot better. You can hear what's going on around you but you're not going to have that roar.

Number two, the smell and the fumes of a gas bike aren't really going to be there.

MCDOWELL: Which is my cologne.

PASCHEL: Which is your cologne. It's not mine today. It's not mine today. It's the reason --

MCDOWELL: I'm just kidding.

PASCHEL: -- I'm stepping on further way. But third, and I think most important is all the -- all the vibration that you tend to feel with the gas bike, you don't feel with an electric motorcycle. So the only thing you're really feeling is your connection to the road and the ride. For me --

MCDOWELL: These are made in the United States, made in America just like the Harley, so is that a selling point, too.

PASCHEL: It's a huge point for our consumers. The bikes have been engineered from the ground up, designed and are all built in the bay area, in Northern California.

MCDOWELL: How -- what are your sales like year-over-year, how much are they growing?

PASCHEL: They were growing in about a 35 percent compound annual growth rate. It's similar to what's happening in the E.V. space. And two dynamics at play, one, is a motorcycle market that tends to be a bit flat. The second is an E.V. market that's growing rapidly. Luckily for us, we're tending to follow a curved of the E.V. market.

MCDOWELL: What about other products that you might be looking at outside of motorcycles?

PASCHEL: So, we have -- we have three basic business segments. The first is the commercial motorcycles which are for sale to consumers and motorcycles for us --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: And I interviewed the founder of the company years ago when the first bikes were rolling out.

PASCHEL: Yes. Neal was fantastic; he was a NASA-funded engineer at one point, and a mountain bike and a motorcycle enthusiast.

MCDOWELL: Right.

PASCHEL: The second segment for us is fleets and military. It's a great application for local police forces. And third is this powertrain business, where their companies that realize they're a little bit behind the curve on electrification, we've got millions of miles underneath the bikes, we've got 11 years of experience and they're coming to us to help them electrify the products that they have already created.

MCDOWELL: Sam, good to see you. Please come back.

PASCHEL: Thanks so much for having us.

MCDOWELL: I wish I would get on one but -- I'm not wearing my motorcycle pants today. Sam Paschel, thank you so much.

PASCHEL: Thank you so much. (INAUDIBLE) come out to California and we'll get your leg throw over a bike.

MCDOWELL: Yes, on a day like today, it's a little chilly, I'll take even Northern California, the coldest place on the planet in the middle of July. Thank you so much, Sam.

PASCHEL: Thank you very much.

MCDOWELL: It's really good to see you. Coming up, final thoughts from our all-stars.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: I don't know why that song reminds me of Kevin Kelly but it does. Final thoughts right now. Erin, to you first.

ELMORE: I drank a whole Starbucks, it's obvious, Frappuccino, so I'm all juiced up today. My vote is for Trump to keep yelling as a (INAUDIBLE). Have a happy weekend.

MCDOWELL: Kevin?

KELLY: I'm going to bring -- wear my piano key necktie next time I'm out here, and also it's important to note that CVS, only 14.5 percent of their customers use mail order subscription through their pharmacy, Amazon is coming for you.

MCDOWELL: And Lea, final thoughts

GABRIELLE: So the Congress, the budget resolution, well, that was due back in April. It's almost Halloween, if they get started on next year's now, then they might get it done by Independence Day. So I'd say, get it moving.

MCDOWELL: And here's my final thought to the people in Congress, the GOP who are writing that house -- that tax reform bill, if you touch 401(k) plans and make this market tank, you're going to own that, and you will feel the wrath of President Trump for your remaining days in Congress. A big thanks to Erin Elmore, Kevin Kelly, and Lea Gabrielle. Have a great weekend, everybody. Mr. Varney starts right now with "VARNEY & COMPANY."

Stuart, I don't know it if I'm early or late, but it's all yours.

VARNEY: I'll take it. I'll take it, Dagen, gratefully. Thank you very much indeed, Dagen. All right.
